Marc Catlin \n  \n   \nRep. Patrick Neville \n  \n  \nBy Charles Ashby \nSaturday, January 28, 2017 \n \nDENVER \u2014 The new leader of the House Republicans isn\u2019t earning a lot of friends on the Western Slope. \n \nThat\u2019s because many people are upset that House Minority Leader Patrick Neville, R-Castle Rock, didn\u2019t appoint his caucus\u2019 newest member, Rep. Marc Catlin, R-Montrose, to the House Agriculture, Livestock & Natural Resources Committee. \n \nThey considered it a no-brainer that Catlin would gain such an appointment. He is an undisputed expert in water issues, particularly on the Western Slope, \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s just ridiculous,\u201d said Christian Reece, executive director of Club 20, a Western Slope advocacy group. \u201cThe committee and the House as a whole would benefit greatly if they used his skills. One would think that appointments would be based on a legislator\u2019s skill set. With attempts to implement the statewide water plan this year, it\u2019s important to have a strong voice from the Western Slope on such a committee.\u201d \n \nInstead of being appointed to the ag panel and the House Transportation Committee \u2014 as his predecessor, now Sen. Don Coram, R-Montrose, was \u2014 Catlin was assigned to the House Public Health Care & Human Services Committee and House Finance Committee. \n \nCatlin has no health care, social service or financial background. Instead, he is an acclaimed expert on water issues. \n \nHis job outside of public service is as water rights development coordinator for Montrose County. He also is a former manager of the Uncompahgre Valley Water Users\u2019 Association and a longtime member of the Colorado River Water Conservation District board of directors. \n \nNeville, who refused to be interviewed for this story, has sole discretion over what committees members of his caucus get. But because Republicans lost seats in the House in last year\u2019s elections, that also meant there are fewer seats in House committees for GOP members. \n \nAs a result, coveted committees such as agriculture and transportation end up going to more senior members. \n \nStill, not including someone such as Catlin is a hard pill for Western Slope legislators to swallow because of his vast knowledge on water law, especially when considering who else is on the panel, those lawmakers said. \n \nThe 13-member committee is dominated by lawmakers who hail not just from the Front Range, but from the South Platte River Basin. That\u2019s the region that has the highest population and the greatest need for more municipal water supplies. \n \nThe rest break down to two for the Colorado River basin on the Western Slope, two in the Arkansas River basin in southeast Colorado, and one in the Rio Grande River basin in the San Luis Valley. \n \nThat means when water issues \u2014 which historically divide along basin lines rather than political ones \u2014 come up for votes, the northern Front Range region out-votes the other basins combined, 8-6. \n \nThe Western Slope lawmakers on the panel are Reps. Yeulin Willett, R-Grand Junction, and Diane Mitch Busch, D-Steamboat Springs, both of whom agreed that Catlin\u2019s voice on the panel would be welcomed. \n \nChris Treese, executive director of the Colorado River Water Conservation District, said the Western Slope deserves a greater voice on that committee because the bulk of the state\u2019s water is located here. And someone like Catlin, who has more direct experience with water issues than Willett, an attorney, or Mitch Busch, whose background is in sociology, can speak more knowledgeably about the subject, Treese said. \n \n\u201cMarc\u2019s whole life has been water, Marc\u2019s family has been water, is water, and for the sake of the House ag committee and for the sake of the whole General Assembly, his expertise is being wasted,\u201d he said. \u201cFrom the perspective of his district, the vacancy committee elected him in large measure because of that significant background, that natural resource, water-specific background. I know they are disappointed that he is not being assigned in a way that\u2019s consistent with the talents that he brings to the Legislature.\u201d \n \nMontrose rancher Jay Jutten, a Republican, said people like him look to their elected officials to represent them in far-away Denver, and now is not so sure he\u2019s getting that. \n \n\u201cWe\u2019re over here in the back 40 and we see the Front Range getting a lot of attention,\u201d he said. \u201cThe representation we get, we need them on those committees that are important to us. I\u2019m not saying that the committees Representative Catlin is on aren\u2019t important, but agriculture is huge, transportation is huge for the Western Slope.\u201d \n \nBoth Treese and Reece have sent letters to Neville in recent weeks asking him to reconsider Catlin\u2019s appointments. Neville hasn\u2019t yet responded to either. \n \nAs a result, Reece sent a similar letter to other House Republican leaders, two of whom, Reps. Lori Saine of Dacono and Perry Buck of Windsor, sit on the ag committee. \n \nCoram, who replaced Sen. Ellen Roberts, R-Durango, when she resigned her seat in December, creating the vacancy for Catlin, said he\u2019s been getting dozens of emails and telephone calls about the matter. \n \nCoram, who sat on the agriculture and transportation committees when he served in the House, was assigned to the Senate ag committee when he switched to the Senate. \n \nHe said he\u2019s aghast at Neville\u2019s assignments not only for the ag committee, but transportation, too. \n \n\u201cLooking back at the ag committee for as long as I can remember going back to the \u201860s, there has never been a time a Western Slope Republican agricultural person has not been on the committee,\u201d Coram said. \u201cAnd there was never a time when there wasn\u2019t a Western Slope Republican on the transportation committee.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Charles AshbySaturday, January"},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"},{"name":"US politics news","group":"Society"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"House GOP leader under fire for panel assignments","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Montrose","zipCode":"81401","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Montrose","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169683150","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1618"},"name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard","Local","Geographic"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.gjsentinel.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194732451","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:04:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:43Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T04:47:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395785709","companies":[{"symbol":"002340","primary":true,"name":"GEM Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"SHE","titleCount":0,"isin":"CNE100000KT4"},{"symbol":"08355","primary":true,"name":"i-Control Holdings Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"HKG","titleCount":0,"isin":"KYG4708D1016"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"MOUNTAIN BIKING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"RESORTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"CYCLING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"EXTREME SPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SNOWBOARDING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"MOUNTAINS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"INTERNET & WWW","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"}],"wordCount":"923","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395785709&p=2kx&v=1&x=MQjag5rPfFRQnOXQ-j42Fw","id":"29395785709","content":"Skiing: Your most basic questions, answered     \nJulie Norman cruises down Cow Camp run at Powderhorn Mountain Resort recently. Powderhorn is a great resort for those seeking a good place to ski. There are plenty of runs for all levels and abilities and it is more affordable than other resorts in the state. For those who are new to skiing, some of the most basic questions need to be answered before hitting the slopes \u2014 like where to ski. \n  \n   \nSuzanne Foster Porter keeps an eye on her son, Elliot, 4, during a recent run at Powderhorn Mountain Resort. Elliot is showcasing the wedge, the best way to stop on skis. \n  \n   \nWhether skiing or snowboarding, the most important thing to do is stay safe. That means controlling your speed and wearing a helmet. \n  \n  \nBy Julie Norman \nSaturday, January 28, 2017 \n \nI was researching content marketing for my \u201creal\u201d job here at The Daily Sentinel and found this interesting tool called \u201cAnswer the Public\u201d (askthepublic.com). It\u2019s a way to use keywords to identify questions that have been asked online about a particular topic. Since it\u2019s winter and I\u2019m not mountain biking, I used \u201cskiing\u201d as my keyword and discovered that most of the questions people seem to ask are very basic ones. \n \nThat makes sense to me because, well, sometimes you don\u2019t want people to think you don\u2019t know things; that\u2019s what makes the internet great. So here are the answers to some of those questions I found. I hope those of you reading can find them useful or put them in the hands of those who will. \n \nWhen skiing, how do you stop? I saw this in several variations. To stop when skiing, you can either wedge your skis (push your heels out) to form a \u201cpizza\u201d slice, or you can use a \u201chockey stop.\u201d This requires knowing how to turn. If you can turn, do that and then push your heels down and the edges of your skis into the hill. If neither of those options works, just sit down, but make sure your skis are pointing across the hill, not down it! \n \nWhy is skiing so much fun? I think that answer probably differs from person to person. I like the challenge of it and I enjoy the scenery. If you\u2019re skiing, chances are you\u2019re in a beautiful place! It\u2019s also exhilarating to swish down a slope (staying in control of course) or glide through untracked powder. It\u2019s also a great digital break; I cannot ski and text at the same time. Honestly, it\u2019s just fun! If you need to ask the question, maybe it\u2019s not the sport for you. \n \nWhat is the fall line? The fall line is the direction of the slope or, the direction gravity leads you as you\u2019re skiing down it. Sometimes portions of slopes can have a \u201cdouble fall line\u201d which means that it has a standard downhill slope, but also that part of the run may be angled to one side (Maverick and Red Eye at Powderhorn have this feature in places). \n \nWhat is carving? Carving refers to a type of ski turn. When you tip your skis onto the edges, the sidecut of your skis causes them to bend and an arc to form. The ski then follows this arc to produce a turn. \n \nHow do I control my speed? Make another turn. You can also slow your turns by making wider turns (though this can cause more harm than good sometimes because if you turn too wide and slow down too much you won\u2019t be able to make the next turn). \n \nWhere are the best places to ski? This is a totally subjective question based on where you live, the type of terrain you enjoy, and how long you\u2019ve been skiing. If you live here on the Western Slope, the best place to ski is Powderhorn. It\u2019s easily accessible, has beginner, intermediate, and expert terrain, and is more affordable than large resorts. \n \nIf you don\u2019t mind traveling a bit, Snowmass is another great option but again, that\u2019s my own opinion. If you\u2019re looking for unique places to ski, do some online research to learn about different resorts. You might check out other Colorado Gems (coloradoski.com/gem-card) to find small, family-friendly resorts across Colorado. To look for resorts with great deals, try Liftopia.com. \n \nWhich muscles does skiing use? Downhill skiing mostly engages your quads and gluteal muscles. However, I can tell you that after a long day of skiing, your quads, calves, and even arms may be sore. \n \nYour arm muscles get used more than you might think when you\u2019re skiing. If you have to push with your poles down a long cat track (think: heading to Tenderfoot at Powderhorn) you\u2019ll use arm strength to help with that. If you fall and have to push yourself up, you\u2019ll again be using arm muscles to assist you. Mostly though, your quads are getting the biggest workout. If you want to start training for ski season in the fall, try squats, lunges, and cycling. \n \nWhich is safer, snowboarding or skiing? Either can be dangerous if you aren\u2019t in control and aren\u2019t paying attention to your surroundings. Ski or board at a speed at which you feel comfortable; don\u2019t let friends talk you into going faster than you want. Make sure you\u2019re on terrain that is suited to your abilities. Don\u2019t go down an expert run if you just took up the sport last week. Be aware of who and what is around you (trees, other skiers or boarders) and always wear a helmet.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Julie NormanSaturday, January"},"topics":[],"title":"Downhill discussion","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Montrose","zipCode":"81401","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Montrose","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169683150","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1618"},"name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard","Local","Geographic"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.gjsentinel.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194733049","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T04:47:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:42Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T04:55:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395785710","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[],"wordCount":"562","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395785710&p=2kx&v=1&x=kfxG-VTy1lccCxO_KZTNUw","id":"29395785710","content":"Fruita Monument\u2019s Gunner Rigsby rises up for a dunk Saturday during the Wildcats\u2019 47-13 victory over Montrose. Rigsby scored a game-high 21 points as the Wildcats set a school record for fewest points allowed in a game. \n  \n \nBy Dale Shrull \nSaturday, January 28, 2017 \n \nTrey Morrill made it tough on Montrose when he was at the top of Fruita Monument\u2019s suffocating 1-3-1 zone defense. \n \nAt 6-foot-6, the lanky, long-armed Morrill took away passing lanes and harassed Montrose ball-handlers beyond the top of the key. Then, to start the fourth quarter, Morrill snagged a steal near midcourt and took off, the crowd roaring in anticipation. \n \nMorrill didn\u2019t disappoint as the senior soared in high above the rim for a powerful dunk to put the Wildcats up 40-9. \n \nFruita Monument (9-9, 2-1) used that swarming defense throughout to come away with a 47-13 Southwestern League win over Montrose on Saturday. \n \n\u201cWe just want to create a lot of havoc up there,\u201d Morrill said about the zone defense. \u201cWe want to create steals and get layups and dunks. Our best defense is our greatest offense, and we have a great defense.\u201d \n \nOffensively, the Wildcats started quick with a three-point play from Gunner Rigsby and a 3-pointer from Jake Brizzolara for an 8-0 lead. \n \nThe 5-foot-10 Rigsby, who finished with a game-high 21 points, slipped a dunk over the rim later in the first quarter, and followed that with a highlight-reel underhand scoop for a bucket to put the Wildcats up 20-2. \n \nBut it was the Wildcats\u2019 defense that was the real star of the game. The 13 points allowed was a school record for Fruita Monument, breaking the old mark of 16. \n \n\u201cWe just kept working and working on defense, and the rim just kept getting tighter and tighter for them,\u201d Fruita coach Billy Dreher said. \n \nMontrose (6-11, 0-3 SWL ), a team of underclassman, was no match for the Wildcats\u2019 size, experience and athleticism. \n \nMorrill finished with eight points and Brizzolara seven for the Wildcats. \n \nFruita Monument Fruita girls cruise past Indians \n \nAngelique Gall\u2019s solid all-around game led Fruita Monument to a 56-24 Southwestern League win over Montrose. \n \nIn the first quarter when the Wildcats took a 21-5 lead, Gall did a little everything. \n \nThe Wildcats (16-1, 3-0 SWL) pounded the ball inside to the junior, who scored the first 10 points of the game and 12 of her 16 points in the first quarter. \n \nGall also scored off an offensive rebound, blocked a shot and forced two steals in the opening quarter. \n \nRosa Lopez added a 3-pointer and the Wildcats were cruised toward another blowout win. \n \n\u201cThey had a smaller lineup and we knew we wanted to get the ball inside,\u201d Gall said. \u201cWe knew it was going to work with any of our post (players),\u201d \n \nAs usual, the Wildcats\u2019 swarming defense, including a half-court press, was key to the win. \n \nMontrose (11-6, 1-2 SWL) finally crashed in on Gall, who took a pass inside at the post, then kicked it out to a wide-open MacKenzie Wells on the wing who swished a 3-pointer. \n \n\u201cThat\u2019s one of my favorite things to do, especially kicking it out to our guards,\u201d Gall said. \n \nCoach Michael Wells shuffled players in and out for the rest of the game, with reserves getting plenty of playing time. \n \nThe second quarter was choppy for the Wildcats until Amy Stagg drilled a 3-pointer. Then, with the clock winding down, Alexis Prall swished a 3-pointer at the buzzer to put give the Wildcats a 31-10 lead at halftime.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Dale ShrullSaturday, January"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"\u2018Cats break record with stifling D","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Montrose","zipCode":"81401","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Montrose","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169683150","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1618"},"name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.gjsentinel.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194733217","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T04:55:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:42Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:05:53Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395785711","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"GEOMETRY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ACADEMY AWARDS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"WOMEN","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CALCULUS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"ENTERTAINMENT & ARTS AWARDS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"52"},{"name":"LIFE FORMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"69"},{"name":"ADVANCED PLACEMENT PROGRAMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"MATHEMATICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"71"},{"name":"TARAJI P HENSON","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1306","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395785711&p=2kx&v=1&x=QnhngTbUh9Wa6Gj7ZYOYaQ","id":"29395785711","content":"Cute little boy and girl in front of a big blackboard. Studio shot on black background. \n  \n \nBy Rachel Sauer \nSaturday, January 28, 2017 \n \nThere\u2019s a scene in the film \u201cHidden Figures\u201d in which Col. Jim Johnson (played by Mahershala Ali) expresses surprise to see a woman doing complex mathematics because it\u2019s \u201cso taxing.\u201d \n \nKatherine Johnson (played by Taraji P. Henson), the woman doing the math, replies with this: \u201cOn any given day, I analyze the binomial levels of air displacement, friction and velocity and compute over 10,000 calculations by cosine, square root and lately analytic geometry. By hand. There are 20 bright, highly capable Negro women in the west computing group, and we\u2019re proud to be doing our part for the country. So yes, they let women do some things at NASA, Mr. Johnson. And it\u2019s not because we wear skirts. It\u2019s because we wear glasses.\u201d \n \nThere are a lot of ways the film, nominated Tuesday for the Best Picture Academy Award, can be seen: as women overcoming the times and attendant social barriers; as black women overcoming even more barriers because of their race; and as the triumph of math. \n \nUsed by people who know what they\u2019re doing, math saves the day. \n \nIn \u201cHidden Figures,\u201d it helps the United States win the space race and beat the commies. In life, well, we\u2019d still be living in caves without it, assuming the human species wasn\u2019t dead from some plague that could\u2019ve only been defeated with a foundation of math. \n \nIt would be wrong to call this the Age of Math, because every age has been an age of math or else life as we know it wouldn\u2019t exist, but it seems that finally popular culture is recognizing that the people to celebrate in film and on TV are the ones who know their way around the trapezoidal rule. \n \nIn fact, it\u2019s an especially hopeful sign for math getting its rightful recognition that the female mathematicians in \u201cHidden Figures\u201d aren\u2019t basement-dwelling weirdos incapable of interacting with other humans, but normal, cool, brilliant women who really, really know calculus. \n \nThis is a step up, because how many times in film have the mathematically inclined been portrayed as the geeky, the unstable, the hopeless and the hygienically challenged? \n \nOK, yes, the gang on \u201cThe Big Bang Theory\u201d are huge nerds, but they\u2019re hilarious and that\u2019s a top 10 show. \n \nMaybe Hollywood will continue to recognize that the mathematician on the team is just as valuable, and probably more so, than the beefcake with the gun. Heck, maybe the mathematician is the beefcake with the gun. \n \nMaybe this could be the beginning of everyone loving, or at least appreciating, math just a little bit more. \n \n\u201cMath puts the real world in numbers,\u201d explained Emad Shahnoushi, 17, a junior at Palisade High School and a student in one of teacher Ann Conaway\u2019s AP calculus classes. \n \nAt the end of a recent class, the 15 boys and 11 girls in attendance that day pondered what they love about math. \n \n\u201cBecause it makes sense.\u201d \n \n\u201cIt has a right answer.\u201d \n \n\u201cIt explains science.\u201d \n \n\u201cBecause it has rules and it\u2019s not arbitrary like every other subject,\u201d said Shaun Arhelger, 17, also a junior, and only half joking. \n \nThis was at the end of a lesson on the trapezoidal rule, which began with an exercise Conaway designed based on the Stephen King book \u201cThe Girl Who Loved Tom Gordon\u201d: \u201cNine-year-old Trisha McFarland is Hopelessly lost in the woods, and the efforts of those looking for her have turned up nothing. The graph below shows the woods in which she is lost and measurements of the width of the woods (in miles) at regular intervals.\u201d \n \nThe students had to use the trapezoidal rule to approximate the area of the woods and the number of people it would take to scour the entire woods in a single day, based on one person being able to search 15 square miles per day (which Conaway acknowledged is extremely generous). \n \nLike she does occasionally, because that\u2019s how math is approached in the real world, Conaway allowed her students to pull their super-strength calculators from their backpacks, though she wants them also to be able to do the calculus on paper. \n \nUltimately, after a few hits and misses \u2014 \u201cWe make a lot of mistakes in math,\u201d Conaway said, \u201cand the learning comes in when you recognize the mistake and figure out how to fix it.\u201d \u2014 it was determined that the woods were 51,850 square miles and the search would require 3,457 people. \n \nSo, this one\u2019s for the people who ignominiously lump arithmetic and mathematics together, who sneer, \u201cWhen am I ever going to use calculus in the real world?\u201d \n \nYou might not, but here\u2019s hoping the search and rescue team does. \n \nAnd yes, granted, not everyone is good at math, just like not everyone is good at laying tile or fixing cars or doing public relations. Maybe even reading about that trapezoidal rule exercise made you itchy and uncomfortable. \n \nBut math \u2014 so foundational, so fundamental \u2014 has long borne the stigma of being \u201chard.\u201d Remember the talking Barbie debacle from the late \u201890s, when one of her programmed phrases was \u201cMath is hard!\u201d \n \nTee hee! If everyone thought that way, Barbie, then you\u2019d probably want to stop driving your convertible over any bridges or near any kind of man-made structure. \n \nConaway said while some students do psych themselves out about the difficulty of math before they attempt it, District 51\u2019s emphasis on Habits of Mind is encouraging students to at least be willing to try. \n \n\u201cThrough the integration of Growth Mindset and Habits of Mind into our classrooms, students are more and more willing to treat things that are difficult for them as a challenge and an opportunity,\u201d explained Josh King, a math teacher at Central High School. \u201cOur school has been emphasizing the importance of effort over skill to encourage students to learn from their mistakes. \n \n\u201cGrowth Mindset is an ideology that is based on the work of Dr. (Carol) Dweck and revolves around the idea that our brains are malleable. Depending on our approach to tasks, concepts, etc. we can either let our prior experience hold us back and use it as an excuse (fixed mindset), or we can look at tough situations as a chance to grow \u2014 \u2018I can\u2019t factor that trinomial YET\u2019 (growth mindset).\u201d \n \nPerhaps it\u2019s this mindset that will raise the number of undergraduate students pursuing math-intensive majors, which has not seen net growth over the past 30 years, according to the Mathematical Association of America (maa.org). We need students in math-intensive majors! There will be no smartphone innovations, no space stations, no efficient machines, no crowd control, no urban design without them! \n \nPlus, consider this: Start typing the name \u201cIsaac\u201d into the Google search bar. All it takes is \u201cIsa\u201d and Google suggests \u201cIsaac Newton.\u201d Talk about a legacy! Who doesn\u2019t want to be that famous? Or at least as cool as, say, Neil deGrasse Tyson or Elon Musk? Or as visionary (and rich) as Bill Gates? \n \nThere is art in math, and elegance. British author G.K. Chesterton opined, \u201cThe difference between the poet and the mathematician is that the poet tries to get his head into the heavens while the mathematician tries to get the heavens into his head.\u201d \n \nAnd in \u201cThe Housekeeper and the Professor,\u201d Yoko Ogawa wrote, \u201cSolving a problem for which you know there\u2019s an answer is like climbing a mountain with a guide, along a trail someone else has laid. In mathematics, the truth is somewhere out there in a place no one knows, beyond all the beaten paths. And it\u2019s not always at the top of the mountain. It might be in a crack on the smoothest cliff or somewhere deep in the valley.\u201d \n \nYes! Math! The ultimate adventure! The uncharted territories! Let\u2019s keep this zeitgeist going! \n \nMath is hard? No, math is awesome.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Rachel SauerSaturday, January"},"topics":[],"title":"Finally! 28, 2017 \n \nThe  Salvation Army Thrift Store formerly located at 1155 N. Fourth St. has moved into the old Harbert Lumber building at 240 North Ave. and is open for business. \n \nCustomers can make purchases using cash or check while the internet is being installed, said Capt. Steve Staneart , commanding officer of the Grand Junction corps. \n \nStaneart said an arrangement with the Harbert family allowed the move, which may be permanent. \n \n\u201cThe Harbert family has been on our board for generations, and they were very kind to us to allow us to go in there for something we could afford,\u201d he said. \n \nThe Salvation Army is leasing the space for a year, with an option to buy the building if it\u2019s a good fit. \n \nStaneart said the building has nearly double the space as the old thrift store, and includes a yard that will be useful since the organization just received a license to do after-school care for children. \n \nThe organization will keep the former store building and plans on repurposing it for after-school programs offering arts, education, character development and sports. \n \nThe Salvation Army also spruced up its Clifton store at 3227 I-70 Business Loop B, Staneart said. \n \nThe stores are open from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m., Monday through Saturday. \n \nFor more information, call 242-7513 or visit grandjunction.salvationarmy.org. \n \n■ Customers of the building materials supply company ProBuild , 2773 Riverside Parkway, probably have noticed the new signage and new name of the operation, Builders FirstSource , as they whizzed by along the parkway. \n \nIt\u2019s not a new business \u2014 just the final step in an acquisition process that began in July 2015. \n \n\u201cWe\u2019re just now getting the signs changed,\u201d an employee at the newly branded store said this week, adding that the store is the same as what people remember. \n \nAt the time it was announced that Builders FirstSource was acquiring ProBuild, officials said the combined company would help better focus on their four critical customer segments: production builders, custom builders, multifamily/commercial builders, and repair and remodel businesses. The leverage of being a part of a national network \u2014 Builders FirstSource had 430 locations, and served 74 of the top 100 metropolitan statistical areas across 40 states at the time of the deal \u2014 is presumably a perk of the combination. \n \nIf you\u2019re wondering, Wikipedia via the United States Census Bureau says Grand Junction is the 279th statistically most populous metro are in the country, \n \n■ One end-of-the-year list that escaped our clutches until now was the Forbes \u2019 Ranking of America\u2019s 100 Largest Banks, which included some notable local strength. \n \nGlacier Bancorp , parent to Bank of the San Juans , ranked high on the list, at number five. \n \nUS Bancorp, or US Bank, was listed at number 58, and Wells Fargo ranked number 66, both respectable finishes on the list, which ranks banks based on metrics related to growth, profitability, capital adequacy and asset quality, Forbes said. \n \nAll of the data Forbes relied on for the list is based on regulatory filings for the period ending Sept. 30, 2016. \n \nThe magazine\u2019s ranking of the 100 largest banks was borne out of the financial crisis of the late 2000s, when credit quality was cratering across the banking industry. \n \n■ \n \nDo you know about an area business opening, closing, moving or changing? {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395785717","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"TALKS & MEETINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"POLITICAL PARTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"63"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"NEWS REPORTING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"FREEDOM OF PRESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"PUBLIC HEARINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"943","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395785717&p=2kx&v=1&x=JQx33hGyyNk7VSzjB37Shw","id":"29395785717","content":"By Staff \nSaturday, January 28, 2017 \n \nI am a retired educator and appreciate and thank you for the recent articles on District 51 and their students. However, I think it is quite shameful for our local newspaper to give the education articles more precedence than the inauguration of the 45th president of the United States, Donald J. Trump, on Friday. I looked for an article on the inaugural proceedings in Friday\u2019s paper and found it almost on the bottom of the front page with a headline in much smaller type than the school news. I thought, OK, maybe they are waiting until Saturday when they will show a larger picture and include a more impressive article. But I was disappointed again this morning. Same spot, same size photo and a small article. Guess I should have been thankful it was on the front page and not on Page 9A, which had a large photo, a small photo and a big article on the protesters. \n \nWhile various elected officials have often had big crowds for town hall meetings, the Grand Junction Women\u2019s March crowd of thousands publicly venting multiple issue opinions to an elected official is unprecedented \u2014 and entirely worthy as a front page newspaper story. \n \nIt was wonderful to see the strong images of the Women\u2019s March last weekend in downtown Grand Junction. If I knew there was a planned march, I would have driven in from Montrose to join. Count me in next time. \n \nThank so much for your coverage of the Women\u2019s March. Not only did it happen here but all over the world. Perfect example of our First Amendment rights. \n \nI\u2019m a little confused. I did not vote for President Trump, but yet he is my president. I did not yell vulgarities, I did not burn a limousine, and I did not march in protest over an imagined loss of rights wearing a \u201c##### hat.\u201d That in itself seems ignorant and self-degrading and has put the women\u2019s movement back to square one. I don\u2019t see how meaningless violence and uninformed protests will bring our country back together. But those are the things The Sentinel chose to give top billing in last Sunday\u2019s paper. Somebody help me. \n \nThank you, Daily Sentinel, for your great coverage of our local Women\u2019s March. How wonderful to see so many folks, of all ages, gather and walk together to promote tolerance, peace, unity and respect. \n \nFront page photograph from anti-president march mentions Japanese internment camp with no mention that those U.S. citizens were locked up by a Democratic Party president. \n \nThanks to The Daily Sentinel for its in-depth reporting regarding the Women\u2019s March. I was there to witness the event from the sidelines, and am pleased to say the newspaper article simply reported the facts (not \u201calternative facts\u201d). During this time when the media is being heavily criticized, it is increasingly important to protect this independent source of information as guaranteed by our Constitution. \n \nMesa County Commissioner John Justman says \u201cMesa County voters are conservative\u201d and thinks that\u2019s the only thing that should guide whatever he does in office. But the huge anti-Trump protest last week showed Mesa County in 2017 is far from being monolithic in its political views. There are lots of liberal and progressive residents in Mesa County, and our views count as well. We are tired of local elected representatives completely ignoring our views, as Mr. Justman does. Commissioner Justman needs to start respecting and representing our views as well. \n \nA tax increase is the way to get projects financed. I would be happy to approve an increase for a rec center. We have event centers \u2014 the fairgrounds, Avalon, Two Rivers, Las Colonias Park, the Botanical Gardens, James M. Robb Colorado River State Parks. How many do we need? We need a rec center. \n \nWe have a hockey rink and an events center. What we need is a rec center. It is a great place for children, youth, adults and senior citizens. I will never vote for anything but a rec center. \n \nIf the \u201ccity fathers\u201d think a $62 million investment is a great idea, how about spending it on an activities center that every citizen could use and enjoy? \n \nTo the jerk who almost killed us last night, Jan. 20: We were coming home and ready to turn left at 32 Road and \u2028C 1/2. My husband put on the left turn signal, happened to look in the mirror and saw you coming on the left at a very excessive speed, running from a sheriff\u2019s car. A few more seconds and you would have T-boned us and we would probably be dead today. In the future, be a decent human being and face up to whatever you did wrong instead of running away and endangering innocent people. \n \nOh, my goodness, Steve Beauregard! You have outdone yourself with your \u201ctaking turns for the worse\u201d column! Every time I read it, I see something else that just makes me laugh out loud. You know the Grand Valley, you live here and enjoy the valley. Keep up the witty writing. We all need a good laugh now and then, eh? \n \nIt is unfortunate to read about the dog killing on Orchard Mesa, but not a surprise, assuming the dog owner and Mesa County Animal Services had been made aware of the problem. It is unfortunate people being disturbed by a nuisance dog have to take the law into their own hands. A no-win situation for both parties. \n \nIf you call Xcel and give them the location of the burned out streetlight they will replace it. The one on the corner of Pitkin and Fifth strobes at night, which is dangerous for epileptics.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"StaffSaturday, January"},"topics":[{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"You Said It, Jan. 29, 2017","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Montrose","zipCode":"81401","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Montrose","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169683150","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1618"},"name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard","Local","Geographic"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.gjsentinel.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194733913","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:42Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

The cost of attending CMU ranges from roughly $18,900-$35,000, depending on residency, according to the univeristy\u2019s website. \n \nStudent-athletes receive athletic scholarships, but few, if any, of the coaches at CMU can afford a full international scholarship. \n \nAll international students who have an incoming grade-point average of 3.0 or higher can qualify for an $8,000 financial scholarship, $4,000 per semester. \n \n\u201cSadaam (Yousufzai), he\u2019s incredibly, incredibly bright and he wouldn\u2019t be here unless we could kind of package that together,\u201d men\u2019s soccer coach Todd Padgett said of the freshman from Afghanistan, who went to an American high school in Ontario, Canada. \n \n\u201cIt helps us tremendously. That\u2019s $8,000 we don\u2019t have to come up with, it\u2019s something they\u2019ve earned and the university awards them. Now that $28,000 figure is brought down to $20,000. \n \n\u201cWhen we\u2019re looking at an international player, the importance of that player qualifying for that amount of money is almost vital because of where our budget is at and what we have the ability to provide an international player is just simply not $30,000. But we can get the conversation started if you\u2019re able to knock that down to 20. Let\u2019s say out of pocket in your mind is another 10, now suddenly we\u2019re taking about $10,000 as opposed to $30,000.\u201d \n \nProof of funds isn\u2019t the only step in gaining admission, and working on international student-athlete eligibility can be a long, drawn-out process. \n \n\u201cThe most difficult thing I\u2019ve run into with international students is from the transcripts and test scores, and having either one, the original documents, two, a translation, or three, both,\u201d said Austin Kaiser, CMU\u2019s assistant athletic director for compliance and student services. \u201cThey have certain eligibility requirements and submissions into the (NCAA) eligibility center, that I can see, and that determines if they\u2019re eligible that first year or not. \n \n\u201cFortunately, the NCAA does take care of a lot of that, but they have certain requirements for what we have to submit. The challenge comes when a kid comes over from southwest Asia or Europe and they submitted originals to the institution, but that\u2019s all we have. \n \n\u201cOr we have a copy the institution can verify that yes, this is official, but the NCAA asks, we need an official copy, and if you don\u2019t have that, we need a certified, stamped copy of your transcripts, with a certified translation of your transcripts, and that has to be mailed in. There are certain criteria for what they need. It\u2019s difficult.\u201d \n \nKaiser has an NCAA website bookmarked on his computer that breaks down what\u2019s required. \n \n\u201cYou feel for the student-athletes, they don\u2019t necessarily know what\u2019s needed,\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s part of the education process, but until they\u2019re here, it\u2019s hard to educate them on that. All of a sudden the clock starts ticking on when to get it all in.\u201d \n \nAt CMU, Kaiser and the coaches rely on the admissions department and Annie Gingerich, who handles all international student admissions. Kaiser laughs that when an international student-athlete has a question about his or her status, the first words out of his mouth are often \u201cGo see Annie.\u201d \n \n\u201cShe\u2019s phenomenal,\u201d he said. \n \nAlong with eligibility and compliance, Kaiser\u2019s duties include student services, whether that\u2019s arranging tutoring, counseling or just being a sounding board for all athletes. \n \n\u201cI have 700 children, so I can\u2019t be the counselor for every single one of them. Something that I do best as I can is refer to the great resources we have on this campus,\u201d Kaiser said. \n \n\u201cIt all starts with them oftentimes coming into my office and sitting down and kind of having a heart-to-heart conversation, this is what I need. I\u2019d be lying if I said it\u2019s every single one of them every single day. It\u2019s pretty rare, but nonetheless that\u2019s where it starts. \n \n\u201cThey can come in here and shut the door and say whatever needs to be said. From there, I can say I think it is in your best interest to see this person. I\u2019ll help set up appointments, make phone calls, referrals, whatever it is.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Patti ArnoldSaturday, January"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: athletics news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Attending Mesa not cheap for foreign athletes","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Montrose","zipCode":"81401","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Montrose","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169683150","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1618"},"name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.gjsentinel.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194734255","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T04:48:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:42Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

COLORADO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"479","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395785607&p=2kx&v=1&x=2H-7EN0bWc2fXzO4SRhotQ","id":"29395785607","content":"By Katie Langford \nSaturday, January 28, 2017 \n \nWhat do a fruit grower, a high school student, a mayor, a teacher and a college student have in common? \n \nThey\u2019re all immigrants, in one way or another. \n \nNearly 100 people attended a panel discussion about immigration at the Mesa County Central Library on Saturday, and five Grand Valley residents spanning several decades talked about their experiences living in \u2014 and sometimes feeling separated from \u2014 their local community. \n \nFor a few of them, like Grand Junction Mayor Phyllis Norris and longtime Palisade fruit grower Bruce Talbott, immigration dates back hundreds of years, to when their ancestors first arrived in the American colonies. \n \nFor West Middle School teacher Therese Moran, who is Native American, moving across the country was the result of circumstance as often as it was of choice. \n \nFor Colorado Mesa University student Shristi Adhikari, who immigrated from Nepal as a child, and Palisade High School student Emad Shahnoushi, who immigrated from Iran as a child, growing up in two countries has produced struggles and victories. \n \nAdhikari was at the panel in place of her father, Kamal, who has worked at the Nepal Restaurant in downtown Grand Junction for more than a decade. She moved to Grand Junction from Nepal when she was 12 years old. \n \n\u201cMy dad really wanted us to be able to succeed, and that\u2019s one of the main reasons he came to the U.S.,\u201d she said. \u201cEvery day I\u2019m so grateful for my dad and what he\u2019s done.\u201d \n \nAdhikari said it was hard adjusting to the language and culture for the first three years she lived in the United States. \n \n\u201cI have struggled and I do struggle, but through all of those struggles and adversity I\u2019m still very, very grateful,\u201d she said. \n \nShahnoushi said his father was separated from his family for long periods of time in his efforts to move from Iran to the United States, first for multiple failed attempts to get a visa from the American embassy in Turkey, and later in moving to Hong Kong for two years to obtain a visa there. \n \n\u201cWe went through a lot of hardships to get here,\u201d he said. \u201c(My father) is the reason I\u2019m here today and the reason I\u2019m able to have these opportunities.\u201d \n \nTalbott said he doesn\u2019t often experience discrimination within his orchards and farms. \n \n\u201cWe are dependent on a quality of worker that we can\u2019t get indigenously,\u201d he said. \n \nBut when his workers seek employment other places in the Grand Valley, racial discrimination is a factor. \n \nThere were a few moments of visible frustration, and one audience member vocally disavowed President Donald Trump\u2019s recent ban on refugees and travelers from several predominantly Muslim countries, including Syria. \n \nBut overall, attendants and speakers spoke of the need for unity. \n \n\u201cIt takes each and every one of us to do it, and it takes a lot of hard work,\u201d Norris The case remains ongoing. \n \nIn Beauford\u2019s case, attorney David Lane wrote: \u201cA common thread in (several civil suits against the company) \u2026 is that CCS and related companies ignored obvious signs and symptoms to deny inmates access to necessary emergent care. Such deficiencies are the custom, practice and standard operating procedure of defendant CCS and its related entities.\u201d \n \nCompany spokesman Jim Cheney wouldn\u2019t comment on Beauford\u2019s case specifically, but said Lane\u2019s claim was ludicrous and that the company\u2019s employees are trained under policies that follow National Commission on Correctional Healthcare guidelines. \n \n\u201cTo make the broad assertion that it is our standard practice to ignore the needs of our patients is simply ridiculous and completely without merit,\u201d Cheney wrote in an email. \n \nCheney said policies are in place to deal with patients who refuse medication. In the case of low-functioning patients, employees are expected to try to identify their guardian, then follow local protocol for mental health patients. \n \nCorrect Care Solutions has a year-to-year contract with the county, according to Mesa County sheriff\u2019s spokeswoman Megan Terlecky. \n \nThe company has held the contract since 2015, although it also acquired other groups that held the contract dating back to 2002. NEW ZEALAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"78"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA & NEW ZEALAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"}],"wordCount":"592","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395785631&p=2kx&v=1&x=ZdwRV4lMnWekVRl5qhBdDQ","id":"29395785631","content":"Tony Touri doesn't know where he might have ended up if not for the support of prisoner support group Pars. \n   \nDozens of Australian deportees returning to New Zealand each month, sparking concerns resources are too stretched for them to reintegrate successfully. \n \nHelen Murphy, manager of Prisoners' Aid and Rehabilitation Society of Canterbury (Pars), said Kiwi-born criminals from across the Tasman were \"coming continuously\".  \n \nPolice figures show that of the 660 sent back since January 2015, 218 had offended in New Zealand since their return. \n \nA further 15 arrivals from Australia are expected in February. \n \n  \n   \n   \n   \n   \n   \n   \n \nPolice Association president Chris Cahill said long-term measures were needed to better support the numbers coming through. \n \n\"It's far from an ideal situation. The Aussies think it's great because it's a win win for them.\" \n \nCahill said there was little compassion in the Australian policy, which sent back everyone no matter what their offence. \n \n\"It might be one thing when you've got someone that has committed an armed robbery sitting in jail. It's different when you've got someone who has lived their whole life there and been convicted of a relatively minor offence.\" \n \nTony Touri, 48, landed in Christchurch before Christmas, after stints in jail and an Australian immigration detention centre. \n \nHe left behind his family, a $2000-a-week job and the kickboxing club where he helped train youth. \n \nTouri saw Christchurch as a fresh start with labouring opportunities and a place free from old North Island gang connections. \n \n\"It turned my life upside down. When I arrived here, I felt like an alien.\" \n \nCahill said it had been well proven through released prisoners, that if supports were not in place, the risk of reoffending was greater. \n \n\"These people are sort of similar but there isn't the same support available to follow up with them all the time, so it doesn't surprise me we're getting that 30 per cent reoffending,\" he said. \n \nThe Canterbury branch of Pars has found growing demand for their support service. \n \n\"We could have one in a month. We could get roughly one a week, then two in one week,\" Murphy said. \n \nIn 2014, Pars settled just three people in Christchurch. That figure rose to 15 in 2015 and to 51 in 2016. \n \nFive women were among the group that had arrived since 2014. \n \nCounties Manukau District has the highest population of deportees, with 118 residing in the area.  \n \nAuckland City has attracted 89, while 69 people are listed in Canterbury.  \n \nWellington has 52 returning offenders and 51 are in the Waitemata District. \n \nCorrections deputy national commissioner Rachel Leota\u200b said the provision of effective reintegration services for returning offenders was important because many did not have strong links to New Zealand.  \n \nCorrections budgeted $300,000 a year for five years for providers such as Pars to help returning offenders settle back into life in New Zealand.  \n \nPrior to entering a contract with the Corrections in 2016, Pars received $77,000 from the Christchurch City Council to support deportees. \n \nCahill said before an information sharing agreement with Australian authorities was signed in September 2015, police were lucky to get a few hours notice of new arrivals.  \n \n\"Whereas now we are able to prepare a little and have staff meet them.\" \n \nHigh-risk offenders are visited by police 48 hours after arrival. \n \n\"It's good in theory but there simply aren't the resources to do that. And there are no controls,\" Cahill said. \n \nHe said in some cases in Auckland, returning offenders had checked out of supported living arrangements or motels before police arrived for their checkup.  \n \n\"They're not breaking the law per se when they do that, because a lot of them aren't under any restrictions. They're just into the wind.\" \n \n  \n      Comments","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"EMILY SPINK"},"topics":[{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"New Zealand news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"}],"title":"Dozens of Australian deportees are being sent to NZ on a weekly basis","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","countryCode":"NZ","country":"New Zealand"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Timaru Herald","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169685249","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1076"},"name":"Timaru Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://stuff.co.nz"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194735746","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:07:10Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:41Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Ad Feedback \"These people are sort of similar but there isn't the same support available to follow up with them all the time, so it doesn't surprise me we're getting that 30 per cent reoffending,\" he said. \n\nThe Canterbury branch of Pars has found growing demand for their support service. \n\n\"We could have one in a month. We could get roughly one a week, then two in one week,\" Murphy said. \n\nIn 2014, Pars settled just three people in Christchurch. That figure rose to 15 in 2015 and to 51 in 2016. \n\nFive women were among the group that had arrived since 2014. \n\nCounties Manukau District has the highest population of deportees, with 118 residing in the area. \n\nAuckland City has attracted 89, while 69 people are listed in Canterbury. \n\nWellington has 52 returning offenders and 51 are in the Waitemata District. \n\nCorrections deputy national commissioner Rachel Leota\u200b said the provision of effective reintegration services for returning offenders was important because many did not have strong links to New Zealand. \n\nCorrections budgeted $300,000 a year for five years for providers such as Pars to help returning offenders settle back into life in New Zealand. \n\nPrior to entering a contract with the Corrections in 2016, Pars received $77,000 from the Christchurch City Council to support deportees. \n\nCahill said before an information sharing agreement with Australian authorities was signed in September 2015, police were lucky to get a few hours notice of new arrivals. \n\n\"Whereas now we are able to prepare a little and have staff meet them.\" \n\nHigh-risk offenders are visited by police 48 hours after arrival. \n\n\"It's good in theory but there simply aren't the resources to do that. And there are no controls,\" Cahill said. \n\nHe said in some cases in Auckland, returning offenders had checked out of supported living arrangements or motels before police arrived for their checkup. \n\n\"They're not breaking the law per se when they do that, because a lot of them aren't under any restrictions. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:08:21Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395376400","companies":[{"symbol":"01808","primary":true,"name":"Enterprise Development Holdings Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"HKG","titleCount":0,"isin":"KYG3070M1116"},{"symbol":"XV41","primary":true,"name":"Enterprise Development Holdings Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"BER","titleCount":0,"isin":"KYG3070M1116"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"JOB CREATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"SOCIAL MEDIA","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"ENTERTAINMENT & ARTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"76"},{"name":"SPONSORSHIP","domains":["IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"SMALL BUSINESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ENTREPRENEURSHIP","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"HOLDING COMPANIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"ECONOMIC STIMULUS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"86"},{"name":"LEATHER & ALLIED PRODUCT MFG","domains":["IND"],"score":"50"},{"name":"BLOGS & MESSAGE BOARDS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"882","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395785860&p=2kx&v=1&x=ZtcpxHl8V9w2IfsVtdGekg","id":"29395785860","content":"One post at a time is how a young Port Elizabeth blogger aims to change perceptions of townships in Nelson Mandela Bay. \n \nKhanyisa Melwa (23), a Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University public relations management graduate, has a blog focused on creating hope in the townships and showing how to establish thriving small businesses. \n \n\u201cI chose to start a blog to tell township stories in an authentic manner. It was a means of disrupting the single story narrative about townships that always focuses on social ills \u2013 crime, unemployment, strikes and other negative things,\u201d Melwa said. \n \n\u201cYes, these stories can be told but they are not the only things happening in the townships. I want to feature the untold stories about township arts, township business and township people \u2013 how they manoeuvre through their tough day-to-day lives. I want to change the often-held belief about township life.\u201d \n \nHis blog, aptly called Kasifixation, started two years ago and mainly centres on small entrepreneurs operating from street corners in the townships. \n \nKasifixation, a clever combination of the word kasi (slang for township) and fixation (passionate about something), has gained huge mileage on social media, and is opening business opportunities for those featured in the form of sponsorship and funding. \n \nMelwa, who says he is a social entrepreneur, said: \u201cI am very passionate about the township economy, and I believe this is one of the solutions to boost this sector. \n \n\"Most of the businesses I have featured on my blog have since increased their revenues because of the exposure. \n \n\u201cThere is a lot of business potential in the townships, [but it needs] to be tapped to the maximum. \n \n\"For example, the creative arts is a huge sector which, if tapped into, and supported by government, will create many jobs and improve the lives of township people and remove that stigma of townships being thought of as places of crime.\u201d \n \nHe said the creative arts sector could also bring tourists to townships and boost their economy, adding that shebeens are the prevalent business. \n \n\u201cBy my small contribution through my blog, I want to grow the small business which, in turn, will boost the township economy,\u201d he said. \n \nHis next big idea is to set up a \u201ccreative agency\u201d that will help township entrepreneurs market themselves and their products to ensure growth. \n \nMelwa also intends starting Kasi Bioscope \u2013 a pop-up cinema project which will be found in all the townships of Nelson Mandela Bay metro \u201cjust to introduce people to consuming creative art\u201d. \n \n\u201cI like township people to celebrate themselves, like their blackness, within the context of township life,\u201d he says. \n \nTwo of the businesses that have increased their bank balances because of the exposure from Kasifixation are 469 Enterprises, now a holding company of five businesses, and Bambanani Fresh Art, a leather products manufacturing company. \n \nSiyabulela Mandla, the owner of 469, told City Press this week that ever since appearing on Kasifixation, he has featured on national radio and in newspapers and magazines. \n \n\u201cI have other businesses under 469 and these are in the transport, car wash, shisa nyama sectors. My annual turnover has increased substantially, from R800 000 in 2013 to R2.3 million in 2015. \n \n\"So, that first exposure from the blog opened up some doors for me,\u201d he said. \n \nMandla employs 20 people. \n \nHe says that he was interested in business from childhood. \n \n\u201cI always wanted to know how the business industry works ... I used to make and sell wire cars at street corners in Motherwell where I grew up,\u201d he says. \n \nLast year he won the Eastern Cape SAB KickStart competition. \n \nMandla has also started a programme called Kasi Talks Business, where, along with other entrepreneurs, he teaches and trains employees business skills \u2013 from financial management to full entrepreneurship development. \n \nMandla says the euphoria of independence made people forget about the township economy and the import of starting small. \n \nPeople, he explains, thought that after independence they would get everything on a silver platter, earn large amounts of money and start big businesses. \n \n\u201cIt is only after 22 years that they have now realised that the dream will not materialise and are now thinking of spaza shops and other small township businesses,\u201d he says. \n \nMasibulele Matshaya, the owner of Bambanani Fresh Art, also attributes his growth to the blog. \n \n\u201cWe are now in talks with the department of trade and industry with a view to getting a sponsorship. After reading about us in the blog, the department contacted us asking for our profile, but we are still waiting,\u201d he said. \n \nThe company makes leather shoes and accessories such as belts, bags and wallets. \n \nIt employs three people, but hopes to increase the figure in the near future. \n \nTheir annual turnover as per last year was R48 000. \n \n\u201cThe problem is that there are no support systems in the township economy. The potential is massive. Government must assist this sector,\u201d he said, adding that they make 30 pairs of shoes a month. \n \nHe says they receive financial support from the Small Enterprise Development Agency, the Eastern Cape Development Corporation and the National Youth Development Agency. \n Read  Fin24's top stories  trending on Twitter:  Fin24\u2019s top stories \nFollow Fin24 on Twitter , Facebook , Google+ and Pinterest . 24.com encourages commentary submitted via MyNews24 . November's total of $718 million was up by $123 million compared with a year earlier.\n\nThe results reversed a mid-year slump in the state's stamp duty receipts.\n\nTurnover was very strong in the final quarter of the year. Stamp duty was paid on 21,239 residential transfers across NSW in December, which was 31 per cent higher than in July.\n\nThe average stamp duty received per transaction in December was $34,385 \u2013 around $2100 more than the corresponding month a year earlier.\n\nThe strong stamp duty figures suggest Sydney's property market defied predictions of a slow-down and picked up pace in late 2016.\n\nFigures released by the Domain Group last Tuesday showed Sydney's median house price jumped 4.7 per cent in last three months of the year to reach $1.124 million. The city's median unit prices rose nearly 3 per cent in the quarter to $711,256.\n\nDomain's measure of Sydney's median house price has risen by 69 per cent \u2013 or $450,000 \u2013 in the past four years.\n\nWhile the end-of-year surge in stamp duty will bolster the state's already healthy bottom line, the figures also underscore how difficult it will be for the new Premier, Gladys Berejiklian, to improve housing affordability.\n\nAt her first press conference as Premier last week Ms Berejiklian vowed to address the housing affordability crisis, declaring it \"the biggest issue people have across the state\".\n\nShe said specific policies to deal with this challenge would be outlined \"in the near future\".\n\nStamp duty revenue will get a further boost in coming months as a new surcharge on the stamp duty paid by foreign investors comes into effect. The surcharge was introduced in the June 2016 state budget but revenue from the new measure is not expected until early this year.\n\nSydney's four-year housing boom has helped deliver the state government a massive increase in the transfer duty levies on the transfer of property and other assets.\n\nIn 2011-12, just before the boom began, the government received $3.8 billion in transfer duty but that had swelled to nearly $9 billion by 2015-16.\n\nResidential stamp duty alone accounted for about 9 per cent of the state government's revenue last financial year.\n\nThe half-yearly review of the NSW budget, released last month, lifted the forecast for the state's budget surplus for this financial year by about $300 million to $4 billion.\n\nThe story first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Matt Wade"},"topics":[{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Boom bolsters Berejiklian's bottom line","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","zipCode":"2650","state":"New South Wales","countryCode":"AU","zipArea":"Wagga Wagga","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Southern Weekly","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169750061","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Southern Weekly","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.southernweekly.com.au","publisher":"Fairfax Media"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194738643","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:59:37Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:44Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://nnimgt-a.akamaihd.net/transform/v1/crop/frm/silverstone-feed-data/e3c18faa-fe37-48b4-bad2-520457875b09.jpg/r2_0_728_410_w1200_h678_fmax.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

Daso, EFF, Nicholas Nyati, NMMU, Sasco, Udesmo, Zandile Mbabela \n\nSome leaders at NMMU come out against interim structure which will temporarily take place of SRC \n\nAN interim structure put in place to fulfil the vital role usually undertaken by the student representative council (SRC) at NMMU would see the downfall of student politics and activism at the university. \n\nThis was the view of some student leaders on the proposed 10-member structure set to deal with issues facing students for the next 10 months. \n\nThe interim structure was devised as SRC elections could not take place last year. \n\nThe interim structure will be answerable to the student governance and development (SGD) office, a body that administers funds on behalf of student organisations and organises leadership development programmes. \n\nThe annual SRC elections at NMMU should have taken place in September last year but were cancelled amid #FeesMustFall protests which led to a six-week-long closure of the university. \n\nNMMU spokeswoman Zandile Mbabela said SRC elections would take place once a review of the SRC constitution was finalised. \n\n\u201cThe inability to conduct elections essentially laid bare some inadequacies within the SRC constitution in that it does not anticipate a situation where elections cannot be held,\u201d Mbabela said . \n\n\u201cIt does not have the necessary guidelines to deal with an extension of an existing SRC term, nor does it make provision for interim arrangements should elections not be held.\u201d \n\nThe interim structure would comprise two students from each of the four recognised political party affiliates on campus \u2013 Daso, Sasco, the EFF and Udesmo \u2013 as well as two nonpolitical students. \n\nFormer SRC president and Daso representative Nicholas Nyati said the proposed interim student leadership structure was seeking to kill student politics. \n\nNyati said he was convinced the university was trying to strengthen the powers of the student governance and development (SGD) department which answers to university management. \n\n\u201cThis structure is not elected by students, therefore it will not carry a mandate by students but rather a mandate from the dean of students and the SGD, both bodies that get their mandate from management, not students and students are the biggest stakeholders in the university,\u201d Nyati said. \u201cThe amendments are going to favour the SGD and in that way you are killing the student\u2019s voice on campus.\u201d \n\nNyati said the SGD would have deciding power rather than the SRC. \n\nAccording to Mbabela, the SGD office helps provide and promote capacity building in terms of student governance, leadership and co-curricular activities among the student community. Various members of staff and students work in the office. \n\nUdesmo chairperson Zukisa Fuzani echoed Nyati\u2019s sentiments, saying the structure would leave thousands unrepresented. \n\n\u201cThe way that this structure will be put in place is not democratic; students are not being afforded the chance to elect their own representatives. \n\n\u201cNot everyone will be afforded the chance to express their views in the SRC, for example the international office will not be represented,\u201d Fuzani said. Mbabela disagreed. She said: \u201cThe structure is made up of leaders of existing, recognised student formations. \n\n\u201cThey were elected to those positions by students and are therefore in a position to effectively represent them.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Siyamtanda Capa"},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"\u2018New body will kill student politics\u2019","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Africa","subregion":"Southern Africa","countryCode":"ZA","country":"South Africa"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Herald Live","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"458677779","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"5"},"name":"Herald Live","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.heraldlive.co.za"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194739137","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:09:04Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:44Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T04:50:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395785816","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"ETHICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"61"},{"name":"YOUTH CLUBS & ACTIVITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"85"},{"name":"BUSINESS ETHICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"CALENDARS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"ADVICE COLUMNS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; COLORADO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"53"}],"wordCount":"913","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395785816&p=2kx&v=1&x=qlFyPyIUG63S2xTuFnGa9Q","id":"29395785816","content":"PHOTO BY CT\u2014Sent as TAMMY MUG. \n  \n \nBy Tammy Gemaehlich \nSaturday, January 28, 2017 \n \nDear Advice Columnist : \n \nThere\u2019s some new cookies in town that keep hitting on me. \n \nThey said they\u2019d be around a couple of months, but are wanting me to hang with them now. They seemed harmless at first, but every time I see a box, they sweet talk me in to joining them for a bite. I graciously decline, but they are quite convincing and are persistent with their luring, unwanted advances. \n \nI attempt to ignore them and walk away with strengthened willpower, but there\u2019s one that always tries to Tagalong . \n \nAnother asked point-blank if I wanted S\u2019more ? \n \n\u201cSome more what?\u201d I asked, flabbergasted. He didn\u2019t say a thing ... just stared at me with marshmallowy eyes. Sigh. \n \nThe third one suggested we Do-si-do. Seriously? Does he have peanut butter between his ears? He doesn\u2019t even know my name. \n \nThe fourth was a little flaky and flashed his jailbird-like stripes as he whispered softly in my ear, \n \n\u201cSamoa.\u201d \n \nStunned, I replied, \u201csome more \u2018a what?\u201d \n \nThese cookies and their friends are really sweet and tempting, but I\u2019m not interested. How do I resist this temptation and end the incessant flirting? I\u2019m afraid I might crumble and give in, throwing away my thin-meant New Year\u2019s resolution. \n \n\u2014 Cookie Jar Fling? \n \nDear Cookie Jar: \n \nIt is with a big smile \u2014 perhaps a Savannah Smile , that I quote The Borg from Star Trek: \u201cResistance is futile.\u201d \n \nBeginning today, these cookies will be all over the Grand Valley. They are Girl Scout Cookies: Thin Mints, Samoas, Tagalongs, Trefoils, Dos-Si-Does, Savannah Smiles, and Toffee-Tastic (the gluten-free choice). \n \nThis year marks 100 years of Girl Scouts selling cookies and 100 years of Girl Scouting in Colorado. Cookie purchases support girls in developing goal setting, decision-making, money management, people skills and business ethics. And, in return, your mouth is happy. \n \n\u2014 Advice columnist \n \nP.S.: Looking for cookies? Check out the \u201cCookie Locator\u201d at girlscoutsofcolorado.org or get the mobile app to search for booth sale locations. \n \nP.P.S.S.: Girl Scouts from Troops 4274 and 4278 will kick off the 2017 sale with a drive-thru booth from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. today at Walgreens, 316 W. Aspen Ave. in Fruita.  \n \n■ \n \nThe Fruita Lions Club chili supper is planned for 4\u20138 p.m. Saturday at Independence Village, 225 N. Coulson St. in Fruita. \n \nCost is $5 for adults, $3 for ages 6\u201312 and free for ages younger than 6. Diners can choose chili or Judy\u2019s famous chicken noodle soup. \n \nProceeds will go to Fruita Monument High School scholarships. \n \n■ \n \nThe Delta Hubwheelers Square Dance Club has scheduled February dances on Saturday nights, Feb. 4 and Feb. 18, in the aerobics room at the Bill Heddles Recreation Center in Delta. \n \nThe Feb. 4 dance will be a regular dance. On Feb. 18, the dance will have a \u201cValentines\u201d theme, with a bonus potluck dinner at 6 p.m. before the 7 p.m. dance. Both dances will feature club caller Naaman Moorehouse of Grand Junction. \n \nAll dances are Mainstream with Plus tips. Round dances are to recordings and include beginner and advanced levels. Prerounds to recorded cuers begin at 6:30 p.m. Mainstream square dance with Plus calls and round dance cues between tips begin at 7 p.m., ending at 9 p.m. \n \nThose attending are invited to bring food and snacks for all to enjoy at intermission. Call Helen at 856-4187 or Paul at 773-4495 for information. \n \n■ \n \nThe Grand Mesa Peaches Chapter of Questers International is seeking new members and will host a tea from 2 to 4 p.m. Thursday in the Sundowner Building Community Room, 3150 Lakeside Drive, No. 103. \n \nThe program will be \u201cWhy do we collect anything . . . especially antiques?  Or is collection a passion or obsession?\u201d presented by Goldie Ward. Visitors will learn more about Questers and meet chapter members. \n \n\u201cQuester members have a strong desire to see that the best of American heritage is preserved for future generations,\u201d a news release said. \n \n\u201cQuesters seek to educate by research and study of antiques, to raise funds and donate grants for the preservation and restoration of artifacts, existing memorials, historic buildings, landmarks, as well as educational purposes.\u201d \n \nThe three-tiered organization serves members at the local, state and national levels. \n \nIf you would like to attend the tea, please call chapter president, Corine Hesslink at 242-9169 by Jan. 30. \n \n■ \n \nThe Quilts of Valor National Sew Day is Saturday, Feb. 4, and the Grand Valley Valor Quilters will host the local event beginning at 10 a.m. Saturday at the Community Room of Ed Bozarth Chevrolet, 2595 U.S. Highway 6 & 50.  \n \nThe public is invited to participate in making quilts to be awarded to local veterans and active duty personnel. Sewists should bring machines and cutting boards, etc., and non-sewists should bring ironing and cutting skills. Also, bring a soup and/or salad for the potluck. \n \nFor a copy of the pattern that will be used or for information, call Sue Schore at 241-7457 or Shar Weiser at 245-5422. \n \n■ \n \nNonprofit organizations are encouraged to apply for the opportunity to raise funds by selling items at A Robin\u2019s Nest, a retro, vintage and antique store, at 602 Main St. \n \nThe store is looking to work with a local non-profit partner to promote its fundraising area in the store, with a zero financial commitment to the nonprofit. The application deadline is Feb. 15 and applications can be picked up at A Robin\u2019s Nest, seven days a week.  \n \n■ \n \nSubmit Calendar and community news items by email to .(JavaScript must be enabled to view this email address) , by fax at 244-8578, or by mail to 734 S. Saldh\u2019s home touwn is Gothenburg, Sweden. \n  \n   \nColorado Mesa University basketball players Maja Beier, left, and Chiara Giesselbach, right, watch the action from their seats on the sidelines during a recent game. Both women are students from Germany. \n  \n QUICKREAD   \nCMU International Student-Athletes \n \nBaseball \n \nTanner Rempel, Canada \n \nMen\u2019s Basketball \n \nJames Sylvester, Canada \n \nLudvig Saldh, Sweden \n \nEimer Lopez, Puerto Rico \n \nFilip Nowicki, Poland \n \nMen\u2019s Cross Country/Track \n \nMakoto Watanabe, Japan \n \nFootball \n \nRiccardo Young, Panama (attended
