\nSaif Ezzat Sayed, Egypt \n \nJerry Veneris, Greece \n \nMen\u2019s Tennis \n \nMax Lindqvist, Sweden \n \nOliver Lindqvist, Sweden \n \nAlain De La Bastide, Venezuela \n \nWomen\u2019s Basketball \n \nMaja Beier, Germany \n \nChiara Giesselbach, Germany \n \nMa\u2019ata Epenisa, Tonga (attended school in Utah) \n \nWomen\u2019s Golf \n \nNaomi Yamada, Brazil \n \nSoftball \n \nTyneesha Houkamau, New Zealand \n \nWomen\u2019s Swimming \n \nHanna Sangfelt, Sweden \n \nWomen\u2019s Tennis \n \nRebecca Osterberg, Sweden \n \nGeorgia Hansen, Australia \n \nFrederikke Karst, Denmark \n \nVolleyball \n \nGabriela Dias, Brazil \n \n*\u2014No longer in program \n \nSource: CMU Sports Information Department \n  \n \nBy Patti Arnold \nSaturday, January 28, 2017 \n \nSaying goodbye at the airport is the worst. \n \nNot hearing your native language, speaking English every day, understanding the language in a lecture or when a large group is carrying on several conversations at once, that\u2019s a challenge. \n \nMissing family, knowing you can\u2019t go home most school breaks because you\u2019re thousands of miles and an expensive plane flight away can compound the normal case of homesickness most college freshmen experience. \n \nHowever, the experience of getting a college education and playing college athletics, just as it is for American student-athletes, has compelled more than 30 international student-athletes to overcome additional hurdles at Colorado Mesa. \n \n\u201cI\u2019ve been wanting to do this since I was like 10,\u201d said freshman men\u2019s basketball player Ludde Saldh, who is from Gothenburg, Sweden. \u201cI don\u2019t know, American basketball. I liked the NBA, college.\u201d \n \nSaldh attended a boarding school the past three years that was a few hours from his family. It helped him learn how to be on his own, but still, flying nearly 5,000 miles from home was hard. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s different from what I\u2019m used to,\u201d he said of college basketball. \u201cBut no regrets.\u201d \n \nOther than the food, perhaps. \n \n\u201cI think we have healthier food in Sweden,\u201d he said. \n \nAdjusting to an American diet is often an issue. \n \n\u201cI would love to have a home-cooked meal,\u201d said Chiara Giesselbach, a freshman on the CMU women\u2019s basketball team from Weiterstadt, Germany. \u201cMy mom used to make this potatoes with cheese and vegetables in the oven. I don\u2019t know how she makes it, but I miss it a lot.\u201d \n \nGiesselbach\u2019s older sister plays college basketball in San Diego, so she understood what she might encounter, but she and teammate Maja Beier, who is from Berlin, lean on each other. \n \n\u201cI feel like especially it was good to have each other around all the time,\u201d Giesselbach said. \n \n\u201cWhen I first came here, I\u2019ve never lived on a campus or (eaten) in a cafeteria,\u201d Beier said. \u201cI was always home with my parents. I\u2019m getting used to it.\u201d \n \nMost of the international student-athletes could take advantage of the long break at the holidays and go home. The international basketball players and their teammates had only one week off. Some, including Saldh and Beier, headed home, others, like Giesselbach, stayed in the U.S. \n \nAn advantage international student-athletes have over non-athletes from other countries studying at CMU is having a built-in group of friends on their team. \n \n\u201cThat first year is the toughest one,\u201d women\u2019s basketball coach Taylor Wagner said. \u201cAfter that they get to know people and have friends and integrate themselves on campus and in the community. \n \n\u201cThat first year they\u2019re still learning everything. It\u2019s hard for someone from the U.S., let alone leaving home and what you\u2019re used to.\u201d \n \nAfter the first semester, even though they still miss their families, the homesickness isn\u2019t as bad. Skype or FaceTime allow them to video chat with their families, which helps. Like every other student-athlete, they have to learn to manage their time with practice, games and classes. \n \nIn Germany, you either play basketball in a club program, or go to university, Beier said, not both at the same place. Being able to go to college and play basketball, the 6-foot-4 center said, is \u201ccool.\u201d \n \nOne of the international student-athletes in the basketball program, Filip Nowicki, has been through what the freshmen are feeling. He\u2019s been in the U.S. five years, first attending a prep school in Indiana, then going to Sacred Heart before deciding to transfer after two years. \n \n\u201cAfter coming to the States, the biggest challenge was the language,\u201d said Nowicki, from Wloclawek, Poland. \u201cI wasn\u2019t homesick because I left home when I was 13. I got used to being away from my family, I went to school five hours away. Being away from family wasn\u2019t a big deal for me, but the language and basketball was different.\u201d \n \nMost of the international student-athletes have had English classes since they were young, but Nowicki said he still struggled when he first came to America. Last week he met an American student on his floor who speaks some Polish, which was a nice surprise. \n \n\u201cI came with practically no English,\u201d he said. \u201cWe took English in high school, but I would say no English. I had to learn everything, how to talk, speak and read it.\u201d \n \nBeier, too, said she was worried at first about the language, and although sometimes her grammar isn\u2019t perfect in her papers, she\u2019s doing well in class. \n \n\u201cBefore I came here I thought it would be really hard with the language. In school I would have problems understanding or writing an essay,\u201d she said. \u201cMost of the teachers know I\u2019m an international student, I told them at the beginning. When they grade my essays they know I\u2019m an international student, so maybe that helps.\u201d \n \nInternational clubs have meetings and have activities such as going on hikes that Beier said helps them meet more people who are sharing the same experiences. \n \nSometimes it just takes a little time to become acclimated, like any college student. \n \n\u201cFrederikke (Karst) is doing better this year,\u201d tennis coach Dan MacDonald said of the sophomore from Denmark. \u201cShe and (Rebecca Osterburg, who is from Sweden) are friends, and sometimes that happens, you get one and they reach out to a friend and they come. (Karst) struggled a little bit with the language and the food we eat, little things like that. This year she seems more at ease.\u201d \n \nAnd there are bonuses. \n \n\u201cFrederikke loves how cheap our clothes are here,\u201d MacDonald said, laughing. \u201cShe\u2019s a shopper. Electronics, phones, everything here is so much cheaper. When her family comes, \u2018We\u2019re going to go over to the outlets in Dillon, everything\u2019s so cheap in your country!\u2019 \u201c \n \nDespite the obstacles they face in language, food and distance from home, there\u2019s also a comfort zone. \n \n\u201cThe sports part puts them at ease,\u201d MacDonald said. \u201cIt gives them a place they\u2019re used to.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Patti ArnoldSaturday, January"},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Mexico news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Sports: athletics news","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"College education, athletics a draw for Colorado Mesa international student-athletes","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Montrose","zipCode":"81401","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Montrose","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169683150","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1618"},"name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.gjsentinel.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194739581","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T04:48:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:44Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:02:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395785826","companies":[{"symbol":"031860","primary":true,"name":"NSN Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"KRX","titleCount":0,"isin":"KR7031860000"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"ATTENTION DEFICIT DISORDER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"CORRECTIONS WORKERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"INFANTS & TODDLERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"62"},{"name":"HEALTH CARE","domains":["IND"],"score":"69"},{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"LAWYERS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"74"},{"name":"PRISONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PRIVILEGED COMMUNICATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"69"},{"name":"COUNTY GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"COUNTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DISEASES & DISORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"SUITS & CLAIMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"INVESTIGATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"LITIGATION","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"EPILEPSY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"MENTAL ILLNESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"CONTRACTS & BIDS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"AUTOPSIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"DISABLED PERSONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"CORRECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"NURSES & NURSING","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; TENNESSEE, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"2088","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395785826&p=2kx&v=1&x=bQ4ITcYAYHdufX9uHplusA","id":"29395785826","content":"Tomas Beauford, who died April 16, 2014, while in the custody of the Mesa County jail. His family is suing the county for not properly caring for Beauford\u2019s epilepsy, which killed him while an inmate at the jail. Photo special to the Sentinel \n  \n   \nTomas Beauford and his mother, Tiffany Marsh. Photo special to the Sentinel. \n  \n   \nOne of the men\u2019s pods in the Mesa County Jail. \n  \n  \nBy Gabrielle Porter \nSaturday, January 28, 2017 \n \nA bracelet might have kept Tomas Anderson Beauford alive. \n \nDespite mental and behavioral illnesses that meant the 24-year-old functioned more like a 6-year-old, Beauford had mastered the use of the magnetic bracelet that combatted his epilepsy. \n \nBut on April 16, 2014, Beauford didn\u2019t have his bracelet. It had been confiscated by deputies at the Mesa County Jail. \n \nTaking his prescribed medications also might have kept Beauford alive. But in jail without family and caretakers who often cajoled him with promises of Starbursts and Sprite, Beauford hadn\u2019t taken his meds regularly in six weeks when he died. \n \nIn the hours before his death, Beauford\u2019s jailers saw him suffering what they would later realize were several violent seizures in his cell. Attorneys representing Beauford\u2019s mother wrote that if deputies had reacted correctly, he might never have died. \n \n\u201cAlone in his cell, Mr. Beauford ultimately had a series of seizures, fell off his bed and died with his head jammed underneath his desk,\u201d the attorneys wrote in a civil lawsuit naming Mesa County and the jail health care providers as defendants last spring. \u201cMr. Beauford\u2019s demise could have undoubtedly been prevented had defendants provided him with prompt and appropriate medical attention and treatment.\u201d \n \nAn autopsy determined Beauford\u2019s death was natural and caused by a seizure. Jail workers who dealt with him were cleared of wrongdoing after an internal investigation that\u2019s referenced in the civil suit, but which the county refused to release, saying it was subject to the \u201cgovernmental deliberative process privilege,\u201d according to Assistant County Attorney John Rhoads. Mesa County sheriff\u2019s spokeswoman Megan Terlecky wouldn\u2019t answer questions about whether any jail policies have changed in the years since Beauford\u2019s death, citing the ongoing lawsuit. \n \nCorrect Care Solutions, the Tennessee-based company that employed the jail\u2019s nursing staff, still holds the contract to provide health care in the jail. Mesa County commissioners are expected to vote on that contract soon. \n \nBeauford\u2019s mother, Tiffany Marsh of Aurora, said her son\u2019s death is evidence that jail guards and nursing staff aren\u2019t properly trained on handling mental illness. \n \n\u201cDo they not understand what disability means? Do they not understand?\u201d Marsh said. \u201cHe\u2019s just a mentally ill kid who needed help, not to die in jail.\u201d \n \nSTRUGGLED AS YOUTH \n \nBeauford\u2019s challenges in life started early. \n \nMarsh, then a teenage mother, said she was in denial about the issues her family and friends saw in her newborn son. \n \nBeauford was diagnosed early on with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder at school. But a doctor later said when teachers thought his attention was drifting, Tomas had probably been suffering from multiple small-scale seizures. \n \nBeauford\u2019s emotional and behavioral issues worsened during the next several years. Hallucinations began at age 8 after he was injured by a falling windowpane. \n \nHe was 12 when he had his first grand mal seizure. He was later diagnosed with epilepsy, a condition that never subsided. \n \nDespite Beauford\u2019s health problems, Marsh said he was fun-loving and kind. Generous to a fault, he held a job as a groundskeeper at the Aurora Mental Health Center, but often gave his pay away. When he was little, he liked to invent board games that he made his family play. \n \n\u201cThat boy wasn\u2019t just loved,\u201d Marsh said. \u201cHe was adored, and he was cherished.\u201d \n \nMarsh\u2019s goal was always to keep Beauford at home. But the single mother of four had an increasingly hard time keeping track of him. At 17, he went missing for 10 days. Marsh found him at an adult care facility; he was taken there when he couldn\u2019t remember who he was. \n \n\u201cThat\u2019s when his memory started going,\u201d Marsh said. \n \nBeauford eventually was placed in a psychiatric hospital at Fort Logan, where he was diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder. Later he was sent to another facility in Pueblo, where doctors realized how badly he had deteriorated since his epilepsy diagnosis. \n \n\u201cThey finally did the IQ test and realized he had lost 20 points on the IQ test,\u201d Marsh said. \u201cIt\u2019s like watching a person with Alzheimer\u2019s, except he was younger.\u201d \n \nBeauford\u2019s condition briefly improved after doctors changed his medications, but he eventually started to decline again and his seizures became more violent. \n \nWhen he was about 19, Marsh, initially resistant to brain surgery, eventually agreed that he should receive an implant to help assuage his seizures. The implant \u2014 a \u201cvagal nerve stimulator\u201d \u2014 cycled on and off throughout the day. He was fitted with a magnetic bracelet and taught to hold the magnet near his body when he felt a seizure coming. The device wouldn\u2019t necessarily stop seizures, but it would prevent them from snowballing into dangerous back-to-back episodes, Marsh said. \n \nBeauford, a young adult whose mental state was still in decline, spent a year living at Wheat Ridge Regional Center west of Denver in 2012. It was convenient for Marsh, but eventually Beauford started to wander again. \n \nOnce, caretakers called to tell Marsh her son had wandered away and was found having a seizure on the railroad tracks. Staffers didn\u2019t think it was safe for him to stay in Wheat Ridge and suggested he transfer to the Grand Junction Regional Center, which was able to lock down residents for security. \n \nMarsh, who looked forward to a date with her son every Thursday \u2014 shopping, movies and other outings with just the two of them \u2014 reluctantly agreed. \n \n\u201cI didn\u2019t want him to go to Grand Junction because it\u2019s so far from me,\u201d she said. \u201cBut I didn\u2019t want him to die either.\u201d \n \nARRESTED FOR VIOLENT BEHAVIOR \n \nBeauford\u2019s time on the Western Slope, far from his family, didn\u2019t go smoothly. He was arrested Nov. 30 after staff at the Grand Junction Regional Center reported that he was breaking facility windows by throwing chairs against them, an affidavit said. Beauford\u2019s magnetic bracelet was confiscated when he was booked at the Mesa County Jail, despite a document from the Regional Center describing the implant, the civil suit said. \n \nBeauford suffered more than one seizure during a weekend in the jail holding cell. The lawsuit suggested jail staff unsuccessfully tried to get Beauford to take his medication but never moved him from the cell. \n \nBeauford was released on bond Dec. 2 and Regional Center staff later told prosecutors not to press charges. \n \nBeauford was arrested again March 1. During this altercation, Beauford threw punches, kicks and a steel chair at other people, an affidavit for his arrest said. The report said Beauford had grabbed the buttocks of people trying to restrain him. \n \n\u201c(One victim) received no physical injuries but wanted to report the unwanted sexual contact by Tomas, who has a history of sexual assaults,\u201d the report said. Beauford was arrested on assault charges as well as a misdemeanor count of unlawful sexual contact. \n \nThis time Beauford wasn\u2019t released after a weekend. He was ordered held on a $10,000 cash or surety bond, and stayed in jail. \n \nMENTAL STATE DETERIORATED \n \nBeauford\u2019s condition was poor from the day he was arrested. \n \nJail records cited in the civil suit described him having \u201cmultiple seizures during the booking process.\u201d \n \nDespite the jail\u2019s past experience with Beauford and a document from the Grand Junction Regional Center describing in detail his medical needs, a deputy wrote on an intake form that Beauford had no special medical or mental health needs. \n \nHis magnetic bracelet was confiscated again and Beauford again stopped taking his meds. \n \nGrand Junction defense attorney JR Davis, who took over Beauford\u2019s case two weeks after his arrest, said the 24-year-old was incoherent the first time they met in court March 17. \n \nDavis also visited Beauford in jail March 27 for 45 minutes. \n \n\u201cI tried to ask him questions about his case,\u201d Davis said. \u201cI tried to ask him questions about himself and he just maintained his downward gaze. He had spit coming out of his mouth.\u201d \n \nDavis, who filed a motion for a court-ordered mental competency evaluation the next day, said he doesn\u2019t believe anyone could have mistaken Beauford for a fully functioning adult. \n \nMarsh didn\u2019t visit her son at the jail until April 4. She noticed then that he wasn\u2019t wearing his magnetic bracelet. Beauford told her it had been taken. \n \nA staffer from the Regional Center had told Marsh earlier that two magnetic bracelets had been brought to the jail \u2014 one for Beauford and one usually worn by his caretaker. \n \nMarsh said a jail nurse she spoke to by phone after the visit assured her Beauford would get it back. \n \nAccording to the civil filing, though, he never did. \n \nDEATH PRECEDED BY MULTIPLE SEIZURES \n \nBeauford\u2019s medical condition \u201crapidly deteriorated\u201d in the hours before his death April 16, 2014, the suit said. The filing described multiple instances when jail staff and nurses noted seeing Beauford having a seizure and didn\u2019t provide medication or transport him. One deputy is described seeing Beauford having a seizure on his bed and neither opening his cell door nor contacting him through the intercom. \n \n\u201cRather than providing him with the medical attention and treatment he so desperately needed, Mr. Beauford was actively ignored,\u201d the complaint said. \n \nA deputy spotted Beauford lying on the ground in his cell with his head inside the bottom shelf of his desk at about 11:55 p.m. April 15. \n \n\u201c(The deputy) elected not to enter Mr. Beauford\u2019s cell to check on him, knock on Mr. Beauford\u2019s door, or to utilize the intercom to check on him, even though he knew that Mr. Beauford had suffered multiple seizures earlier in the night,\u201d the filing said. \n \nTwenty minutes later, the same deputy returned to Beauford\u2019s cell to check on him. When Beauford didn\u2019t move or respond to knocking or calls through the intercom, the guard asked for a nurse using a code that the filing describes as meaning \u201cthe situation to which they are being called is not urgent,\u201d the civil suit said. \n \nThe nurse immediately recognized that Beauford wasn\u2019t breathing and a deputy began CPR. The nurse attempted to use an automated external defibrillator on him, but Beauford was already dead. \n \nA case report filed by the Mesa County Sheriff\u2019s Office \u2014 which includes accounts from the nurse that night, Renee Workman, and two night shift deputies on duty when Beauford died, Peter Dalrymple and Richard Perkinson \u2014 confirms much of the detail from the civil suit. \n \nIt\u2019s notable that the magnetic bracelet, key to the plaintiff\u2019s lawsuit, isn\u2019t mentioned once in the Sheriff\u2019s Office case report. \n \nDeputy Perkinson\u2019s account in the report is particularly significant. He recounts how at one point, while checking Beauford in his cell, he dismisses shaking and \u201cgrunting\u201d under a blanket by Beauford as \u201cmasturbation.\u201d \n \nAn investigator later in the report reminds, \u201cDeputy Perkinson confirmed he was aware of Mr. Beauford\u2019s seizures,\u201d as he was present when Beauford was first booked, and experiencing seizures during the process. \n \nSEEKING REFORMS \n \nMarsh said she has been trying to put her life back together since her son\u2019s death. She planned to speak Jan. 21 about her son at the Women\u2019s March on Washington. \n \nIn April 2016, Marsh filed a lawsuit naming as defendants Mesa County, former Mesa County Sheriff Stan Hilkey, Correct Care Solutions and a number of deputies and nurses who had contact with Beauford. The suit alleges that county and medical staff violated his 14th Amendment rights by failing to provide medical care and treatments and by depriving Beauford of his life without due process. It also claims they violated the federal Americans with Disabilities Act by discriminating against Beauford based on his disabilities. \n \nThe suit, which is seeking unspecified damages, is ongoing and parties are next due in federal court in Grand Junction Feb. 9. \n \nMarsh said she doesn\u2019t understand why, after being told about the importance of his magnetic bracelet, jail staff didn\u2019t return it to Beauford. \n \n\u201cThat was a matter of life and death, and it proved to be so,\u201d she said. \n \nMarsh said Mesa County needs to reform the way it treats mentally ill people who are crossways with the law. She said the jail nurses shouldn\u2019t have taken \u201cno\u201d for an answer with giving her son medication. \n \nShe said arrestees with severe disabilities should be brought before a judge more quickly for a mental status hearing. \n \n\u201cYou can\u2019t keep people like that in jail,\u201d she said. \u201cA lot of these people are too fragile to be incarcerated.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Gabrielle PorterSaturday, January"},"topics":[],"title":"Death in custody","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Montrose","zipCode":"81401","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Montrose","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169683150","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1618"},"name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard","Local","Geographic"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.gjsentinel.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194739765","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:02:00Z","adultLanguage":"true","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:44Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T04:46:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395785847","companies":[{"symbol":"7959","primary":true,"name":"Oliver Corp","contentCount":1,"exchange":"NGO","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3200600009"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"COLLEGIATE SPORTS ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY SPORTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ATHLETES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SOCCER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"FOREIGN STUDENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"COACHES & TRAINERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"SCHOOL SPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"HIGH SCHOOLS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BASKETBALL","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"EMPLOYMENT SERVICES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"SCHOOL ATHLETIC STAFF","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"COMMUNITY COLLEGES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SOCCER TOURNAMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"JAPAN","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"JAPAN; KYUSHU, JAPAN","domains":["GEO"],"score":"57"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"91"},{"name":"DENVER, CO, USA; UNITED STATES; COLORADO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; COLORADO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"1590","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395785847&p=2kx&v=1&x=imoy5pZRXkGYg2Z8LKFKVQ","id":"29395785847","content":"Foreign student-athletes making their mark on\u2028Mesa sports teams     \nColorado Mesa\u2019s Filip Nowicki cheers on his teammates from the bench during a recent men\u2019s basketball game as he recouperates from an injury. Nowicki, a junior, is from Poland. \n  \n   \nMoshe Perez, pointing after a goal \n  \n   \nEimer Lopez \n  \n   \nRoberto Diaz \n  \n  \nBy Patti Arnold \nSaturday, January 28, 2017 \n \nWhen the Colorado Mesa men\u2019s soccer team played in the 2014 NCAA Division II final four, the Mavericks had four international players on their 35-man roster. \n \nOne of those, Stan Schrock, is the son of U.S. military parents, who was born in Italy and grew up in Okinawa, Japan, where he honed his soccer skills. \n \nThe University of Charleston had 15 Americans on a 50-man roster. \n \n\u201cOne American saw the field for Charleston,\u201d coach Todd Padgett said. \n \nThe official boxscore showed all 15 Charleston players listed as participating in its 2-0 victory were internationals as opposed to two for CMU, Schrock and Roy Abergil. \n \nThat experience opened Padgett\u2019s eyes to the reality that, even in Division II athletics, international student-athletes are a major factor in success at the national level. \n \n\u201cI think one thing we were able to come back home and say was, well, I think we can sprinkle in a little bit of international flavor to what we\u2019re doing. I think we\u2019ve done that the past few years in the recruiting classes we\u2019ve brought in,\u201d Padgett said. \n \nThis past fall, the Mavericks had nine international players on the roster, two of whom were redshirts, another who attended high school in Denver. \n \nPadgett estimated that of the roughly 25 emails he and Schrock, now his assistant coach, get every day, 80 percent are from international student-athletes. \n \nIn many cases, international student-athletes are a bit older and more experienced than Americans straight out of high school or junior college. \n \n\u201cWe love them all the same, but (international athletes) come over here with greater experience and playing at a greater level,\u201d Padgett said. \u201cBy and large that generally equates to being a little more gifted, a little more talented, or at least a little more experienced. \n \n\u201cOne thing that made Roy so successful, he\u2019s 25 years old, he was experienced, he had simply played more soccer at a higher level than any other player in the program. We all saw that.\u201d \n \nAbergil graduated in December and is currently trying out for professional soccer teams in the U.S. \n \nEvery coach at CMU is inundated daily by emails from athletes, parents and recruiting services. More and more international students are reaching out, and more and more coaches are saying yes. \n \n\u201cIf they can play, I don\u2019t really care where they\u2019re from. If they\u2019re from Timbuktu, if they\u2019re a good student-athlete and a guy who can help us, he\u2019s a guy I want to recruit,\u201d said Michael Dominguez, the assistant men\u2019s basketball coach and recruiting coordinator. \n \nThe logistics of recruiting international student-athletes can get tricky. Limited recruiting budgets don\u2019t include coaches hopping on international flights, or paying for official on-campus visits from abroad. \n \nEmails are exchanged, followed by text messages and phone calls, and Skype and FaceTime come in handy for face-to-face conversations. CMU has a virtual tour of campus on its website so recruits can get a look at where they might be living the next 4-5 years, and once an offer is made, Annie Gingerich, the associate director of admissions who specializes in international programs and services, makes sure everything is in order. \n \nPassports and visas are a must, and there are a myriad of regulations regarding international student-athletes\u2019 age and past teams. Many countries don\u2019t have school sports like the United States, and club and national teams could violate the NCAA\u2019s amateurism guidelines. \n \nAbergil was docked one year of eligibility because he played several games for a team in Israel after serving his required two years in the military before coming to CMU. \n \nFilip Nowicki played for a professional club basketball team in Poland before entering the U.S. to attend prep school, but because he wasn\u2019t paid other than the allowed expenses and equipment, he retained his amateur status. \n \nAfter prep school, which helped him learn English, Nowicki said he had more than a dozen Division I scholarship offers. He went to Sacred Heart in Connecticut, but wasn\u2019t happy with a lack of playing time and decided to transfer after two years. \n \n\u201cCoach Dominguez found me and messaged me on Twitter,\u201d he said. \n \nOnce he was released from Sacred Heart, his name was placed on a website of players seeking to transfer. With the Mavericks needing big men, Dominguez noticed the\u20286-foot-10, 250-pound center, and started the process. \n \n\u201cThe hard part is you don\u2019t get to see them in person,\u201d Dominguez said of many international recruits. \u201cEvery other foreign kid we\u2019ve seen live, Fil we didn\u2019t get to see live, but he had a lot of film out there and Division I talent, you\u2019re able to understand it a little bit more.\u201d \n \nLudde Saldh, a freshman on the men\u2019s basketball team, wasn\u2019t seen in person \u2014 he\u2019s from Gothenburg, Sweden. Dominguez saw him on video and talked to his coaches, and was convinced the 6-8 forward could compete in Division II basketball. \n \nJames Sylvester (Canada) and Eimer Lopez (Puerto Rico) transferred to CMU. Dominguez saw Lopez at a junior college jamboree, and Sylvester had played for former CMU guard Jase Herl. \n \nIn total, Colorado Mesa has more than 30 international student-athletes on 14 different teams this school year. The majority made first contact, and, several coaches said, paved the way for others to look to the Mavericks. \n \nTennis coach Dan MacDonald has brothers Max and Oliver Lindqvist from Sweden, and women\u2019s basketball coach Taylor Wagner signed two players from Germany this season, guard Chiara Giesselbach and center Maja Beier, who were teammates on a tournament team that played in San Diego last summer. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s a different avenue, where you might be recruiting against three or four other schools rather than if they\u2019re in the U.S., 20 or 30 other schools. Your odds increase a little bit,\u201d Wagner said. \u201cThere are things you have to account for, are they going to get homesick? You don\u2019t get to see them a lot; a lot of times it\u2019s just video. I was lucky enough to see these two girls.\u201d \n \nBeier, Wagner said, probably would have had Division I schools beating down her door if she was from the U.S., because she\u2019s 6-4. \n \nLike soccer, tennis is a sport that has rosters packed with international players, even in the RMAC. And like Padgett, MacDonald said if you want to keep up with the competition, it\u2019s vital to have a diverse roster. \n \n\u201cThey\u2019re all great kids and they just want to play tennis,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re such an international sport, like soccer, obviously. Tennis is just so popular in Europe, South American countries and Australia. To be competitive, we have to have a couple. \n \n\u201cWould I like to have all American kids? Part of me says probably yes, but it\u2019s a great learning experience for the international kids and the American kids. They experience different cultures.\u201d \n \nObviously tennis, soccer, golf, basketball and track and field are wildly popular throughout the world, but American football? \n \nCMU coach Russ Martin said it\u2019s growing \u2014 he has two players from Panama, Riccardo Young and Jan Michael Mirrop, both of whom redshirted this season. They attended Parker Lutheran High School in Denver, a school the Mavericks typically recruit. \n \nYoung and Mirrop could pave the way for a coaching clinic, Martin said. \n \n\u201cWe\u2019re trying to do a deal with them in Panama. One\u2019s dad heads all the youth leagues in Panama City, so he\u2019s trying to get a situation where our coaches can go down hopefully this summer and do a camp for their kids and a clinic for coaches, and in return, hopefully some of their coaches can come up here to mirror and follow us through spring football for four or five days and hopefully improve the level of teaching and coaching,\u201d Martin said. \u201cIf we can get it done I think it\u2019ll be an awesome deal.\u201d \n \nYoung, a defensive lineman, and Mirrop, a linebacker, are raw, but eager to learn. \n \n\u201cBoth are very raw, but they are good young men, great work ethic, and they are strong, so I think they have a chance to be good players,\u201d Martin said. \n \nWith less-restrictive age limits than Division I, more international athletes are looking to Division II schools, and more and more Division II schools are loading up rosters with older, international-experienced athletes. \n \nPadgett knows that international experience has helped the Mavericks compete at the national level \u2014 Abergil scored 23 of CMU\u2019s 42 goals this season \u2014 but he also believes that the university\u2019s first priority is American students. He\u2019ll continue to recruit internationally, but within reason. Abergil, Moshe Perez, Luis Schraidt and Roberto Diaz, he said, \u201cdid a fantastic job elevating our program.\u201d \n \n\u201cI think it\u2019s a bit unfortunate that Division II, especially on the soccer side of things because of how global our sport is, is really gravitating toward (international rosters). I think it\u2019s something we will always try to fight against, because we don\u2019t want Colorado Mesa\u2019s men\u2019s soccer program to be all international players,\u201d Padgett said. \n \n\u201cA lot of people probably wonder what we would look like without a Roy, without a Moshe. I don\u2019t have the answer to that question. I think they make us better. I still think we would be successful here at Mesa without those two, but as a staff, after we got back from the final four, we said, \u2018OK, we need a couple more special players.\u2019 \u2019\u2019","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Patti ArnoldSaturday, January"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"International flavor","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Montrose","zipCode":"81401","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Montrose","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169683150","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1618"},"name":"Grand Junction Daily Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.gjsentinel.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194740263","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T04:46:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:44Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"}],"wordCount":"824","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395785871&p=2kx&v=1&x=9lfQdQ6Y4X8Ms0qE8BjYbg","id":"29395785871","content":"The new premier has pledged to govern for all of NSW but Labor says the new ministry rewards factional operatives. \n\nGladys Berejiklian has unveiled a cabinet to fight the 2019 election in the face of a revitalised Labor opposition and a rising minor party vote in the regions, including a resurgent One Nation.\n\nMs Berejiklian and Deputy Premier and Nationals leader John Barilaro announced the new line-up at Queanbeyan, in the regional seat of Monaro held by Mr Barilaro on a margin of just 2.5 per cent.\n\nThe unusual decision follows the Nationals' disastrous loss in last year's Orange byelection to the Shooters, Fishers and Farmers party, which has pledged to target other regional seats.\n\nIn a reshuffle designed to \"reset\" the government for 2019, four ministers have been dumped from cabinet: Nationals Adrian Piccoli who had education; Duncan Gay who held roads; and Leslie Williams who had early childhood education and Aboriginal affairs. Also out of cabinet is Liberal MLC John Ajaka, who was minister for ageing, disability services and multiculturalism. However, Mr Ajaka is set to become President of the Legislative Council.\n\nIn strategic appointments with an eye on the crucial electoral battleground of western Sydney, two new MPs from the area, Mulgoa's Tanya Davies and Castle Hill MP Ray Williams, have been elevated to cabinet.\n\nMs Berejiklian has also created the new portfolio of minister for WestConnex, to be held by Penrith MP Stuart Ayres, who is also minister for western Sydney.\n\nThe move is being seen as an attempt to reset the discussion about the $16.8 billion road project from complaints about the disruption of inner-Sydney communities to the benefits it will bring commuting western Sydney families.\n\nAnother surprise announcement is the new position of minister for counter terrorism which Ms Berejiklian said was necessary \"unfortunately due to the circumstances our world is in\".\n\nLiberal MP David Elliott \u2013 a leader of the centre-right faction that supported Ms Berejiklian's election as Liberal leader and premier after the retirement from politics of former premier Mike Baird \u2013 adds the role to his existing portfolio area of corrections.\n\nIt will involve liaising with state, Commonwealth and international counter terrorism bodies.\n\nUnveiling the new cabinet, Ms Berejiklian repeated the pledge that her government would listen, consult and act and \"wants to make sure every single community across NSW gets its fair share\".\n\nMr Piccoli will be replaced in education by Rob Stokes, whose planning portfolio will be taken over by former industry and energy minister Anthony Roberts.\n\nMr Roberts, a leader of the right faction whose numbers also supported Ms Berejiklian's election, also becomes special minister of state.\n\nNationals MP for Oxley Melinda Pavey enters cabinet to take over the roads portfolio from Mr Gay, while her party colleague Sarah Mitchell has been promoted to the ministry to take on early childhood education and Aboriginal affairs.\n\nAmong the biggest winners are two of Ms Berejiklian's strongest supporters in her own left faction: former Legislative Council president Don Harwin and Hornsby MP and former parliamentary secretary Matt Kean.\n\nMr Harwin comes into cabinet as energy and resources minister and minister for the arts.\n\nHe has also been appointed leader of the government in the Legislative Council. Mr Kean enters cabinet as minister for innovation and better regulation.\n\nMr Harwin and Mr Kean were key to engineering the numbers to have Ms Berejiklian elected leader.\n\nIn other Nationals promotions Adam Marshall will head tourism and major events, which has been taken from Mr Ayres.\n\nDeputy Nationals leader and primary industries and water minister Niall Blair picks up the trade portfolio from Mr Ayres and the key jobs portfolio of industry from Mr Roberts.\n\nFormer deputy premier and Nationals leader Troy Grant has held onto police and adds emergency services to his responsibilities.\n\nFormer local government minister Paul Toole becomes minister for lands and forestry as well as racing.\n\nPru Goward moves from mental health and women to her former portfolio of family and community services. She remains minister for the prevention of domestic violence.\n\nVeteran Liberal MP Brad Hazzard will move from family and community services to health following Jillian Skinner's decision to quit politics after being told she could not remain in the portfolio.\n\nCronulla MP Mark Speakman, a senior barrister, moves from environment to attorney-general, replacing Vaucluse MP Gabrielle Upton who takes over environment.\n\nMs Upton has also been handed the challenging local government portfolio amid unrest over forced mergers including from Woollahra Council in her electorate. Victor Dominello moves from innovation and better regulation to finance.\n\nAndrew Constance remains Transport and Infrastructure Minister and Deputy Liberal leader Dominic Perrottet will move from finance to become treasurer as expected.\n\nOpposition leader Luke Foley said the reshuffle \"is not about serving the interests of the people of NSW\".\n\n\"It's about serving the interests of the backroom operators and lurk merchants of the Liberal Party to whom Ms Berejiklian is beholden to.\" The story first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Sean Nicholls"},"topics":[{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Cabinet shakeup as Gladys Berejiklian resets for 2019","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","zipCode":"2650","state":"New South Wales","countryCode":"AU","zipArea":"Wagga Wagga","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Southern Weekly","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169750061","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Southern Weekly","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.southernweekly.com.au","publisher":"Fairfax Media"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194742152","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:59:48Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:44Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://nnimgt-a.akamaihd.net/transform/v1/crop/frm/silverstone-feed-data/fb29f073-02ed-46ee-9fcb-a76504dad85e.jpg/r2_0_728_410_w1200_h678_fmax.jpg"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:45Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395589060","companies":[{"symbol":"WWTH","primary":true,"name":"With Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"US9773991040"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"ELECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"POLITICAL CANDIDATES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"NIGERIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"96"},{"name":"NIGER","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"MUHAMMADU BUHARI","domains":["PEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"1691","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395785922&p=2kx&v=1&x=kGebs8Xon5tsko6juJOSDw","id":"29395785922","content":"Chief (Mrs) Calista Nkiru Adimachukwu (Mmilioma), National Women Leader, Ohanaeze Ndigbo Worldwide, speaks on Igbo presidency and the state of the nation. \n \nBy Olalekan Bilesanmi \n \nF ormer President Olusegun Obasanjo has thrown his weight behind Igbo presidency. What do you have to say about that? \n  \nIgbo President is possible in 2019 but not through APC or PDP. APC will like President Buhari to continue for second term and PDP has zoned the presidency to the North. The only chance for the Igbo is to form a formidable political party together with other notable Nigerians which will present an Igbo man as their presidential candidate. \n \nWith hard work and good reason presented to other Nigerians, it will work. Nigerians are changing everyday by day with their thinking cap, and sure that ordinary Nigerians will not continue to support marginalisation. Obasanjo\u2019s support for the Igbos is highly welcomed but for now you can see that he is no more in power to make it happen, it is left for the Igbos to work hard towards that direction. Lastly, the better option for all Nigerians is for Buhari to implement the 2014 National Conference recommendations for equitable Nigeria. \n Some Igbo called for support for Gen Muhammadu Buhari (rtd) during his campaign and they said it was for the good of the Igbos. Do you think that the government of Buhari will benefit the Igbos?  \nI am aware that some individuals in the South East called for Igbo support for Buhari prior to the 2015 elections. There was even a blame game against the Igbos for putting their eggs in one basket. It is too early to judge Buhari or know his mindset on Igbos, however time will tell. President Jonathan lost the election and Igbos feel bad but we lost nothing because we gained the brotherhood of the South South. When Emeka Odumegwu Ojukwu was alive, he visited the Alafin of Oyo and the Ooni of Ife to extend hand shake across the Niger. \n \nHis action was misunderstood, but he explained that if there was an understanding between the South East and South West, it was the beginning of political wisdom. He also explained that the personalities he went to visit in the West were the greater authorities he had to meet to forge a political understanding. However after the Igbos had tried in the First Republic and other periods in the political history of Nigeria, they had a change of mind. \n \nThe Igbos reasoned they had supported the North and the West in the past, and that partnership failed. The Igbos    even reasoned that since    Ojukwu\u2019s idea of a handshake across the Niger did not work, a new political partnership was necessary. More recently, the South South, South East and South West Assembly was formed aimed at securing    support from these zones for    Jonathan and also in case an Igbo man decides to contest the presidential election in future. \n \nMeetings were held in Enugu, Asaba and some other places. Ekwueme, Chief ABC Nwosu, Chief    Chukwuemeka Ezeife and a host of others attended some of the meetings. Also Ohanaeze Ndigbo\u2019s call for support for Goodluck Jonathan was done after wide consultations from traditional rulers and important personalities. However we will still enter into political understanding with the Middle Belt and the North after wide discussions. \n Calista Nkiru Adimachukwu \nWe will let everyone know the reasons while the South East will vie for president and expect wide support from other zones. Nevertheless, after we try all these things and they fail, the    solution lies in the implementation of the report of the 2014 National Confab. If there is any Igbo personality that is begging for recognition and position from the government of Buhari, that person is insulting the Igbos. What we expect from those people is for them to tell Gen. Mohammadu Buhari point blank to implement the reports of the National Constitutional Conference of 2014. \n \nYou have emphasized the report of the National Conference. Do you think it remains the solution to the agitations of the Igbos? \n \nBefore the National Conference, slots were given to political parties. However APC did not send representatives and they made no contributions. All the geo-political zones sent delegates and    appreciated that conference as well as saw its relevance. They finally came out with a masterpiece and powerful document on how Nigeria can live together peacefully. Till now, APC has said nothing about that constitutional conference and it remains suspicious. So if any person starts asking questions about the reasons the Igbos supported President Goodluck Jonathan, that person is not a student of history. Ndigbo supported Jonathan mainly because of that conference. Therefore any Igbo personality that meets Buhari should urge him to implement the report of the National Conference for equitable Nigeria. When the dust settles down, Ohanaeze Ndigbo will go and meet Buhari with a powerful delegation to discuss a way forward and also about the report of the National Conference. \n \nDo Igbos have any regret? \n \nYes, the Igbos have three regrets. The first is the non-implementation of the Aburi Accord. The second is that the Igbos have not gotten any meaningful gain after their foremost contributions to Nigeria\u2019s independence. The third regret is that the East and West delayed Nigeria\u2019s independence for the North to meet up with the pace of independence. It was because of this that Whitehall imposed federalism on Nigeria. Sadly, our sacrifice is not appreciated. \n \nWhat are Ohanaeze Ndigbo doing on this ongoing IPOB crisis. (Struggle for Biafra)? \n \nFirst of all, I would like to draw you back to my interview in Vanguard newspaper on may 24, 2015 with the headline \u201cIgbos case on National Conference report for Buhari\u201d \u2014 Ohanaeze National Women Leader. Our regrets as a region in Nigeria\u201d. \n \nI granted that interview before President Buhari was sworn in on may 29, 2015. My reason for granting that interview was for him to know the position of Ndigbo for equitable Union government. \n \nWhen he assumed office and started making appointments. He was supposed to treat all Nigerians fairly according to the oath of office he took, so when he started making lopsided appointments, sidetracking one of the major bloc that contributed more than any region in Nigeria to give Nigeria the fastest independence. That was what provoked the youths to agitate for Biafra, because they feel that they don\u2019t have any future in one Nigeria. I am again pleading to Mr President as a mother to immediately start the process of implementing the 2014 national conference report for equitable Nigeria, where everyone would have a sense of belonging without fear or favour. I also use this opportunity to plead with Mr President to grant Nnamdi Kanu unconditional release because he has done nothing to warrant his continuous incarceration. I am urging Vanguard newspaper to republish my may 24,2015 interview for Nigerian\u2019s perusal because it is still in tune with current reality. \n \nWhat do you think/comment on this Patience Jonathan\u2019s issue with EFCC? \n \nI am not against President Buhari\u2019s war against corruption through EFCC but first of all the war should be fought with sincerity in all ramifications. \n \nIf left to me to advise, the president should start the anti-corruption crusade from members of his party to prove to the world that he is sincere in what he is doing, not only fighting the opposition. In my own humble opinion it is a clear cut agenda to bulldoze the opposition. \n \nAs for Jonathan\u2019s wife, I am not against the EFCC probing her but they should beam their search lights to former first ladies from Northern Nigeria extraction to prove to the world that they are not just out to fight Jonathan\u2019s family who made sure that there was a peaceful transition to the present administration which was acclaimed world wide. \n \nWhat is your view on current recession under the watch of the APC leading government? \n \nWhen APC as a political party were campaigning to be voted into power, they knew very    well that Nigeria economy had a problem, so they came up with the change agenda, that if voted into power they would restore the economy, that was the reason Nigerians voted for them. \n \nWhen they assumed office they started blame game and that blame game has continued till today, pretending they didn\u2019t know there was a problem before they took office, instead of doing the needful of restoring the economy. Based on    that, foreign investors started pulling out their money back to their country and that is why we are in this present recession. But all hope is not lost because Nigeria have potentials to be great again even more than before within 10 years. \n \nI could remember that after the Nagasaki and Hiroshima    atomic bombing of second world War in Japan, they cut themselves out of the world for 20 years and looked inwardly on how to bounce back. Look at their economic position in the world affairs now. Nigeria\u2019s case is a matter of 10 years, that is why I am pleading to Mr President to do the needful so that we can have the \n \nconducive environment to move the Nigeria economy forward. \n \nYour take on Yoruba supporting secret trial for Nnamdi Kanu? \n \nThe Yoruba\u2019s are intelligent people. I do not think that it is the collective decision of the Yoruba\u2019s to back the secret trial of Nnamdi Kanu. So it is only the personal opinion of the individual saying it. \n \nWhat do you have to say concerning the capture of Sambisa forest by the Nigeria military? \n \nOur president Muhammadu Buhari should be congratulated for that. But the Federal Government has to do more to ensure that the Chibok girls are rescued and Shekau captured. \n \nOn Ibori\u2019s release from UK prison? \n \nWhat do you want me to say on that. The london court has released him, so he should enjoy his freedom. \n \n2017 FG budget as it concerns  Ndigbo? \n \nWe have our representatives in the Senate and House of Representatives. It is their duty to scrutinize the budget and highlight if it is favourable to us or not. If it is not favourable to Igbos, it is also their duty to find a remedy. That is one of the reasons we voted them there.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Nigeria news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Africa news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Igbo presidency: Don\u2019t rely on Obasanjo\u2019s support- Adima ...","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Africa","subregion":"Western Africa","countryCode":"NG","country":"Nigeria"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"LiveBip.com","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"608962712","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"LiveBip.com","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Politics","Society","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://feeds.feedburner.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://www.alternativeadvert.com/click.php?z=30&pl=10499&ad_type=62&img=1473714806"],"sequenceId":"695194743432","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:45Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Patrolman Nicholas Sangster struggled with a 30-year-old Charlestown man on the side of Main Street in August , he found himself in a precarious position. \n \nThe man, Hombre Harris, described by me.\u201d \n \nGrappling with an aggressive man who the police said was under the influence of drugs, Sangster was able to avoid serious injury thanks to the help from two witnesses \u2014 Kevin Swanson, of Ashaway, and Westerly resident Edward French, according to Hopkinton Police Chief David Palmer \n \n\u201cWhat these guys did, our officers will forever be grateful for,\u201d Palmer said. Palmer said the men pulled Harris off Sangster and helped contain him, holding the man down for two minutes as the patrolman and other officers handcuffed him. \n \nHarris has since pleaded not guilty to charges of felony assault with a motor vehicle, assault on an officer, driving under the influence and disorderly conduct. The case is being processed in Washington County Superior Court. \n \nSwanson and French were recognized with a letter of appreciation from the Hopkinton Police Department this month. The letters were presented during a ceremony before the Town Council, with Swanson present. \n \nThe two men could not be reached for comment. \n \nPalmer said the letters of appreciation were the least the department could do. The coverage provides internet accessibility at key locations, from shops and restaurants to Craig Field, Westerly High School and the Westerly Yacht Club. \n \nState Sen. Brian Patrick Kennedy, D-Westerly, joined Jay Allbaugh, Cox senior vice president and regional manager, to announce the new network on Saturday at the Washington Trust Community Skating Center. \n \nWesterly is the third Wi-Fi location Cox has deployed in Rhode Island. Wi-Fi launched in Providence\u2019s Kennedy Plaza in 2015, followed by Upper and Lower Thames Streets in Newport. The hotspots are part of more than 500,000 that are accessible by customers nationwide. \n   \nFrom this section: \nWesterly home sales up 11% in 2016 \n  \nWith the explosive growth in usage of smartphones, tablets and other mobile connected devices, Cox said that Wi-Fi adds significant value and reliable internet access. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:48Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395786302","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"BIRDS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ECOSYSTEMS & HABITATS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"WETLANDS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"FRESHWATER ECOSYSTEMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CHRISTMAS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"GARDENING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"HOMEOWNERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"LOGGING INDUSTRY","domains":["IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"LANDSCAPE ARCHITECTURE SERVICES","domains":["IND"],"score":"75"},{"name":"BIRDING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ANIMALS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"LAND USE & DEVELOPMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"WILDLIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SALTWATER ECOSYSTEMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"BOOK PUBLISHING","domains":["IND"],"score":"50"}],"wordCount":"753","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395786302&p=2kx&v=1&x=v4HKpe80kGagXlTDWVAeEA","id":"29395786302","content":"People are still talking about the removal of some thickets in Watch Hill. Birders participating in the Christmas Bird Count reported that two thickets that had provided habitat for certain species had been removed, and not for the purpose of construction, but for aesthetic reasons. \n \nHere\u2019s an email I received from birder Glenn Williams after I first wrote about this issue: \n \n\u201cI just read your column after being told that I was quoted in it,\u201d Williams writes. \u201cI am so glad that someone is taking the issue to the public. I just sent a description to someone who asked about it and thought that I should send you the same information. \n   \nFrom this section: \nEditorial: At this DOT, rubber actually hits the road \n  \n\u201cI have been doing the Napatree CBC since its inception and am a co-compiler. The area that I cover for the count is Watch Hill. Every year, there are less thickets. Homeowners are definitely switching from a natural and wild look to a manicured style of landscaping. The latter is of little value to birds and other animals. There is nothing that can legally be done as the areas are upland habitat. \n \n\u201cWhat bothered me most is that this year, two large wetland thicket areas were completely destroyed. I thought that there was protection for wetlands. The first is on the left of Wauwinnet Avenue (always thought that it was Watch Hill Road) as you drive into Watch Hill. It is a pond that had extensive trees and thickets. It has been clear cut to the ground all the way to the pond. There is a silt fence, but it was actually in the pond, not outside of it. The other spot is along Ocean View Highway. Wetlands were filled in to build a large house and surrounding thickets have been clear cut. This is a pretty large area that has produced numerous quality bird species in the past.\u201d \n \nWilliams\u2019 email raises a lot of questions. I began to think about whether the clear-cutting had been done at the owners\u2019 request or if it was a landscaper, a garden designer, or even a landscape architect who had just gone ahead and done it. The homeowners might not even have been in residence when it occurred, so they might not be aware that this was done on their properties. \n \nHow many property owners share Williams\u2019 perspective that most landscapes can and should also offer less-manicured places for wildlife and birds? Are people even aware of the importance of these thickets? You don\u2019t have to have a big ugly pile of sticks in your front yard, but most people can find an unobtrusive spot where they can offer cover and food to birds. \n \nPerhaps some ecologically minded group could publish a pamphlet for homeowners that would explain the value of thickets and brush piles and how a manicured landscape with a large expanse of green monoculture lawn is of no value to the ecosystem. Some people will not care, but others might. \n \nWildlife rehab courses begin \n \nThe January sub-permittee wildlife rehabilitation course has already begun, but if you have an interest in working with orphaned or injured wild animals and birds, you might want to check out the February session. This course is the first step toward becoming a state-licensed rehabilitator. \n \nI took the course a few years ago and I found it fascinating, although the calculations of medications and feeding formulas were very technical, as they have to be, since the requirements of different species are so exacting. \n \nThe course fee is $50. Wildlife Rehabilitators of Rhode Island has more information on its website: http://www.riwildliferehab.org/events \n \nPileated woodpeckers \n \nI always enjoy visiting people in other areas to see which birds are coming to their feeders. While in Quebec visiting family over the holidays, I sat in my sister\u2019s living room watching the purple finches, which I have not had at my feeders. She also gets occasional irruptions of common redpolls, which, when they descend en masse, number in the hundreds and scarf up her expensive thistle seed at an astounding rate. \n \nIt was too early in the season for the northern finches, but one morning, a pair of pileated woodpeckers that sometimes stop by swooped in and fed for several minutes at the peanut feeders. These are the largest of our woodpeckers, and very impressive when seen up close. They\u2019re also the woodpeckers that make the weird, oblong holes in trees. \n \nAs always, please email me with your thoughts and observations. \n \ncdrummond@thewesterlysun.com @CynthiaDrummon4","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"The Wild Side: Private landowners can help save ecosystem","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Washington","zipCode":"02891","state":"Rhode Island","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Westerly","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Westerly Sun","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169688372","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"803"},"name":"Westerly Sun","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Local","Geographic","Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thewesterlysun.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.riwildliferehab.org/events"],"sequenceId":"695194744545","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:48Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Tori deflected a pass and Carson stole it \u2026 they got their opportunity, and we preach it all year long, and they were the epitome of that. RHODE ISLAND, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"682","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395786207&p=2kx&v=1&x=VekO32heGOlnr95t3EkvLw","id":"29395786207","content":"WESTERLY \u2014 Working as a substitute teacher would be ideal for Angel-Lena Smith, of Westerly, a certified paraprofessional who is studying part time for her teaching certificate. \n \n\u201cI would like to get into the district to have my name known \u2014 the ideal schedule would be about three days a week,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s all about networking, so by the time I\u2019m finished with school to be a teacher, that way I\u2019d already be in the district.\u201d \n \nSmith, 30, was among a steady stream of applicants who attended the school district\u2019s Winter Open House at the Westerly High School cafeteria Saturday. The event served as a job fair for substitute positions as teachers, paraprofessionals, custodians, and bus drivers. \n   \nFrom this section: \nZone change requested for artist guesthouses \n  \nKimberly Sihavong, director of human resources, said 81 people had registered for the event as of 10 a.m. \n \n\u201cI\u2019m really impressed with the turnout \u2014 it\u2019s the first time we\u2019ve done this so I was a little nervous,\u201d she said. \u201cWesterly is facing a substitute shortage, which is kind of a nationwide problem, and with all the kids that graduate from college in December, there\u2019s a ton of people looking for jobs and there\u2019s not a lot of jobs because it\u2019s mid-school year and this it gives them an opportunity to become employed, to find a home in the district.\u201d \n \nIn Rhode Island, substitute teaching requires a bachelor\u2019s degree but no longer requires a substitute certificate. In Westerly, the substitute per diem rate is $80, which Sihavong said was \u201cpretty average\u201d since $70 to $100 per day is the range statewide. \n \nSihavong said she didn\u2019t currently have any full-time teacher openings and wouldn\u2019t know until late spring how many positions would open up because of retirements and resignations. \n \nSubstituting can be a good career choice for those looking to get their foot in the door to eventually get a job as a teacher, but it requires dedication and commitment, she said. \n \n\u201cSubbing is like test-driving a car \u2014 every school district is different and it\u2019s a good way for them to see if it\u2019s a good place for them to end up permanently,\u201d she said. She noted that good candidates \u201ccare about the community, they care about the kids, they want to become involved; they\u2019re not just coming in, doing the work and leaving \u2014 they\u2019re engaging with us.\u201d \n \nFor Harvey Blanchette, 36, of Westerly, substitute teaching would mesh well with his parenting duties and his desire to teach. \n \n\u201cI saw the ad online and I thought it was kind of a nice opportunity and I\u2019ve been thinking about getting into education for a really long time,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m a stay-at-home dad with a lot going on so it seems like a nice chance to test the waters\u201d \n \nWorking on a per diem basis would provide flexibility, he said. \n \n\u201cI\u2019m responsible for my daughters most of the time and I\u2019d be able to find coverage pretty quickly,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s tough to have a full-time job because then you\u2019re paying for day care for the entire span of time \u2014 working a couple days a week is more manageable.\u201d \n \nNicole Fortunato, 23, came all the way from her home in Ramsey, New Jersey, to apply for the open house. A 2015 graduate of Roger Williams University, she has worked for two years as a teaching assistant in New Jersey. \n \n\u201cThey emailed that they were having the open house and I thought it was a good networking opportunity,\u201d she said. \u201cI am trying to become an elementary school teacher and I want to come back to Rhode Island. I\u2019ve been a teaching assistant for two years and I\u2019m ready to teach on my own.\u201d \n \nWesterly High School Principal Todd Grimes said he was pleased with the caliber of applicants at the event. \n \n\u201cI didn\u2019t know what to expect but I\u2019ve had some really great conversations today with some potential employees,\u201d he said. Substitute teaching, he added, \u201cis a challenging position \u2014 you need to have strong communication skills, be flexible and adaptable and work well with people because you never know what to expect and every assignment may be different.\u201d \n \nchewitt@thewesterlysun.com","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Substitute jobs could open doors","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Washington","zipCode":"02891","state":"Rhode Island","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Westerly","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Westerly Sun","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169688372","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"803"},"name":"Westerly Sun","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Local","Geographic","Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thewesterlysun.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194747779","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:48Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

It was adapted into a hit film starring Meryl Streep and Anne Hathaway. \n \nThe new musical will be produced by McCollum, Fox Stage Productions and Rocket Entertainment. During that time, St. Pius X School has reached out to all families with a goal of making Catholic education attainable. We are a school where families and children of all faiths are welcomed and educational needs are met: a school where families are active participants in the education of their children, and a school where the community members support both religious and educational goals. \n \nStudents need to be prepared to live a life enriched by the teachings of Christ and to integrate these skills into college and career readiness. Our mission is to carry on this rich Catholic tradition in times that are economically challenging while meeting the educational challenges of the 21st-century. How do we carry out this mission? \n \nThe ways and teachings of Jesus Christ are modeled in an environment where students demonstrate their knowledge of Catholic teachings, their growth in faith and their willingness to serve others. Students will grow academically, display critical thinking skills and use technology as a learning tool. \n   \nFrom this section: \nDowntown lunch nearly went up in smoke \n  \nAfter careful study of research-based programs, we at St. Pius X have embarked upon restructuring our school program both academically and economically. In our rebranding we are changing our name to better represent the school and services provided. St. Pius X School will be changed to St. Pius X Regional Academy. Regional reflects the many communities and parishes we serve. Academy reflects the personalizing, specializing and spiritualizing of the educational program. \n \nThe restructuring of the academic programs will begin with the implementation of a principal/academic dean leadership program. This new model directly benefits every member of our community. The academic dean will work directly with classroom teachers focusing on curriculum development, data analysis and instruction. Through a personalized, specialized and spiritualized education, we educate the child in mind, body and spirit. \n \nThrough the implementation of lead teachers and peer coaching, we will personalize and specialize the educational process. We will continue to meet the needs of all students by adding a math specialist to expand our math curriculum to include algebra 1, which will prepare students to enter grade 9 with the option of taking geometry or algebra 2. One of the responsibilities of the math specialist will be to work with teachers in grades 5 to 8 to implement the diocesan math curriculum. We will also be adding a Spanish curriculum for students in grades K to 8. The diocesan integrated curriculum will complement the STREAM (science, technology, religion, engineering, arts and mathematics) program. \u201cBring Your Own Device\u201d (ex. Chromeboook) will be implemented in grades 5 to 8. \n \nIt is our goal to keep Catholic education affordable. To that end we are implementing a tuition freeze. Sibling discount and financial assistance will also be available. For the long-term sustainability of our academy, it is imperative that we have the support of both individual benefactors and local businesses. We do not benefit from tax money. We rely solely on tuition, fundraisers and some subsidies from local Catholic parishes. In order to maintain our tradition of excellence, we are asking individuals and businesses to consider supporting us through sustained charitable giving. \n \nThrough God\u2019s blessings we are able to teach students about his great love for us and how we can better serve others. Please visit our website at westerlystpiusxschool.org or call or for an appointment to visit our academy. \n \nThe writers are the pastor of St. Pius X Church and the principal of St. Pius X Regional Academy.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Letter: St. Pius X School moving to next level as St. Pius X Regional Academy","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Washington","zipCode":"02891","state":"Rhode Island","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Westerly","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Westerly Sun","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169688372","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"803"},"name":"Westerly Sun","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Local","Geographic","Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thewesterlysun.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://westerlystpiusxschool.org/"],"sequenceId":"695194749386","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:17:48Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

1949 novel 1984 shot to number 1 on Amazon. I haven\u2019t seen any sales figures, but  according to a story in The New York Times , the book\u2019s publisher just ordered a 75,000-copy reprint to meet the new demand and was considering yet further printings. Those are remarkable numbers. What happened? \n \nI would have liked to think that the spike in sales happened in response to my essay about Orwell and the assault on free speech in the academy in this month\u2019s New Criterion . I\u2019ll come back to my observations about 1984 later on.  First, however, candor requires that I acknowledge that it was not my essay that sparked the surprising flood of sales. \n \nNo, the reason for the book\u2019s new success was Donald Trump.  Was it just another example of the Trump Bump, his doing for the publishing industry what he has done to the Dow Jones average (up by 9% since the election), foreign investment in the U.S., and basic country-wide confidence that the country is getting back on the right track? \n \nNot quite. When I say that \u201cDonald Trump\u201d was responsible for the sudden and unexpected surge in sales of 1984, what I mean is that the media seized upon a remark by Trump advisor Kellyanne Conway in response to the controversy over the number of people who viewed Trump\u2019s inauguration a week ago.  Trump opined that one and a half million people attended the festivities. The media laughed at that number, claiming it was much lower. Sean Spicer, in his first appearance as the administration\u2019s press secretary, insisted that Trump was right and that, in fact, \u201cthat was the largest audience to witness an inauguration, period. Both in person and around the globe.\u201d The media went to town on that, emitting dozens of articles with graphs, charts, statistics, and expert testimony. According to their count, what Trump, and Spicer, said was demonstrably false. \n \nIn one gleeful exchange  on NBC\u2019s \u201cMeet the Press,\u201d Chuck Todd repeatedly pressed Kellyanne Conway on the issue.  Why Did President Trump and then his press secretary deliberately lie about the facts of the size of the crowd at the inauguration? Conway parried that the press seemed determined to put the new administration in a bad light. For one thing, she noted, we didn\u2019t really know what the total number of people who watched the inauguration was. For another, the press, fixated on crowd size, essentially ignored a reporter\u2019s tweet that Trump had had the bust of Martin Luther King Jr. removed from the Oval Office when that really was demonstrably false. It was all, said Conway, part of the general effort to diminish and delegitimate the new administration.  All that slid of Todd\u2019s back, who came back to the facts about the size of the crowd.
