{"tags":["Features","Previews","mario kart 8 deluxe","nintendo switch"],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-19T23:01:48Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395789354","companies":[],"licenses":[],"indexTerms":[{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"}],"wordCount":"383","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395789354&p=2kx&v=1&x=EcTbNZeBF_jnJfLRC_YsdQ","id":"29395789354","content":"TABLETOP MODE CHANGES EVERYTHING IN MARIO KART 8 DELUXE.  \n\n \nI guess, for the most part, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe is the same game that released on the Wii U . The biggest takeaway from playing this as the Switch event was the fact we were able to play split-screen on the Nintendo Switch in tabletop mode and boy does this change everything. The fact that you can literally take this game with you on your Switch tablet and play two-player split-screen with a single Joy-con each is a game changer. I never took my Wii U anywhere and whilst I ways took my 3DS with me, it was only really a single-player machine and there\u2019s where the Nintendo Switch will hopefully bring back co-op gameplay. \n \n\n \nI don\u2019t hate the inclusion of being able to carry two items but I don\u2019t think it was entirely necessary either. The courses aren\u2019t really long enough to the point that you need to be holding two items at any given time in my opinion. \n \nI had the chance to play the new battle mode. More specifically, the new balloon fight on the Splatoon course. It felt much more closer to the more traditional battle mode that I\u2019ve always loved about Mario Kart. Not quite what it was on the Nintendo 64, but it\u2019s definitely a ton of fun, and it\u2019s set to get a lot more play time with the aforementioned tabletop play. \n \n \nLittle needs said regarding Mario Kart 8 Deluxe; it\u2019s more or less the same Mario Kart Wii U owners are already familiar with, albeit with a few more bells and whistles. This, of course means it is still fantastic and made better with the inclusion of all the DLC, the return of Battle Mode and the ability to carry two items. \n \n\n \nThe versatility of the Switch really shines with Mario Kart. Playing on the big screen, in TV Mode, of course looks fantastic, but even sat at a table, you and your friend looking at the Switch\u2019s screen, each armed with a Joy-Con each, the game still looks and feels incredible. The social nature of the Switch really shines here, and Mario Kart 8 Deluxe will likely be an essential game to have in any Switch owner\u2019s collection. \n  \nMario Kart 8 Deluxe will release JAPAN","domains":["GEO"],"score":"78"},{"name":"JAPAN; HOKKAIDO, JAPAN","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"TOKYO, JAPAN; JAPAN","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"538","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395790063&p=2kx&v=1&x=lPuw5mUJS3Tv1IuQaCEwRw","id":"29395790063","content":"In 1988, the Hokutosei sleeper express was the first train to use the Seikan tunnel to link Ueno Station in Tokyo to Sapporo, over a journey of 1,200 kilometers. It gained popularity through such charms as luxury sleeping cars and a dining car where travelers could enjoy French-style cuisine. However, to the regret of many fans, in August 2015 the train service was discontinued due to the opening of the Hokkaido Shinkansen line and the aging of the Hokutosei train cars.\n\nLast month, the Hokutosei was \"revived\" as a hostel in the Nihonbashi Bakurocho area of central Tokyo. Called Train Hostel Hokutosei, the hostel reuses train car equipment and has become a hot topic among railway enthusiasts who consider it a rebirth of their beloved sleeper express.\n\nThe hostel differs from ordinary accommodations, with large dormitory-type guest rooms shared by men and women on three floors and a large guest room exclusively for women on one floor. Its 38 bunk beds and two semiprivate rooms can accommodate up to 78 overnight guests. Restrooms, shower rooms and a kitchen are shared.\n\nMany of the interior items, including the bunk beds, were previously used in the sleeper express.\n\nSigns bearing train car numbers are posted at the entrance to each of the large guest rooms. Reading lights installed beside the beds are the actual ones used in the sleeping cars. In addition, the door to the dining car has been reused as the hostel's restroom door.\n\n\"I traveled on the Hokutosei train several times,\" said a company employee in his 40s living in Itabashi Ward, Tokyo, who stayed at the hostel overnight. \"Memories come flooding back at the smell and the feel of things here. I'd like to come again.\n\n\"I used to think I'd have a drink with my son, who's now in elementary school, on board the sleeper express some day,\" he said with a tinge of regret. \"But the dream will have to stay a dream, and that's too bad.\"\n\nCurrently, even Hokutosei fans from nearby are said to be coming in large numbers to stay the night at the hostel.\n\nThe idea for the Hokutosei hostel came from the East Japan Railway Co. group, one of the train's operators, and a company in Chiba Prefecture whose business involves repurposing unused property as accommodation facilities and managing those facilities. They hoped to re-create the experience of a trip on the Hokutosei for businesspeople and foreign tourists looking to casually enjoy a long stay in Japan. Renovation work, which incorporated the sleeper express' design concept of making the best use of limited space, was carried out in an existing seven-story building above the underground JR Bakurocho Station.\n\nAccommodation fees vary depending on preferences, but largely go from about 2,500 to 4,000 yen ($22 to $35 U.S.) per night.\n\nThe Nihonbashi Bakurocho area is near the starting point of what were the Gokaido highways - the five major highways linking Edo, the current Tokyo, and regional areas during the Edo period (1603-1867). The area is said to have flourished as a town of hatagoya inns.\n\nRecently, as the number of foreign tourists to Japan has rapidly risen, a growing number of accommodation facilities have emerged in the area to meet the needs of tourists seeking long-term stays at low rates.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Ryuzo Suzuki The Japan News/Yomiuri"},"topics":[{"name":"Tokyo news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Asia-Pacific latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Japan news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Elements of sleeper train revived as Tokyo hostel","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Volusia","zipCode":"32117","state":"Florida","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Daytona Beach","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daytona Beach News Journal","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169666623","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"3018"},"name":"Daytona Beach News Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.news-journalonline.com/"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194821748","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-28T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:30Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.news-journalonline.com/storyimage/LK/20170129/NEWS/170128500/AR/0/AR-170128500.jpg"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-28T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395790026","companies":[{"symbol":"2726","primary":true,"name":"PAL Group Holdings Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3781650001"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"BICYCLES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"VEHICLE TRAFFIC","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CYCLING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"TEXT MESSAGING","domains":["IND"],"score":"61"},{"name":"ROAD TRANSPORTATION SAFETY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"TRAFFIC ACCIDENTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"MOTOR VEHICLE SAFETY EQUIPMENT","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DEATHS & DEATH RATES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"LAW ENFORCEMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"62"},{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"57"},{"name":"TRENDS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES","domains":["IND"],"score":"61"}],"wordCount":"584","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395790026&p=2kx&v=1&x=AiKTvrBHbLbMXEurQUHEPw","id":"29395790026","content":"Many deaths are created by carelessness or bad behavior.\n\nI have several points to make on recent editorials that address highway safety in our area.\n\nFirst, one year\u2019s data does not make a trend. While incidents that result in these deaths should be reviewed, there is no definite conclusion to be made.\n\nSecond, pedestrian safety should not have priority. Aren\u2019t all lives special? Many deaths are created by carelessness or bad behavior, and are caused by those who are the victims of such encounters. So with some 80 percent of deaths occurring after dark, better lighting and educating pedestrians on the need to wear light-reflective clothing would be a big help to motorists. I\u2019m sure all of us have been out at night and seen folks crossing or walking along roads, and noted that their clothing made it very difficult to see them.\n\nWith more visitors coming to our area and with the warm weather much of this year, it is reasonable that more people are walking and bicycling than in colder, more rainy years.\n\nBefore we attempt to arrive at possible changes that could affect some of the issues causing the higher number of roadway deaths, first we need to look at the causes. That information is lacking at this point, and guessing at the problems will not help matters. When I see words like \u201cbelieved,\u201d \u201csuspects\u201d and \u201cprobably\u201d used by authorities in trying to figure out what to do, I know that these folks don\u2019t know why this happening and thus are just guessing at answers. Would patients want their doctors guessing at what to do when they have a medical issue? I think not.\n\nLet\u2019s get the facts together and study them before jumping to conclusions.\n\nOne thing we should not do is pass more laws about what people cannot do in their cars. Whether it be seat belt use, having an open container inside, or texting or otherwise using a cellphone, such laws just become revenue streams and provide law enforcement with excuses for stopping motorists who are posing no harm to others. This also removes our scarce and valuable police from patrolling for the real problem: drivers who we all see, all too often, getting away with bad and dangerous behavior. We should be concentrating on drivers who show by their actions on the road that they are a threat to others.\n\nIn statistics I have seen, pedestrians are as often as not responsible for getting hit by vehicles. I\u2019m all for the crosswalks with flashing lights that are used in high-pedestrian areas such as Clearwater Beach. Woe be you as a motorist or pedestrian if you do not use and honor the crossings as intended.\n\nThe advent of the \u201cShare The Road\u201d campaign is another problem because it pushes bicycle use of roadways. Combining high- and low-speed traffic is dangerous, which is why most freeways prohibit pedestrians and bicyclists. Marked bike lanes also shrink the pavement for vehicles, increasing chances of collisions with other vehicles. Motorists, not bicyclists, paid for the roadway \u2014 and considering 99 percent of people use roadways to travel or engage in commerce, the speedy and efficient use of highways by vehicles should be the highest priority. That said, sidewalks and bicycle paths are good community investments but not with highway funds.\n\nLet\u2019s figure out what the problem is before we come up with a big plan that may not address the real issues.\n\n\u2014 McGuire, of Palm Coast, is a longtime activist with the National Motorists Association.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"MIKE MCGUIRE: Find traffic safety fixes that work","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Volusia","zipCode":"32117","state":"Florida","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Daytona Beach","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daytona Beach News Journal","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169666623","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"3018"},"name":"Daytona Beach News Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.news-journalonline.com/"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194822593","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-28T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:30Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.news-journalonline.com/storyimage/LK/20170128/OPINION/170127603/AR/0/AR-170127603.jpg"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-28T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395790119","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SOCIAL MEDIA","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"TALKS & MEETINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"EVIDENCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"US REPUBLICAN PARTY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"POLITICAL PARTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"88"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2016","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"INVESTIGATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"CITIZEN SCIENCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"IMMIGRATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"INTERNET SOCIAL NETWORKING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"VOTERS & VOTING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"PRESS CONFERENCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"US DEMOCRATIC PARTY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"ELECTION FRAUD","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"OBAMA'S FIRST 100 DAYS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"BARACK OBAMA","domains":["PEO"],"score":"56"}],"wordCount":"694","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395790119&p=2kx&v=1&x=EG_71I9KeH47CEpIDPk9hA","id":"29395790119","content":"What's a community newspaper to do?\n\nAt the end of this column is an invitation to readers. But first, let's discuss the past few days.\n\nLast week, I found myself in a running debate on social media with supporters of President Donald Trump over a couple statements the new president made.\n\nFirst Trump insisted his inauguration attracted the largest crowd ever in Washington, D.C. Various press reports pointed out clear visual evidence that both President Barack Obama's 2009 inauguration and the women's protest march in the nation's capital the day after Trump's inauguration drew larger crowds than Trump's inauguration. That led an agitated White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer to hold a no-questions press conference last Saturday night to excoriate the media for \"deliberately false reporting.\"\n\nOn Sunday morning, I challenged a post on Volusia County Republican Party Chair Tony Ledbetter's Facebook page that repeated the suggestion that the so-called \"mainstream media\" were publishing false news about Trump's inaugural crowd. \n\nAmong other things, I pointed out that crowd scientists who studied photos of both events concluded that the women's protest march was about three times the size of Trump's inaugural crowd. They also concluded that Obama's 2009 inaugural crowd was bigger than Trump's inaugural. That brought a response from Ledbetter, who attended Trump's inauguration. \"Pat, really, crowd scientists. NOW THAT IS REALLY FAKE NEWS,\" he wrote. \n\nOn Monday, during a meeting with leaders from both parties of Congress, Trump insisted that he would have won the popular vote if millions of illegal immigrants hadn't voted for his Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton. Then, early Wednesday morning, Trump tweeted that he will launch a \"major investigation\" into voter fraud.\n\nThat led me to post on my Facebook page: \"Our new president continues to insist that he would have won the popular vote if so many illegal immigrants hadn't voted. Only no one can find any credible evidence to back that up. But there is significant evidence that it's not true. Now Trump has promised a 'major investigation' into voter fraud. I wonder how much this will cost taxpayers.\"\n\nFacebook friend Paul Zimmerman weighed in with a number of comments in favor of an investigation, including: \"I believe the reason there is no 'credible' evidence is because if it is happening, what party do you think would benefit from the fraud?\" (I'm pretty sure he means the Democrats.)\n\nTrump is colorful and charismatic, and some of his goals \u2014 leveling the trade playing field with other nations, creating higher-paying American jobs, and securing our borders \u2014 resonate with many Americans. \n\nHe is combative \u2014 witness last week's Twitter battle with Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto over Trump's vow to build a wall between the U.S. and Mexico, and make Mexico pay for it. The snit led to Nieto canceling a trip to the U.S.\n\nAbove all, Trump and his closest advisers see the media as the enemy. When the media challenge Trump's \"alternative facts,\" many of his supporters see nothing wrong with accusing the media of producing \"fake news\" for doing so.\n\nWhat's a community newspaper to do?\n\nWell, for starters we're going to continue to ensure that The News-Journal's opinion pages remain politically independent. Our core principles \u2014 protecting individual rights; support of free enterprise; championing small government and the belief that most issues should be resolved at the local level; cheering community involvement; and using facts to shape our opinions \u2014 will continue to guide us.\n\nSecondly, we'll continue to report accurately about Trump. If Trump \u2014 or any other politician \u2014 pushes \"alternative facts,\" we plan to report it. That's our job.\n\nFinally, we will maintain an open dialogue about the news with our readers. To that end, consider this an invitation to attend one of our daily morning news meetings, where we discuss stories our reporters are writing as well as the rest of the news. The meetings begin weekdays at 10 a.m. and usually end by 10:45 a.m. To attend, call at least 24 hours in advance so we can be sure to have a chair for you. You can call my cell phone: 386-681-8628.\n\nI look forward to hearing from you, and thanks for reading.\n\n\u2014 Rice is The News-Journal's editor. BEZOS","domains":["PEO"],"score":"57"}],"wordCount":"621","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395790134&p=2kx&v=1&x=l2kz0xil7IQJfBsz9mcAbQ","id":"29395790134","content":"Why should manufacturing jobs lost to foreign competition be privileged by protectionist policies in ways that jobs lost to domestic competition are not?\n\nWhen the president speaks of closed factories scattered like \u201ctombstones\u201d across America, has he noticed the shuttered stores in shopping centers, and entire malls reduced to rubble? He promises \u201cprotection\u201d to prevent foreigners from \u201cdestroying\u201d manufacturing jobs by exporting to America things that Americans want to import. Does he know that one American company might be \u201cdestroying\u201d more American jobs than China is? And that this supposed destruction is beneficial?\n\nThe company is Amazon (market capitalization: $390 billion), created by Jeffrey P. Bezos. He owns The Post, but it is for revolutionizing retailing that he ranks in the pantheon of American business. He belongs there with Richard Warren Sears, Alvah Curtis Roebuck, Aaron Montgomery Ward and Sam Walton, all of whom were constructively disruptive retailers and were as important in the nation\u2019s commercial history as were Henry Ford, Steve Jobs and Bill Gates.\n\nIn 2016, online buying during the holiday season surged 19 percent over the year before, which is one factor explaining this: Macy\u2019s, after announcing in August that it would close 100\u2009more of its remaining 730 stores, now says it will shed 10,000 jobs. Sears, which is 13 decades old and still has 1,600 stores, has lost $9 billion in five years, has closed 500 stores and is closing 150 more.\n\nSears stores in American downtowns, and the Sears catalog that put downtown goods within reach of rural America, caused difficulties for older retailers. In the second half of the 20th\u2009century, Walmarts at the edge of towns caused difficulties for downtown retailers with pre-modern \u2014 meaning pre-Walmart \u2014 global supply chains. Now Amazon is forcing Walmart to master online retailing.\n\nAlthough e-commerce was just 8\u2009percent of all 2016 retail sales, it came disproportionately at the expense of Sears, Macy\u2019s and other \u201canchor tenants\u201d that draw foot traffic from which other mall retailers benefit. When Amazon recently announced that it is going to create 100,000 warehousing and other jobs in the next 18 months, the New York Times reported that online retailing \u201chas destroyed many times that number of positions at malls and shopping centers across America.\u201d\n\nBut Henry Ford, too, \u201cdestroyed\u201d lots of jobs \u2014 those of blacksmiths, buggy-makers, etc. \u2014 the holders of which moved on, and usually up.\n\nWriting at MarketWatch, Rex Nutting argues that as Amazon revolutionizes consumer behavior, it \u201cis going to destroy more American jobs than China ever did.\u201d If so, the \u201cproblem\u201d is productivity. Nutting says \u201cAmazon needs about half as many workers to sell $100 worth of merchandise as Macy\u2019s does.\u201d The Times reports that \u201cthe typical online retailer generates $1,267,000 in sales per employee versus $279,000 at bricks-and-mortar stores.\u201d\n\nAll of which raises a question: Why should manufacturing jobs lost to foreign competition be privileged by protectionist policies in ways that jobs lost to domestic competition are not? When an Applebee\u2019s or Olive Garden, powered by a national advertising budget, opens next to, and causes the closing of, Madge\u2019s Diner, why does Madge not merit protection?\n\nThe reason is this: Domestic protection of Madge and millions of others unsettled by the constant churning of a dynamic domestic economy would mean slow economic growth \u2014 and rapid growth of government as it regulates consumers\u2019 choices and their consequences. But protection from imports also means this.\n\nReactionary liberalism has long held, and today\u2019s faux conservatism agrees, that existing jobs should be protected by policies that reduce the economic dynamism that threatens those jobs. Such protection means a net decrease in jobs but an increase in the self-esteem of blinkered protectionists who see the jobs \u201csaved\u201d but not those that, as a result of lost dynamism, are lost or never created.\n\n\u2014 Will is a Washington Post columnist. His email is georgewill@washpost.com.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"GEORGE WILL: 'Protecting' economy can also kill it","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Volusia","zipCode":"32117","state":"Florida","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Daytona Beach","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daytona Beach News Journal","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169666623","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"3018"},"name":"Daytona Beach News Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.news-journalonline.com/"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194823028","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-28T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:31Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.news-journalonline.com/storyimage/LK/20170129/OPINION/170127599/AR/0/AR-170127599.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-28T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395790168","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"TRAFFIC SIGNALS","domains":["IND"],"score":"87"},{"name":"BICYCLES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"DISTRACTED DRIVING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"76"},{"name":"DRIVER BEHAVIOR","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"VEHICLE TRAFFIC","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"CYCLING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"ROAD TRANSPORTATION SAFETY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"ACCIDENTAL FATALITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"TRAFFIC ACCIDENTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"71"},{"name":"RESEARCH REPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"DRIVING & TRAFFIC LAWS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"LETTERS & COMMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; FLORIDA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"DAYTONA BEACH, FL, USA; UNITED STATES; FLORIDA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"55"}],"wordCount":"1434","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395790168&p=2kx&v=1&x=UVBkV2DAEb1WMnPdVeJttg","id":"29395790168","content":"Consider all facets of road safety\n\nIt\u2019s rare, but I totally agree with the editorial of Jan. 25, \u201cStop the carnage on local roads.\u201d All of the points made in this well-written piece are valid, and I especially like the viewpoint on distracted driving. Texting and other screen-related activities should be primary offenses, and the fines should be significant. There\u2019s nothing so important on the screen that anyone needs to take their eyes off the road.\n\n(READ: Stop the carnage on local roads)\n\nYou did, however, leave out one significant contributing factor to the carnage, and that\u2019s the pedestrians and bicyclists themselves. Many times, at least from my observation, they are their own worst enemies. Just last week, I barely missed hitting a jogger in the dark, wearing black clothes, running in the road when there was a perfectly good sidewalk four feet away. It\u2019s not only stupid, it\u2019s illegal. Florida statute 316.130, section 3 says: \u201cWhere sidewalks are provided, no pedestrian shall, unless required by other circumstances, walk along and upon the portion of a roadway paved for vehicular traffic.\u201d\n\nAnd the people who cross our busiest roads in the middle of a block when a crosswalk with a traffic light is only a few steps away defy any logic or common sense. The same statute makes this illegal as well.\n\nBut the bicyclists who ignore the rules of the road are the worst. They zoom in and out of traffic, oblivious to the danger, and ride two and three abreast knowing they are impeding the flow of traffic, almost challenging drivers to pass them. Here\u2019s a blinding glimpse of the obvious: They may win the moment, but when it\u2019s car versus bicycle, the bicycle loses every time.\n\nThere\u2019s lots of blame to go around, but let\u2019s hope transportation officials look at all the factors, including the actions of people who choose to play chicken with a 3,000-pound car.\n\nSteve Burdette\n\nDaytona Beach\n\nSee those signs\n\nWith all the recent articles and opinions about traffic safety, texting, etc., I think it is time to address another concern for traffic safety.\n\n(READ: Volusia, Flagler see major increases in traffic fatalities)\n\nHave motorists forgotten the meaning of \u201cyield\u201d? All too often I encounter motorists merging onto a high-speed highway such as an interstate, expecting the fast-moving vehicles to just move over and let them in. And, with the recent report in The News-Journal about the increase in accidents, it is even more imperative to abide by all the highway signs.\n\nTo yield is to \u201cgive way,\u201d which is what drivers are supposed to do when a \u201cyield\u201d sign is in their lane of traffic. As a courtesy, we all try to accommodate the incoming traffic when it is safe to do so. But when all lanes are jammed, or drivers are pulling large trailers, at times it is impossible to move over. The first and only expectation that should be considered is that the fast-moving vehicles cannot \u201cgive way,\u201d thereby requiring the incoming driver to either slow down or speed up to merge safely. Forcing or bullying a fast-moving vehicle to move over creates the possibility of a horrific accident.\n\nCome on, folks, let\u2019s use common sense and abide by the traffic signs that say \u201cyield,\u201d and we\u2019ll all make it to our destination alive!\n\nDennis Sender\n\nOrmond Beach\n\nPut phone down\n\nAgain, Mark Lane puts his fingers on the pulse of human action that tragically forces human interaction in his Jan. 26 column, \u201cCrash data shows need for tougher driver texting law.\u201d\n\nAbout 15 years ago, many drivers were suddenly driving around with what appeared to be toothaches or full-blown root canals \u2014 driving with one hand, cradling their jaws with the other. After inspection, it turns out they were talking, and talking \u2014 for many miles \u2014 on those newfangled cellphone devices.\n\nFast forward, and now they\u2019re staring at their crotches most of the time, often using one hand or both hands, fumbling with their iPhones while steering with their knees. Drivers are no longer in a rush. If in front when the light turns green, it could take an eternal five seconds for the brakes to come off. They slog along blissfully, leading Jim Morrison\u2019s \u201cSoft(ware) Parade,\u201d while proudly multi-tasking and feeling so much smarter than challenged, one-dimensional drivers. Some are so bold as to hold the iPhone up to the bottom or even the top of the steering wheel, tiring of raising their eyes every four seconds to view the road. If only the lives of pedestrians, bicyclists, motorcyclists and other drivers and passengers were not at stake!\n\nJohn Arden\n\nDaytona Beach\n\nTracking local votes\n\nWith the recent attacks on the press, I want to say how much I appreciate The News-Journal\u2019s column entitled \u201cFlorida Tally: How Your U.S. Lawmakers voted.\u201d It\u2019s helpful for your readers to stay informed about how our lawmakers are voting, and to track their support or opposition to issues they find crucial in their community.\n\nI was alarmed, for example, to learn last week that U.S. Rep. Ron DeSantis voted to reduce the power of the Federal Trade Commission to regulate the derivatives (swaps) market. Remember, these financial instruments were designed to expressly benefit large banks and institutions, leaving average citizens at great risk. The 2008 global financial crisis was caused, in large part, by that gamble finally collapsing \u2014 costing many middle-class families their homes and life savings.\n\nI\u2019m glad to know where DeSantis stands \u2014 valuing the profits of large financial institutions over average Floridians\u2019 economic security.\n\nThe fact that DeSantis voted to allow insurance companies to deny health care to those with pre-existing conditions was even more troubling to me. Knowing that he voted against an element of the Affordable Care Act that had bipartisan support was, frankly, terrifying. Considering how many people could lose their coverage without such protections should be a concern to all of us, whether or not we supported him in this last election.\n\nI do have one suggestion. If you could publish the bills that are going to be voted on in advance, it would be even more helpful. This way, the public could call their congressmen (202-225-3121) or senators (202-224-3121) to let their voices be heard before votes happen.\n\nLouise Booth\n\nPort Orange\n\nThe next play\n\nThe phrase \u201cimpeachment\u201d is already being tossed about.\n\nI\u2019m waiting for someone to catch it and run for a touchdown. It is then that the bands will play and the flags will wave and wave and wave.\n\nKate Ruhlman Claim victory\n\nBeing brought up in the middle of the middle class, I saw Donald Trump\u2019s victory as inevitable. It was plain (except to establishment elites) that Middle America was completely done with the economic deprivation of globalist hegemony. It was obvious that too many were riding in the wagon, with too few pulling. It was time for taxpaying citizens to take back their country.\n\nAdmittedly, prior to Inauguration Day, there remained a nagging doubt that somehow the powers that be might stop him. But they couldn\u2019t. He outworked, outflanked and outsmarted the entire Washington-media-Hollywood army of arrogance.\n\nPresident Trump for U.S. Let\u2019s roll.\n\nJoe Fieldus\n\nOrmond Beach\n\nCost of immigration\n\nAs a taxpayer I have often wondered why the costs of illegal immigrants living in our country are not deducted from any foreign aid provided to their country of origin. As of 2015, there were an estimated 73,665 non-U.S. citizens in state and federal prisons, accounting for approximately 5 percent of the prison population and costing taxpayers (based on 2012 figures) an average of $31,286 annually for a total cost of approximately $2.3 billion. Additionally, any costs associated with returning the released prisoners to their original home should also be recouped.\n\nAlso, according to the Center for Immigration Studies, illegal immigrant households receive an average of $5,692 in federal welfare benefits every year. Why can\u2019t their countries of origin pay for their illegal presence and costs to U.S. taxpayers? One can only imagine how many taxpayer dollars would be saved by this action.\n\nWilliam E. Patterson\n\nNew Smyrna Beach\n\nTrump\u2019s moves\n\nIn light of the recent actions of our new president, it is clear that he is comfortable with letting the taxpayers fund his follies. Billions for a wall that Mexico isn\u2019t buying, another extensive study searching for nonexistent voter fraud, a pipeline from Canada that we don\u2019t need, relocating the U.S. Embassy in Israel, etc. The fun just never ends. Perhaps he should set up a GoFundMe account and give his wealthy friends a chance to pay for his foible-induced conjurings. How about an intervention or some therapy? Has a president ever been \"Baker acted\"?\n\nMaurice \u201cPat\u201d LaMee\n\nOrmond Beach","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"LETTERS: \" Just last week, I barely missed hitting a jogger in the dark.\"","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Volusia","zipCode":"32117","state":"Florida","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Daytona Beach","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daytona Beach News Journal","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169666623","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"3018"},"name":"Daytona Beach News Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.news-journalonline.com/"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194826385","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-28T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:31Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.news-journalonline.com/storyimage/LK/20170129/OPINION/170127601/AR/0/AR-170127601.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-28T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395790101","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"CHILDREN","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"COUNTY GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"COUNTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"EXECUTIVES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"HOTELS & MOTELS","domains":["IND"],"score":"66"},{"name":"HOMELESS SHELTERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"TEMPORARY SHELTERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PRIMARY SCHOOLS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"APPROVALS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"SUBSTANCE ABUSE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"SCHOOL DISTRICTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"SCHOOL BOARDS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"MENTAL ILLNESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"NEW CONSTRUCTION","domains":["IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"CONSTRUCTION","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"FAMILY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"HOMELESSNESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"VOLUNTEERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"DAYTONA BEACH, FL, USA; UNITED STATES; FLORIDA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"636","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395790101&p=2kx&v=1&x=Q7CKDH2FHpkRfvIaoPApeA","id":"29395790101","content":"Why did The Neighborhood Center succeed? Because like Hope Place, it had its ducks in a row.\n\nLast week, the local leaders responsible for Hope Place, a new facility in Daytona Beach for homeless families with children, held a groundbreaking ceremony at the former Hurst Elementary School. It was symbolically important, not just for what it means for Hope Place, but also for showing the community what can \u2014 and must \u2014 be accomplished with regard to other sectors of homelessness.\n\nThe dozens of community volunteers, social service administrators and elected officials crowded into a small, former classroom represented the collective support that was required to make Hope Place a reality. Forough Hosseini, founder and chair of Food Brings Hope, a local organization that helps feed needy families, was the driving force who had one goal in mind: that no child should be homeless. She enlisted the help of Mark Geallis, executive director of Halifax Urban Ministries, which will run and operate the shelter, as well as others to create a plan and draft a proposal.\n\n(READ: 300-bed family homeless shelter aiming to open in August)\n\nThey knew they needed the approval of the school district and School Board to sell the Hurst building and property, as well as financial support from Volusia County. Hosseini spent months negotiating behind the scenes, laying the groundwork. She initially asked County Manager Jim Dinneen for $1.5 million to acquire renovate the former school, but he said once he was sold on the project he convinced her the county needed to give $3.5 million to do Hope Place right.\n\nThat came with one major caveat: It would be a one-time appropriation. Under no circumstances would the county provide operating expenses.\n\nSo Hope Place has had to persuade several municipalities to pitch in $200,000 every year in addition to what Hosseini hopes to raise from private donors. Local hotels are donating furniture, and businesses are donating building materials.\n\nHope Place is an ambitious project with a lot of moving parts. That it is advancing toward fruition while other proposed homeless solutions have stalled is explained in part by the fact that families with children are an easier sell with a higher chance of success. Most are temporarily homeless because they are down on their luck, and are eager to get back on their feet and become independent again. They are not the chronic adult homeless who hang out in public areas and panhandle, many of whom suffer from mental illness and/or substance abuse. Those cases are more difficult to treat.\n\nBut Hope Place also received so much community support because its sponsors had a well-conceived plan and demonstrated strong leadership and commitment. To prove that success is not limited to families in need, the County Council recently unanimously approved giving $1.13 million to construct a 5,000-square-foot expansion of The Neighborhood Center of West Volusia in DeLand. The nonprofit will add 20 shelter beds and provide the homeless with services. In December, the DeLand City Commission approved spending $50,000 annually for five years on the shelter. The city\u2019s support was crucial to securing the county\u2019s contribution.\n\nWhy did The Neighborhood Center succeed? Because like Hope Place, it had its ducks in a row.\n\nMeanwhile, Daytona Beach, the county, other municipalities and the social services community continue to be fractured over a solution for the hardcore homeless, such as whether it should be a comprehensive shelter (and where it would be located) or a housing-first approach. Plenty of ideas have been batted around, but there\u2019s been no consensus. No leader has emerged to rally stakeholders around a strategy, and until that happens there will be no funding available.\n\nAs its name implies, Hope Place provides optimism for those in need. But it also provides the prospect that its template can be used to effect positive change in other areas of homelessness.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"OUR VIEW: Hope for the homeless","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Volusia","zipCode":"32117","state":"Florida","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Daytona Beach","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Daytona Beach News Journal","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169666623","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"3018"},"name":"Daytona Beach News Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.news-journalonline.com/"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194827475","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-28T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:31Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.news-journalonline.com/storyimage/LK/20170129/OPINION/170127600/AR/0/AR-170127600.jpg"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:32Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395790239","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SPORTS; TENNIS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"93"},{"name":"AWARDS & PRIZES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"COACHES & TRAINERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"LUBBOCK, TX, USA; UNITED STATES; TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"57"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"88"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; ARIZONA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"570","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395790239&p=2kx&v=1&x=e_3bzN6mh8mec-4TnqeD7Q","id":"29395790239","content":"Savannah Slaysman fullfilled a lifelong dream as she helped the Sun Devils earn a monumental upset against the Gamecocks \n  Photo by Nathan J Fish | The State Press \nFreshman Savannah Slaysman competes in the Singles Main Draw at the 2016 ASU Thunderbird Invitational in Tempe, Arizona, Nov. 5, 2016. \n By Joe Jacquez | 51 minutes ago \nASU women's tennis freshman  Savannah Slaysman has dreamed about the opportunity to win the deciding match for the team she grew up watching her whole life.  \n \nOn Saturday afternoon at the McLeod Tennis Center in Lubbock, Texas, Slaysman's dream became reality. \n \nASU defeated No. 16 South Carolina 4-3 at the Texas Tech Invitational, part of the International Tennis Association's Kick-Off Weekend. \n  \nWINNER, WINNER, CHICKEN DINNER! @savslaysman rallies despite cramping to clinch match over #16 South Carolina, 4-3! #ASUvsSC  pic.twitter.com/rXV7NBo0UA \n\u2014 Sun Devil Tennis (@sundeviltennis) January 29, 2017  \nSlaysman claimed the first set against No. 122 Brigit Folland, 6-4. She then surrendered six match points in the second set and fell 5-7. \n \nDespite battling muscle cramps late in the third set, Slaysman persevered and tied the deciding set at two games apiece. Slaysman took the next two games to move ahead 4-2, then traded the next three games to put herself one game away from victory. \n \nSlaysman came through with a 6-4, 5-7, 6-4 win and picked up the biggest singles victory of her young collegiate career. \n \n\u201cI've never cramped before so it was important for me to stay mentally tough,\u201d Slaysman said. \u201cMy teammates and coaches were so encouraging and cheering me on after every single point and I really wanted to win for them. \n \n\u201cI just kept reminding myself of all the work we've put in and that helped me fight through it. I actually didn\u2019t know for sure that my match was the deciding point even though I did have a feeling it was ... It's an experience I will never forget.\u201d \n \nHead coach Sheila McInerney collected her fourth career victory versus the Gamecocks. The 2016 ITA Meritorious Service Award winner was thrilled for Slaysman and her team\u2019s performance. \n \n\u201cI was really proud of our team,\u201d McInerney said. \u201cFor Savannah as a freshman to come through and win the deciding match speaks volumes as to her ability and toughness. It was a very well-played match, and after missing out on six match points in the second set, for her to come back and win the third was incredible.\u201d \n \nNo. 49 sophomore  Sammi Hampton and junior Kelley Anderson earned the other two singles victories for the Sun Devils. Hampton defeated No. 72 sophomore Paige Cline, 6-3, 6-4. Anderson also won in straight sets, dismantling senior Caroline Dailey, 6-0, 6-0. \n \nNo. 63 senior Kassidy Jump fell to No. 62 freshman Mia Horvit in straight sets, 6-4, 6-3. Junior Nicole Fossa-Huergo dropped a 6-3, 6-2 decision to South Carolina No. 100 freshman Silvia Chinellato. Finally, senior Gussie O\u2019Sullivan lost to junior Hadley Berg, 6-3, 6-1. \n \nBefore singles play began, ASU claimed the doubles point. Jump and Hampton were off the court in a hurry, defeating Rohrabacher and Horvit, 6-0. Meanwhile, on court No. 1, senior Alexandra Osborne and Fossa-Huergo earned a ranked win over No. 39 Berg and Cline, 6-3. \n \n\u201cWe came out and played great doubles and the doubles point was crucial,\u201d McInerney said. \u201cKelley and Sammi got off the court fairly quickly (in singles,) which also helped.\u201d \n \nOn Sunday, ASU will play in the regional championship match against  No. 13 Texas Tech . A Sun Devils win clinches a bid into next week's ITA Women\u2019s Indoor Championships in New Haven, Connecticut. \n \nReach the reporter at jpjacqu1@asu.edu or follow @joejacquezaz on Twitter. \n \nLike State Press Sports on","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Joe Jacquez"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: tennis news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Freshman wins deciding match in ASU women's tennis upset over No. 16 South Carolina","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Maricopa","zipCode":"85287","state":"Arizona","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Tempe","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"ASU Web Devil","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169677431","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"9"},"name":"ASU Web Devil","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Local","Geographic","Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.statepress.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/media.asp/37494_110516_asu_womens_tennis5f.jpg","http://www.thesundevils.com/roster.aspx?rp_id=3596","https://twitter.com/savslaysman","https://twitter.com/hashtag/ASUvsSC?src=hash","https://t.co/rXV7NBo0UA","https://twitter.com/sundeviltennis/status/825508281208729603","http://www.texastech.com/index.aspx?path=wten","https://twitter.com/joejacquezaz","https://www.facebook.com/ASUSPsports/","https://twitter.com/statepresssport"],"sequenceId":"695194828513","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:32Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:32Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395790240","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"COACHES & TRAINERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"WINTER SPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"}],"wordCount":"722","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395790240&p=2kx&v=1&x=avIBgcEa1FXszJVk7mVokA","id":"29395790240","content":"Continuing his hot hand, sophomore forward Anthony Croston had two goals to help the Sun Devils earn a split of the weekend series \n  Photo by Delia Johnson | The State Press \nJunior Wade Murphy (15) faces off against defense during a game against Southern New Hampshire at the Oceanside Ice Arena on Friday, Jan. 20, 2017. \n By Matt Layman | 1 hour ago \nIn its second win over a ranked opponent this season, ASU hockey upset No. 17 Quinnipiac on Saturday after losing to the Bobcats 4-2 on Friday. \n \nSophmore forward Anthony Croston and freshman goalie Joey Daccord played a big role in the win, which evened a two-game road series between ASU and QU. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s a big win,\u201d head coach Greg Powers said through Sun Devil Athletics after the game. \u201cIn the grand scheme of things, it\u2019s probably the biggest win we\u2019ve had to date. After not an ideal effort last night, for our young team to bounce back and play that hard, and jump out to a lead on these guys was tremendous.\u201d \n \nIn his last four games, Croston has six goals with one assist, taking 15 shots on goal with a +7 rating (the first two games in that stretch were against a Division II opponent.) His statistical boost as of late follows a trend that dates all the way back to early November. \n \nRead more:   Anthony Croston producing mightily for ASU hockey since promotion \n \nMeanwhile, Daccord stopped 53 of 55 shots faced in net on Saturday for the win, breaking a streak of four straight starts by senior netminder Rob Levin . \n \nDespite the final score, Quinnipiac outshot ASU 55 to 19. \n \n\u201cJoey Daccord had his coming-out party,\u201d Powers said. \u201cWe all knew that was the type of game he is capable of having. If he can play like that and be confident in his ability \u2014 because his ability is off the chart \u2014 the sky is the limit for him.\u201d \n \nAfter struggling to find the net in the first 40 minutes of Friday\u2019s game, ASU took an early 1-0 lead on Saturday when sophomore forward Dylan Hollman found sophomore forward Anthony Croston in front of the QU net. \n \nThe Sun Devils led after nearly 15 minutes of scoreless hockey. \n \nWith just over three minutes left in the first period, an odd-man rush developed for QU that drew out from the ASU net. That left the door wide open for the Bobcats, but they failed to put it home. \n  \nOMG! What a series of saves & plays by the Devils! pic.twitter.com/oadsRuTNau \n\u2014 Sun Devil Hockey (@SunDevilHockey) January 29, 2017  \nFollowing that near-goal by QU, the Bobcats were called for too many men on the ice. The resulting power play yielded a booming slapshot by freshman defenseman Brinson Pasichnuk , putting ASU up 2-0. \n \nJust 22 seconds into the second period, Croston scored on a turnover by the Bobcats during 4-on-4 play. That made it 3-0 Sun Devils with Croston\u2019s second goal of the game. \n \nMidway through the second, QU senior forward Tim Clifton kicked a puck into the ASU net with his skate. The call on the ice was ruled a QU goal to end Daccord\u2019s shutout, but it was subsequently overturned. \n \nJust seconds later, Clifton got another chance and buried it in the net, getting QU on the board to make it 3-1 ASU. \n \nA goal by freshman defenseman Jakob Stridsberg closed out the second period as the Sun Devils went into second intermission with a 4-1 lead. \n \n\u201cStridsberg scored a huge goal to bump it back to a three-goal lead, and when that happened, I had a pretty good feeling,\u201d Powers said. \u201cWhen he scored that, and with Joey being as sharp as he was, I knew he wasn\u2019t going to give up four more goals.\u201d \n \nQU senior defenseman Connor Clifton scored his second goal of the weekend in the third period to cut his team\u2019s deficit to 4-2. But that would conclude the scoring for the evening as ASU hung on to win. \n \nThe Sun Devils\u2019 next opponent could prove to be an even taller task than Quinnipiac: ASU will travel to No. 13 Western Michigan for games on Friday and Saturday, finishing a stretch of four straight road games against ranked opponents. \n \n\u201cI think we played much more disciplined and stuck to our game plan, \" Powers said. \"We play a simple game against teams like this and our guys executed.\u201d \n \nReach the reporter at matthew.layman@asu.edu or follow  @Mattjlayman on Twitter. \n \nLike  State Press Sports on","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Matt Layman"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Croston, Daccord lift ASU hockey to win at No. 17 Quinnipiac","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Maricopa","zipCode":"85287","state":"Arizona","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Tempe","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"ASU Web Devil","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169677431","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"9"},"name":"ASU Web Devil","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Local","Geographic","Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.statepress.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/media.asp/37493__mg_7177f.jpg","https://twitter.com/JDac35","https://t.co/oadsRuTNau","https://twitter.com/SunDevilHockey/status/825499548789436417","https://twitter.com/mattjlayman","https://www.facebook.com/ASUSPsports","https://twitter.com/statepresssport"],"sequenceId":"695194828681","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:32Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:01:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29371171060","companies":[{"symbol":"101140","primary":true,"name":"ARTIS Co Ltd","contentCount":4,"exchange":"KRX","titleCount":0,"isin":"KR7101140002"},{"symbol":"CAPA","primary":false,"name":"Capital Art Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"US13972L1008"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"ARTISTS & PERFORMERS","domains":["IND"],"score":"92"},{"name":"PAINTING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"VISUAL & PERFORMING ARTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"POPULATION SIZE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"MUSEUMS & GALLERIES","domains":["IND"],"score":"91"},{"name":"ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"VISUAL ARTISTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"ART DEALERS","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"BISMARCK, ND, USA; UNITED STATES; NORTH DAKOTA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"52"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; ARIZONA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"52"}],"wordCount":"604","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395790425&p=2kx&v=1&x=8hjLMv6W1UR675qffZg9Nw","id":"29395790425","content":"As the number of Bismarck art galleries increases, the local arts community sees an opportunity to grow. \n\nSince opening, Capital Art Gallery has sold $100,000 worth of art: eight paintings, eight bronze statue, a mosaic and several glass pieces by Jon Offett. And Small Business Saturday was a busy day, said David Borlaug, president of the Lewis and Clark Fort Mandan Foundation, which runs the gallery. \n\n\"In spite of the bad weather, in terms of original art, sales have been great,\" he said. \"It validates Bismarck was ready for this kind of gallery.\" \n\nBorlaug said Bismarck has been \"blessed\" with a multitude of galleries, each with a different niche. Bismarck Downtown Artist Cooperative, Bismarck Art & Galleries Association and Gallery 522 all feature member artists' works. There's also Art Gallerie on Main, where Lydia Richez-Bowman features her own work and that of several other local artists, as well as teaching classes. \n\nBorlaug said Capital Gallery is focused on featuring two artists on its walls \u2014 one expressive and one traditional \u2014 along with several others who work in various other media, such as glass or bronze. The gallery sets itself apart by limiting the number of artists and featuring them for longer periods. And because it does not cater to member artists, \"the world's our oyster,\" he said. \n\nBorlaug has artists lined up for the foreseeable future, with Deane Collin Fay of Gackle alongside Bismarck native Vern Erickson's western Americana pieces coming up in Februarym The Bismarck Tribune (http://bit.ly/2joTPY3 ) reports. \n\n\"There is a thriving art culture in Bismarck,\" Borlaug said. \"We're just glad to be part of it.\" \n\nHe points to Jessica Wachter as an up-and-coming Bismarck artist who has a \"real following across the country,\" with works featured in galleries in Los Angeles and Scottsdale, Ariz. \n\nStephanie Delmore of Gallery 522 agrees. \n\n\"I think we're just getting to that point of there being enough galleries\" that they could partner on events, like gallery hops, she said. \"We can start to thread ourselves together.\" \n\nAs Bismarck's population has become more diverse, Delmore said there are more people who are used to going to galleries on a regular basis. \n\n\"I think the traffic is picking up,\" she said, with the public understanding what art adds to a community. \n\nSince starting 32 years ago, Gallery 522 has wanted all local artists to be able to show their work daily rather than wait five years for their turn at a larger show. \n\n\"We've always meant to be of service to artists,\" Delmore said, and on a day-to-day basis, the gallery has a multitude of artists covering its walls. \n\nBismarck Downtown Artist Cooperative works much the same way, though with slightly different rules and organization, while BAGA has become more well-known for hosting larger shows for its member artists, Delmore said. \n\n\"I think we've got a lovely base of artists in the area,\" she said, and having more galleries showcasing those artists could result in more art-focused events come spring. \n\nBorlaug said he thinks Bismarck is where Fargo was a couple decades ago in terms of growing from a big town to a small city \u2014 and art \"makes cities.\" \n\n\"I feel Bismarck is more than ready to grow its arts community,\" he said. \n\nIn turn, that community could help grow the city, attracting more residents. Borlaug said one of the first things people want to know about before moving somewhere is the arts scene: Is there a symphony? An orchestra? Visual arts? \n\n\"It could help get people to move here,\" he said, and the art produced here is helping tell this area's story. \n\n--- \n\nInformation from: Bismarck Tribune, http://www.bismarcktribune.com \n\nAP Member Exchange shared by The Bismarck Tribune.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"JESSICA HOLDMANThe Bismarck Tribune"},"topics":[{"name":"Entertainment: celebrity gossip","group":"Entertainment"},{"name":"Entertainment: latest","group":"Entertainment"},{"name":"Entertainment: fine arts news","group":"Entertainment"}],"title":"Number of art galleries increases for Bismarck","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Harrison","zipCode":"39507","state":"Mississippi","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Gulfport","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Sun Herald","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169658155","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"6447"},"name":"Sun Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Gossip","Lifestyle","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.sunherald.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://bit.ly/2joTPY3","http://www.bismarcktribune.com/"],"sequenceId":"695194832605","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:01:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:34Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:36Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395790609","companies":[{"symbol":"2659","primary":true,"name":"SAN-A CO Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3324500002"},{"symbol":"SNAAF","primary":true,"name":"SAN-A CO Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3324500002"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"COLLEGIATE SPORTS ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ATHLETES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"VOLLEYBALL","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SPORTS AWARDS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"LETTERS & COMMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"BANGKOK, THAILAND; THAILAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"76"},{"name":"THAILAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"851","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395790609&p=2kx&v=1&x=3VA6Pa28L-fUABo6ieX-WQ","id":"29395790609","content":"Volleyball  \nBy on Jan 29, 2017 03:08 PM \n     \nSila (club team) ang magre-request \u2018di ba? Since wala pa si Alyssa ITC because she is new eh, ngayon lang siya magka-club, so pag ganoon ire-request nila (club team) sa NSA -- LVPI vice president Peter Cayco on Alyssa Valdez's delayed ITC release \n  \nLarong Volleyball sa Pilipinas, Inc. vice president Peter Cayco clarified that there was a miscommunication in the process of acquiring an international transfer certificate (ITC) that delayed Filipina superstar Alyssa Valdez's clearance to play in the Thai League Sunday afternoon. \n \nThe sports association came under fire Saturday following the reports that Valdez still has to receive her ITC to be able to suit up for 3BB Nakornnont in her debut game against King-Bangkok. \n \nIn a late report, Valdez received her ITC and was cleared to play. \n \nCayco was on the receiving end of criticism from volleyball fans, citing reports pointing that LVPI failed to register Valdez for an ITC. \n \nHe clarified that they did their part in giving the former three-time UAAP Most Valuable Player the go-signal to play in Thailand, adding that since Valdez is just applying for a new ITC the process of obtaining one falls on the side of 3BB Nakornnont.  \n \nCayco and Valdez met at the LVPI office in Arellano University in Taft Avenue last January 14 before she left for Thailand the day after.     \n \n\u201cYes, sila (club team) ang magre-request \u2018di ba? Since wala pa si Alyssa ITC because she is new eh, ngayon lang siya magka-club, so pag ganoon ire-request nila (club team) sa NSA,\u201d he explained Saturday during the national team tryouts. \u201cSo binigyan ko sila ng clearance, she\u2019s clear to play. Ang kuwan ko lang, kami (LVPI) daw ang humingi ng ITC dapat nga sila \u2018yung requesting club. Wala pa sayang previous ITC so what should have be done was kuha sila ng clearance sa amin, which I already gave.\u201d \n \n\u201cActually three letters na ang pinapadala ko. We met lang kasi the day before she left so after she left siguro after two days nagpadala na ako ng letter, then I sent a second letter and finally I sent a third letter on Friday that she\u2019s cleared to play,\u201d he continued. \u201cDapat sila na ang nagpa-process niyan eh. Kasi it\u2019s a new ITC and if it\u2019s new, club to NSA (dapat) it\u2019s not club to club kaya mas simple.\u201d \n \nCayco said that LVPI already cleared Valdez to play in Thailand, a historic feat for a Filipina spiker. \n \n\u201cEh ni-release ko na siya eh so I don\u2019t know what\u2019s happening,\u201d Cayco said. \u201cThat paper was Alyssa\u2019s letter to LVPI asking that she may be permitted to play so sinagot ko, after two days may sagot na ako doon, naka-CC, copy furnish si Alyssa. Siguradong maga-grant (ang request), ang sa akin lang na-late lang kasi sila tapos sasabihin bakit hindi pina-process.\u201d \n \nValdez trained for two weeks with the team but failed to send Cayco a copy of her contract and passport \u2013 the required documents needed by FIVB to process the ITC. \n \nLVPI received a copy of the contract just last Friday. \n \n\u201cI have (now) the records with me. I have been asking Alyssa to email me kasi she left na rin \u2018di ba? Before she left, she visited me here on Saturday, so I told her, Alyssa here\u2019s my email add send me a copy of your passport and your contract,\u201d Cayco said. \u201cBut it did not come, kinulit ko na lang siya, sabi ko please send me (the documents).\u201d \n \nCayco said that he sought the help of LVPI secretary general Ricky Palou to contact Valdez for the required documents but the former Ateneo de Manila athletics director told him that a contract in not necessary to acquire an ITC.    \n \n\u201cI asked Mr. Palou to help me get in touch with Alyssa so they sent me a copy of the passport. So ang hinihingi ng FIVB is the copy of the passport and the copy of the contract and he (Palou) told me they (FIVB) don\u2019t need the copy of the contract. I told him that\u2019s what they\u2019 re asking so I might as well give it kasi I cannot tell them naman na, \u2018huwag na \u2018yan\u2019,\u201d he said. \u201cSo finally, I went direct to her club, I wrote them I think twice or thrice. Friday noon they sent me a copy of the contract signed by Alyssa Valdez so now I have with me a copy of her contract and a copy of her passport and yesterday (Saturday) I sent it immediately na to FIVB. Ang problema, Friday (nagsend ng contract) I just hope na process na nila. Roth says the proposed comprehensive plan can influence retail development in the city. \n   \n\u201cThroughout the process it was pretty clear that people want to see more commercial (retail) development,\u201d he said. \u201cThe comprehensive plan can influence developers.\u201d \n   \nRoth made the comments Tuesday, Jan. 24, at a special planning and zoning commission meeting to complete a final edit of the proposed comprehensive plan. He identified elements of the plan that he said could positively impact future retail development. \n   \nCreating a mixed-use zoning district where both commercial and residential uses could be applied to one parcel would signal that the city is seeking retail development, he said. \n   \nRoth pointed to the vacant property at the junction of Lamar Parkway and Old Gray Summit as a candidate for mixed-use zoning. \n   \nThe property is now zoned residential, but Roth said the commission can designate future land use and identify the area as right for commercial development. \n   \n\u201cIt would still be zoned residential, but developers would see (on the future land use map) that the city wants commercial there,\u201d Roth said. \n   \nCommission member Linda Bruns pointed out that a developer had previously proposed constructing a mixed-use development with retail at the front and residences at the back on a nearby parcel, but neighbors opposed it. \n   \n\u201cThis room was full of people who didn\u2019t want retail there,\u201d she said. \n   \nRoth said he thought the desire for more retail development might influence residences on future commercial ventures at that location. \n   \nAlderman Nick Chlebowski, who has been editing the plan, said there are other areas in the city where mixed-use zoning districts might be attractive to developers. \n   \nMixed-use was originally put forth as a zoning tool to lure developers to the old downtown section, where mixed-use already exists in storefronts that have businesses on the ground floor and residences on the second floor. \n   \nChlebowski displayed a future land use map, which identified different areas of the city with different colors. He said he would not consider the area south of the tracks to be part of the downtown area. \n   \nChlebowski said the property south of Orleans Street between South First Street and the Meramec River could be designated a mixed-use district. \n   \nAlthough the property is zoned residential, he said it would be a good candidate for mixed-use zoning with parks as one of the approved elements in mixed-use districts. \n   \nSeeing the area, which is prone to flooding, designated as a future park would help with Alderman Steve Myers\u2019 plan to create a Meramec River Access and establish Pacific as a trailhead. \n   \nBruns said she likes the idea, which reminded her of the Downtown Washington riverfront, where a hiking/biking trail allows public access. \n   \nThe area now contains a mix of residences and vacant lots that were impacted by floods in 2008 and 2015. \n   \nP&Z members reviewed the final two sections of the proposed comprehensive plan at the meeting and said they are very close to bringing the completed version to a vote for adoption. \n   \nRoth said it\u2019s extremely important for the future development of the city for staff and P&Z to have a comprehensive plan as a tool to aid in development review. \n   \n\u201cWe\u2019re seeing a lot of activity of people who want to locate here,\u201d he said. \u201cWe expect to be very busy for the immediate future.
