RECREATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"TOURNAMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"}],"wordCount":"1356","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395792177&p=2kx&v=1&x=IcsACsJR3M8AzmiIPXMlVg","id":"29395792177","content":"IROQUOIS FALLS -   \nWayne Mathieu\u2019s second goal of the game and 20th of the season with 20 seconds remaining in the first overtime period lifted the Timmins Rock to a 5-4 win over the Eskis Saturday night at the Jus Jordan Arena. \n \nIt was the second-straight extra-time 5-4 victory for the Rock who dispatched the Blind River Beavers by the same score with less than a second remaining in double overtime Friday night. \n \nSaturday night, Mathieu broke in two-on-one with linemate Jordan Rendle, but when the Eskis defender opted to stay in the middle to take the pass away, he stepped into a slap shot that beat Eskis goalie Artem Bortovskiy cleanly for the game-winning goal. \n \n\u201cThey kind of fumbled the puck in the neutral zone and I picked it up,\u201d Mathieu said. \n \n\u201cRendle and I had a two-on-one and I decided to shoot. I just tried to put everything I had into it and it seemed to work.\u201d \n \nBortovskiy and Rock netminder Jeff Veitch were both outstanding in the overtime frame, as the two teams abandoned defence in favour of fire-wagon hockey. \n \nThe line of Mathieu, Rendle and Cory Sprague accounted for four of the Rock\u2019s five goals Saturday night. \n \n\u201cWe played a good team game and we found a way to put the puck in the net tonight,\u201d Mathieu said. \n \n\u201cThe boys are really fired up and focused right now. We are playing every game like it is a playoff game right now.\u201d \n \nThe Rock jumped out to a 1-0 lead in the first period Saturday night, as Mathieu potted his 19th goal of the season at the 7:11 mark. \n \nThat\u2019s the way the opening 20 minutes ended, but the Eskis came out flying in the second period to tie things up and then take a 2-1 lead with a pair of goals seven seconds apart. \n \nRyan Forsythe\u2019s third goal of the season dead-locked the score and then Samuel Vigneux put the home side in front when he scored his fourth goal of the season. \n \nThe Rock battled back to tie things up at 2-2 six minutes later when Rendle scored his 24th goal of the season. \n \nTimmins had an excellent opportunity to retake the lead with 4:30 remaining in the middle frame, as forward Cory Sprague was hauled down on a breakaway and awarded a penalty shot. \n \nBortovskiy was up to the challenge, however, and made a right-pad save to keep the score tied. \n \nHis team rewarded him by taking the lead with just 1:01 remaining in the second period, as Alex Mitsionis scored his 13th goal of the season to send the Eskis to the dressing room for the second intermission up 3-2. \n \nThe Rock got back on even terms midway through the third period, as Dean Kiriacou scored his third goal of the season. \n \nDillan Bruce gave Eskis fans hope that they might witness their first win over the Rock this season with 4:12 remaining in the contest when he scored his 23rd goal of the season. \n \nIt would not stand up, however, as the Rock were able to get the puck past Bortovskiy with 2:28 remaining on the clock off a wild scramble in front the Eskis\u2019 net that saw Sprague credited with his 19th goal of the season. \n \nThat set the stage for Mathieu\u2019s overtime heroics. \n \nRock coach and general manager Paul Gagne acknowledged Saturday night\u2019s contest was almost as exciting as Friday night\u2019s last-second victory. \n \n\u201cIt was entertaining,\u201d he said. \n \n\u201cThe fans saw a pretty good hockey game. It was another nail-biter. It was almost like pond hockey, with us playing four-on-four like that. \n \n\u201cOur strategy was that we didn\u2019t come here for one point. We were going for it and our D were jumping up into the play. We knew we had the one point, so we were going for that second point. That\u2019s why the play was so open.\u201d \n \nThat second point allowed the Rock (27-11-3-0) to pull within six points of the idle Cochrane Crunch (29-11-4-1) for second place in the NOJHL\u2019s East Division standings, and the Rock still have four games in hand on their rivals. \n \n\u201cIt was very important for us to get that second point,\u201d Gagne said. \n \n\u201cWe want to finish in second place. We want home-ice advantage in the playoffs. That\u2019s our motivation right now. If we keep playing the way we are right now, with everybody on the same page, we can do it.\u201d \n \nDespite picking up a single point, the Eskis (15-25-3-0) fell another point behind the fourth-place Kirkland Lake Gold Miners (20-20-4-2). The gap between the likely Division Qualifier opponents now stands at 13 points, although the Eskis do have three games in hand. \n \nGagne was impressed with a number of Rock players Saturday night. \n \n\u201cRendle put in a good effort, as he always does,\u201d he said. \n \n\u201cHe had his mojo tonight. You could tell he was really involved. \n \n\u201cAnd Kiriacou is really coming along. We are happy with his progress. He is starting to be a little bit more comfortable in the program and he is starting to move the puck a little bit more. \n \n\u201cMathieu, obviously, is on a roll right now. He is playing really well. \n \n\u201cOn defence, we were struggling a little bit, but we started moving the puck a little bit more. When we don\u2019t move the puck well, we tend to get into trouble. Progressively, we started to move it better as the game went on. \n \n\u201cAnd our goalie (Veitch) might like to have the fourth goal back, but that was a goal scorer\u2019s shot. You have to give credit to the shooter. He made some big saves in overtime, but he did the same thing last night. \n \n\u201cWhat I like about Veitch is that he has been working really hard in practice. We got two victories this weekend and he faced a lot of shots and he made some big saves to keep us in both games.\u201d \n \nEskis coach and assistant general manager Jamy Bernier knows his team came close to finally knocking off the Rock Saturday night. \n \n\u201cWe had a lot of chances,\u201d he said. \n \n\u201cWe just didn\u2019t find the back of the net early enough in overtime. Bortovskiy came up with some huge saves on multiple occasions, but unfortunately we ended up on the wrong side of a bounce once again. \n \n\u201cI think this is our third overtime loss since the Christmas break. We are just going to have to find a way to put ourselves ahead. Our guys are not complacent with what we picked up here tonight. They really show resilience and I believe in that group we are putting out there. \n \n\u201cThere are some small hiccups, some small misplays that are costing us goals, but we are seeing a lot of good things here. We are headed in the right direction.\u201d \n \nDespite the overtime loss, Bernier was pleased with the effort put forth by a number of Eskis Saturday night. \n \n\u201cOur fourth line, with Sam Vigneux, Ryan Forsythe and Cam Boutin, was absolutely phenomenal,\u201d he said. \n \n\u201cThey gave us two goals tonight on the same shift and every other shift they were out there, they were making something happen. They were really giving the opposition a hard time.\u201d \n \nVeitch turned aside 33 of the 37 shots he faced to earn the victory for the Rock. \n \nBortovskiy blocked 43 of the 48 shots the Rock fired his way and was tagged with the overtime loss. \n \nNOJHL NOTES \u2014 The Rock did not dress goalie Albert Rogers (upper-body), defencemen Brandon Campbell (serving the second game of a two-game suspension picked up on Jan. 21 in Powassan) and Spencer Segui (upper-body), as well as forward Tyler Romain (undisclosed). In addition, the Rock lost forward Maxime Lague during the contest, as he continues to battle a flu bug ... The three stars of the game were Mathieu, Rendle and Bortovskiy ... The Rock went 0-4 on the power play, while the Eskis were also 0-4 with the man advantage ... Official attendance at the Jus Jordan Arena was 345 ... Saturday night\u2019s other action saw the Gold Miners thump the Rapids 12-1 in French River and the Eagles triple the Rayside-Balfour Canadians 6-2 in Sault, Mich. ... The Rock will return to action Thursday night when they host the Gold Miners at the McIntyre Arena. ","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Rock edge Eskis in OT","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","zipCode":"P4N","state":"Ontario","countryCode":"CA","zipArea":"Timmins Southeast","country":"Canada"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Timmins Daily Press","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169707372","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"120"},"name":"Timmins Daily Press","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Consumer","Sports"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.timminspress.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194867928","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:53Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

is that time of year when you may be looking to make a change in your career, particularly if you don\u2019t find your current job fulfilling or rewarding. \n \nMuriel Weisz. \n It may be you feel you are not making a difference to other people\u2019s lives or you dislike an office environment. \nIf this is the case and you have a caring nature, perhaps a career in homecare is for you. \n\nNottinghamshire County Council is working with our homecare providers to fill homecare vacancies that exist across the county. \n\nIn the Newark area there are currently around 20 vacancies. \n\nHomecare is a growing area of work as more people are living longer with complex needs and they require support to remain independent in their homes. \n\nThe shortage of homecare workers is a national issue and it is estimated an extra 750,000 will be needed by 2025 to meet growing demand. \n\nI had the pleasure of seeing a local homecare worker in action before Christmas and I was heartened by the friendship she had formed with one of the older people who she supported. \n\nShe said she gained a lot of job satisfaction from knowing she is helping vulnerable people to remain as independent as possible. \n\nFurthermore, she had recently progressed to team leader, which included a salary increase and more responsibility. \n\nThis goes to show there are plenty of opportunities for development if new recruits want a varied career. \n\nObviously, personal care is big part of the job but there are often other tasks that are needed, including taking service users out to cafés and social events to reduce isolation, or buying shopping if their service user is unable to leave their home. \n\nWe have signed UNISON\u2019s ethical care charter that reaffirms our commitment to giving support to the county\u2019s homecare workers as we greatly value the work they carry out. \n\nWhile homecare work has had a bad press in recent years, we are committed to ensuring our homecare workers are paid for their travel time between visits, reimbursed for their work travel costs, and have enough time to talk to clients and provide the care that is needed. \n\nPeople interested in finding out more should visit the council\u2019s website . \n\nMuriel Weisz is the chairman of Nottinghamshire County Council's adult social care and health He knew I had done the portrait and was pleased with it.\u201d \n\nThe original now hangs on the wall above one of his favourite armchairs in his home. \n\nPrints have been sold in aid of the International Bomber Command Centre at Canwick Hill, Lincoln. \n\nOne of the prints, signed for Rosie by Mr Johnson, has a special place in her studio in Lincoln. \n\nMr Johnson, who grew up in Collingham and was a teacher at Highfields School, Newark, after the second world war, lives near Bristol. \n'He is inspirational'  \nThe only surviving British airman who took part in the 1943 Dambusters raid, he received the Distinguished Flying Medal for his part in it. \n\nA petition spearheaded by television personality Carol Vorderman, calling for Mr Johnson to be honoured with a knighthood, has been supported by more than 200,000 people. \n\nHe previously told the Advertiser he would accept the honour if he could dedicate it to his Dambuster comrades and the other men of Bomber Command. \n\nRosie said a knighthood would be a fitting honour to acknowledge the bravery of the airmen and the fundraising that Mr Johnson has since been involved in. \n\n\u201cHe is inspirational and needs to be recognised,\u201d she said.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Newark Advertiser - stage in the Burlington-Edison High School auditorium \u2014 jumping, dancing and emoting his way to laughs from the audience. \n\nBut most of the time, Wann was silent. \n\nThough Wann can hear and speak, his first language \u2014 and the language in which he performs \u2014 is American Sign Language. \n\n\"I say English is my second language, even though I'm a hearing person,\" said Wann, who is the son of two deaf parents. \"That's my goal is to bring these two worlds together.\" \n\nWann, a California native now living in Brooklyn, was brought to Burlington-Edison by the school's Happy Hands ASL Club. \n\n\"He's like the Kevin Hart of the deaf world,\" said Happy Hands Club member Abbey Maroney, a sophomore. \"He's really famous.\" \n\nSome of Wann's jokes \u2014 like unplugging the vacuum while his mother was using it to see how long it would take her to notice \u2014 resonate more with the deaf community than with the hearing community, he said. \n\nBy drawing from his own experiences, he is able to give the speaking and hearing ASL students a glimpse of life as a deaf or hard-of-hearing person, reported the Skagit Valley Herald (http://bit.ly/2kknpM1). \n\n\"It's a great way to share culture,\" he said. \n\nEarlier in the day, Wann spoke with ASL students, who were thrilled to have him around. \n\n\"(Having Wann is) such a big deal for our school and our club,\" junior Jayla Dunn said. \n\n\"And also our town,\" junior Jenica Medina chimed in. \n\nWhile Burlington-Edison High School has no deaf students, Dunn said she became interested in learning sign language to be able to communicate with more people. \n\n\"I was really excited to be able to make conversation with such a diverse population,\" she said. \"You can always have them lip read, but it's such a deeper connection when you speak the same language. \n\nFor Wann, the students' excitement is a sign of change. He remembers the stigma his parents faced while he was growing up. \n\n\"Now it's cool,\" he said. \"If I was a teenager now, I'd get a lot more dates than I did in the '80s.\" \n\nDuring his 20 years as a performer, Wann's parents have remained an inspiration for his comedy show, he said. \n\n\"I feel like I want to sign in case my parents ever came to a show,\" he said. \n\nWhile his wife has served as his speaking interpreter for his comedy shows, Wann said he also often has local people \u2014 such as Happy Hands adviser Liza Bancroft \u2014 interpret sign language into speech. \n\n\"He's so well-respected and well-known in the deaf community,\" Bancroft said. \"So it's a real unique opportunity.\" \n\nOpportunity awaits the students continuing their ASL education as well, Wann said. \n\n\"You are learning our language,\" Wann signed during his show. \"You have two choices: You can use that language to help deaf people ... or you can use it to hurt them. I know you guys want to use it to help. Really, I hope some of you become interpreters, or maybe lawyers. Or maybe you'll work at McDonald's.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"KERA WANIELISTASkagit Valley Herald"},"topics":[{"name":"Entertainment: latest","group":"Entertainment"},{"name":"Entertainment: celebrity gossip","group":"Entertainment"}],"title":"Comedian brings American Sign Language to the stage","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Miami-Dade","zipCode":"33172","state":"Florida","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Miami","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"2","name":"Miami Herald","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169657045","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"833"},"name":"Miami Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Gossip","Lifestyle","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.miamiherald.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://bit.ly/2kknpM1"],"sequenceId":"695194869750","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:06:05Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:53Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:00:05Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395792462","companies":[{"symbol":"3071","primary":true,"name":"Stream Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3399760002"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"STREAMING MEDIA","domains":["IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"PRICE INCREASES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"60"},{"name":"IMPORT TRADE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"63"},{"name":"IMPORT PRICES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"COMPANY PROFITS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"65"},{"name":"NATURAL GAS PRODUCTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"GASOLINE PRICES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"EUROPEAN UNION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"OIL & GAS EXPORTS & IMPORTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"DEVELOPMENT BANKS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"71"},{"name":"PRICES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"PIPELINE TRANSPORTATION","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"OIL & GAS PRICES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"CYPRUS","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"BRUSSELS, BELGIUM; BELGIUM","domains":["GEO"],"score":"57"},{"name":"GREECE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"88"},{"name":"EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"BELGIUM","domains":["GEO"],"score":"72"},{"name":"ITALY","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"}],"wordCount":"517","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395792462&p=2kx&v=1&x=W4tnjERpwEE0MHsNZSt59g","id":"29395792462","content":"By Fiona Mullen \n \nThe Cyprus News Agency (CNA) reported this week that the cost of the EastMed pipeline from Israel to Cyprus, Crete, the Peloponnese in Greece and then Italy would be $6bn. This is close to the $5.7bn figure cited by Globes a few months ago. \n \nCNA also said that a study presented in Brussels had found the pipeline to be commercially viable and technically feasible. \nSubscribers to my monthly report will have already know that I suspect the reported figure is not counting the full cost. \n \nThe entire pipeline including the land pipeline in Greece would be 1,900 km. It will also be very deep, reaching 3,000 metres in some parts. \n \nA figure of $6bn implies a pipeline cost of just $3.2 per km. To illustrate why this is too low,we can compare this with the Nord Stream pipeline. Completed in 2012, Nord Stream is 1,224 km long and only 210 deep\u2014shorter and much shallower than the proposed EastMed pipeline. \n \nNord Stream\u2019s website says that the total investment cost was $7.2bn. Of this total, $5bn was spent on pipes, pipe materials and pipe-laying. A total investment of $7.2bn implies a cost of just under $6 per km. \n \nIf we only count the $5bn investment in pipeline construction, Nord Stream comes to a cost of $4.1 per km. Either way, the NordStream cost was much higher than the amount implied in the estimate for the EastMed pipeline, which would be one of the longest, deepest pipelines in the world. \n \nI suspect that the $6bn estimate does not include the land pipeline in Greece. Remove this and the cost comes in at $4.6 per km. This is a little higher than Nord Stream, but makes sense given that it is much deeper. \n \nIt would be good if I could confirm my hunch. The studies made to date have been paid for by the EU taxpayer, because the EastMed pipeline is an EU \u2018Project of Common Interest\u2019, meaning that it can attract EU funding for studies into its viability. \n \nHowever, when I contacted the Commission to enquire whether the report would be made available, they said it was up to the companies to provide any information. \n \n  \n \nThe price must be right \n \nEven if you take the $6bn at face value and assume that new technology or weak oil prices have led to a massive reduction in costs, there is still the question of what price the sellers need in order to make a profit. \n \nAccording to my Sapienta Economics gas model, you would need a gas price of around $7 per million British thermal units (mmbtu) before you started to make a profit. \n \nEuropean gas import prices have been rising lately, reaching $5.50/mmbtu at the end of December according to World Bank data. However, with a global glut in gas, it will take a while before they stay above $7/mmbtu. \n \nWe can wait that long, or we can solve the Cyprus problem. A shorter pipeline to Turkey would be viable at a price of just above $4/mmbtu according to my model. \n \nThe writer is Director of Sapienta Economics and author of the monthly Sapienta Country Analysis Cyprus www.sapientaeconomics.com","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Energy industry news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Oil and gas news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Cyprus news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Greece news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Europe news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Is the EastMed gas pipeline an option for Cyprus?","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Western Asia","countryCode":"CY","country":"Cyprus"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"The Cyprus Weekly","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"245348327","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"The Cyprus Weekly","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.incyprus.com.cy"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://sapientaeconomics.com/country-analysis-cyprus/"],"sequenceId":"695194871978","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:00:05Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:56Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

These are priced between Rs 8.78 lakh and Rs 10.63 lakh (ex-showroom Delhi). \nWhen contacted a MSI spokesperson told PTI: \u201cIn this segment (1.6 litre engine), customers go for highest trim that has all the features. Therefore, it is business prudence to keep the number of variants at an optimum level in line with customers requirements.\u201d \nThe model\u2019s performance is in line with the company\u2019s expectation, the spokesperson added. \n\u201cWe started a new segment called premium crossover with S Cross. Volume-wise, S-Cross continues to do an average of 2,000-2,100 units monthly,\u201d the spokesperson said. \nS-Cross, the first model from the stable of MSI to be sold through its premium retail chain NEXA, has had a chequered history. \nMSI had introduced the S-Cross in two options of 1.6 litre and 1.3 litre engines in 2015 coinciding with the launch of its premium retail outlet chain Nexa. However, pricing issues hindered sales of the vehicle forcing the company to go for price correction. \nLast year, the company had cut price of the vehicle by over Rs 2 lakh. The reduction in the price of 1.6 litre variant was Rs 2,05,000 for all the three trims, while that of 1.3 litre variant ranged from Rs 40,000 to Rs 66,000. \nS-Cross along with Vitara Brezza have helped the company enhance its market share in the utility vehicle (UV) segment. \nWhile Vitara Brezza has been a runaway hit, S-Cross has been a slow starter for the company. \nAcknowledging the fact, the spokesperson said: \u201cEvery brand has a specific role in the overall portfolio. While some are mass models that sell in big numbers, others may not sell as much as a mass model but contribute to the overall brand objectives of the company for the medium and long term\u201d. \nS-Cross helps Maruti Suzuki in expanding its range and presence with an eye on the future, the spokesperson added. \nGrowth in the UV segment for MSI is over 120 per cent for the April-December period this fiscal. Volume wise the company has sold 1,43,254 units during the April-December period as compared to 63,924 units in the previous fiscal. \nThe company now commands over 65 per cent market share in the total UV segment. These are things human beings have been fighting for since we have gained consciousness, freedom and equality,\u201d Hrithik said. \n\u201cMy father is talking about the progress of the industry, producers and for people, who can\u2019t watch two films in a week on big screen with family as it costs money. So, it is better for everyone that these (big) kind of clashes don\u2019t happen.\u201d \nBoth SRK and Hrithik\u2019s films have been received well at the box office but the actor feels two big budget releases create unpredictability. \n\u201cThere was lot of uncertainty this time because of the clash. If it was a solo film, we would have been on predictable note but because of the clash there was uncertainty,\u201d he says. \n\u201cBut now the uncertainty is turning into certainty with all the feedback and love that we are getting. It comes to down to the same thing \u2013 if the film and content is good it works, you get rewards no matter what,\u201d he adds. \nThe 43-year-old actor, however, insists there is nothing much an actor can do in this as these are trade decisions. \n\u201cIt is not for me to say. I have nothing to do with it. I am an actor and my focus was to better my work. Everything else is a story. If someone tells me anything about this person or that person its a story for me. I don\u2019t get affected by it,\u201d he says when asked if the clash between \u201cKaabil\u201d and \u201cRaees\u201d should have been averted. \nDespite losing out on business, releasing two big films at the same time is not new to Bollywood, it has happened in the past and it might continue as well this year. \nLast year Hrithik\u2019s \u201cMohenjo Daro\u201d released along side Akshay Kumar starrer \u201cRustom\u201d and the latter came out as a winner of box office tussle. \nAsk Hrithik if he would now try to avoid clash of his films with others, he says, \u201cThis is not in my hands alone, it is in the hands of executives. There is a rule that if we clash then we straight away divide it 50:50 (referring to screen space).\u201d \n\u201cSo, there is no 80:20 or 60:40 and if you follow 50:50 then the clash will stop automatically. That\u2019s the best way,\u201d he says. (Photo: Mike Carter / USA TODAY Sports) \n  \n\u2022What: MSU vs. Michigan \n \n\u2022When: 1 p.m. today \n \n\u2022Where: Breslin Center, East Lansing \n \n\u2022TV/Radio: CBS / Spartan Sports Network, including WJIM 1240-AM and WMMQ 94.9-FM. \n \n\u2022Records/Rankings: MSU is 12-9 overall, 4-4 in the Big Ten and unranked. Michigan is 14-7, 4-4 and also unranked. \n \n\u2022Coaches: MSU \u2014 Tom Izzo is 536-214 in his 22nd season, all with the Spartans. Michigan \u2014 John Beilein is 754-448 in 39 seasons, including 203-130 in 10 years with the Wolverines. \n \n\u2022Series: Michigan leads 97-80 all-time, though MSU is ahead 24-14 in the Izzo era. MSU has won the last four meetings. \n \nMichigan \n  \nPos. \n   \nName \n   \nPPG \n   \nF (13) \n   \nMoritz Wagner (6-11) \n   \n12.0 \n   \nF (5) \n   \nDJ Wilson (6-10) \n   \n10.7 \n   \nG (21) \n   \nZak Irvin (6-6) \n   \n14.4 \n   \nG (12) \n   \nM-A Abdur-Rahkman (6-4) \n   \n8.0 \n   \nG (10) \n   \nDerrick Walton (6-1) \n   \n13.0 \n  \nMSU \n  \nPos. \n   \nName \n   \nPPG \n   \nC (44) \n   \nNick Ward (6-8) \n   \n13.2 \n   \nF (22) \n   \nMiles Bridges (6-7) \n   \n16.4 \n   \nG (14) \n   \nEron Harris (6-3) \n   \n12.3 \n   \nG (1) \n   \nJoshua Langford (6-5) \n   \n6.1 \n   \nG (11) \n   \nTum Tum Nairn (5-10) \n   \n4.0 \n  \n\u2022 MSU update: The Spartans enter today\u2019s game in need of a win to keep their postseason trajectory on course. MSU, which has lost three straight, can\u2019t afford to drop home games to NCAA tournament bubble teams if it wants to avoid being on the bubble itself. The good news for MSU is it seems to have freshman Miles Bridges back at 100 percent and, in two of his last three games, playing as well as ever. Bridges is coming off a 33-point effort Tuesday against Purdue, which set an MSU freshman scoring mark. As MSU plays the school that produced the Fab Five, its own four-member freshman class is averaging an Izzo-era best 42.2 points and 18.7 rebounds. Spartans redshirt sophomore Kenny Goins will play with a protective mask \u2014 as he did much of last season \u2014 after breaking his nose against Purdue. \n \n\u2022 Michigan  update: The Wolverines are coming off a blistering offensive performance in a 90-60 home win over Indiana Thursday, which followed a one-sided home victory over Illinois last weekend. At 14-7 and 4-4 in the Big Ten, Michigan is creeping toward the NCAA tournament bubble. What the Wolverines lack is quality wins or road wins, though early season neutral site drubbings of Marquette and SMU are looking better by the hour. Beating MSU at Breslin would go a ways toward bringing the Wolverines into the NCAA tournament conversation seriously, if Thursday\u2019s win didn\u2019t already do that. Michigan is 0-5 this season in true road games. That\u2019ll have to change at some point if the Wolverines want to play in the Big Dance. Michigan\u2019s struggles are on defense and on the glass. The Wolverines are last in the Big Ten in field goal-percentage defense and 3-point defense and second to last in rebounding margin. \n \n\u2022 About the matchup: Michigan won\u2019t be able to punish MSU inside if the Spartans get in foul trouble. That\u2019s not what the Wolverines do, nor do they have the personnel to make MSU pay for its lack of depth of size. What Michigan can do is bury an opponent from beyond the arc. The Wolverines\u2019 9.3 3s per game are second in the Big Ten \u2014 behind Purdue and ahead of Indiana. Six different U-M players have 22 or more made 3-pointers on the season. MSU, while often statistically sound defending the perimeter, has regular lapses guarding shooters, especially off penetration. Michigan doesn\u2019t have the future NBA players in its backcourt it did when it was making deep NCAA tournament runs a few years ago. But the Wolverines have a ton of experience in this rivalry, including two senior starters (Derrick Walton and Zak Irvin) who were on the team that won at Breslin in 2014. Three of MSU\u2019s starters have never played in this matchup before today. \n \n\u2022 Prediction: There has been little carryover from game to game for most teams in the Big Ten this season, MSU and Michigan included. If the Wolverines hit 63 percent of their shots and 55 percent of their 3s and only turn the ball over six times, as they did against Indiana, then the Spartans are in trouble. Of course, Indiana\u2019s disorganized and sometimes disinterested defense contributed to those numbers. Minus the final few minutes of the first half and a few in the second Tuesday, MSU played its most complete game of the season in its loss to Purdue. That effort might get it done against Michigan. The only reliable predictive variables today are that Breslin Center will be rocking and both teams will be dialed in. Home court in this rivalry can mean a ton. \n \n» Make it: MSU 81, Michigan 77 \n \n\u2014 Graham Couch","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: US college sports news","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Tipoff: Michigan State vs. Michigan","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Isabella","zipCode":"48858","state":"Michigan","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Mount Pleasant","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Lansing State Journal","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169663314","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2303"},"name":"Lansing State Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.lansingstatejournal.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194879892","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:56Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

GERMANY","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"EUROPE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"NEW DELHI, INDIA; INDIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"MANMOHAN SINGH","domains":["PEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"ELIZABETH II, QUEEN OF THE UNITED KINGDOM","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"THERESA MAY","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"BORIS JOHNSON","domains":["PEO"],"score":"55"},{"name":"NARENDRA MODI","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"PATRICIA SCOTLAND","domains":["PEO"],"score":"76"}],"wordCount":"638","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395792489&p=2kx&v=1&x=xzAKrjqSqmM06dgj1AMBnA","id":"29395792489","content":"It apears, Britain would prefer a visit by Indian PM Narendra Modi next year. A key official at the Foreign Office in Whitehall put it politely, saying, \u201cMr Modi would be welcome if he came this year, but our choice, if it comes to it, would be next year.\u201d \nSouth Block has been enquiring about options. A senior Indian diplomat ran the idea of a sojourn this summer past the British Foreign Secretary, Boris Johnson, during his recent visit to New Delhi. A trip this year would be scheduled immediately before or after the G20 summit in Hamburg on July 7-8. In 2018 it would be a bilateral component leading up to or in the aftermath of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) in the UK. \n\n(Follow  The Tribune on Facebook ; and  Twitter @thetribunechd )   \n\nBritain\u2019s preference for next year is understandable. Prime Minister Theresa May was in Delhi less than three months ago. It would be too early to review the progress of decisions taken. If any pressing new issues arise in the interim, she and Modi can discuss these on the sidelines of the multilateral meeting in Germany. \n\nBesides, CHOGM would involve British Head of State Queen Elizabeth II, which is very important to Britain. The Commonwealth is dear to her heart. Indeed, it could well be the last time she presides over the 52-nation organisation\u2019s biennial conference. At 90, she is unlikely to travel too far for such events in future. \n\nFormer PM Manmohan Singh and Modi both have skipped recent CHOGMs. An emerging India - in the eyes of Britain \u2013 is quite central to the future of the Commonwealth. \n\nThe Commonwealth is badly in need of a shot in the arm. After Brexit, Britain is desperately seeking enhanced trade with its former colonies to compensate for a possible downturn in exports to and imports from Europe, if compelled to quit the European Common Market. \n\nBut the Commonwealth is in crisis. The British Department of International Development (DfID) has threatened to withdraw its funding unless it improved its performance.  \n\n\u201cThe Commonwealth Secretariat continues to under-perform,\" a report asserted. The secretariat claimed the review  \n\npertained to the period before Baroness Patricia Scotland became secretary-general last April. \n\nIndia is a major contributor to the Commonwealth. A senior diplomat at the Indian High Commission in London is said to have told Scotland she needs to stop bad-mouthing her Indian predecessor, Kamlesh Sharma, if she wants India\u2019s co-operation. The morale at the Commonwealth Secretariat is reportedly low. The BBC quoted senior diplomatic and political sources as alleging \u201cpoor leadership\u201d on the part of Scotland.  \n\nIt further reported: \u201cShe has been accused of financial extravagance over the refurbishment of her official residence.\" Scotland has denied the charges. However, with a meeting  \n\nof Commonwealth trade ministers on the anvil in March, the British Government is jittery. \n\nA former British Ambassador to Japan reporting directly to May has been put in charge of a team preparing for next year's CHOGM while a retired Foreign Office diplomat has been made acting chief operating officer at the secretariat. The interventions are pre-emptive moves by London to arrest the inefficiency.  \n\nMost unusual, the British Queen has expressed her inability to attend the annual Commonwealth Day reception in March. She will be represented at the reception by the Prince of Wales. \n\nThe Indian Prime Minister has been advised visits to Britain this year and next would be an overkill.  \n\nSo, does he come this summer to keep his exuberant overseas Gujarati constituency contented? Or does he visit next year to attend CHOGM? \n\nThere has over the years developed a natural closeness between the UK and India. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:58Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395375060","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"HISTORY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"COINS & COINAGE","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"91"},{"name":"BRITISH MONARCHS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ANCIENT HISTORY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"MUSEUMS & GALLERIES","domains":["IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"ENGLAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"OXFORD, ENGLAND; ENGLAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"77"}],"wordCount":"408","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395792688&p=2kx&v=1&x=D-3TzBOsvlMUk6r-ZhIrTw","id":"29395792688","content":"Historians say an entire chapter of the Anglo-Saxon period will have to be re-written after a metal detectorist found a huge hoard of coins in a field. \n \nJames Mather made the discovery of 200 complete silver coins, seven items of jewellery and 15 silver ingots in a field near Watlington in Oxfordshire in October 2015. Its full significance has now become apparent. \n \nThe find contained a mixture of extremely rare Anglo-Saxon coins and Viking silver, which provides a clearer understanding of the relationship between Alfred the Great, who ruled Wessex and his less well-known contemporary Ceolwulf II of Mercia. \n \nSome of the coins were minted with a 'Two Emperors' design, borrowed from the Romans, which shows that the currency was used in both ancient kingdoms. \n \n\"This is an extraordinary find, one which re-writes Anglo-Saxon history,\" Xa Sturgis, director of the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, which now houses the coins, told Sky News. \n \n\"The keeper of the coin room here came running up the stairs to tell me. The more they were excavated the more it became obvious how significant they are. These coins point to some sort of an alliance in the 870s between Alfred and Ceolwulf.\" \n \nWhile Alfred is often described as the king who founded England, uniting Mercia and Wessex, very little is known of his rival Ceolwulf. \n \n\"These coins prove that there was a very real alliance between the two men at that time,\" added Julian Baker, coin curator at the Ashmolean. \n \n\"That alliance hasn't survived in the historical record until now. Alfred manipulated history to put himself in a better light. To date, history has overemphasised Alfred's record and almost completely neglected Ceolwulf. \n \n\"We can start re-writing that decade now, courtesy of the Watlington hoard.\" \n \nThe Ashmolean has until Monday, 31 January, to raise £1.35m to keep the coins and Viking silver in Oxfordshire and they are extremely close to that figure now. \n \nMore than 500 people in the local area have donated to the fund set up to raise the cash. \n \nMr Sturgis added: \"Alfred is the only king in the history of England described as 'great'. But these coins show that in the 870s he needed Ceolwulf. It's incredible that we know so little about him and Alfred dominates everything. It's like he obliterated Ceolwulf.\" \n \nThe Watlington Hoard, as it is now known, is on public display at the Ashmolean as historians begin the process of re-assessing that period of Anglo-Saxon history. \n  \n© 2017 Sky News, all rights reserved","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"Coins discovery 'will re-write' Anglo-Saxon history","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Europe","subregion":"Northern Europe","county":"Greater London","zipCode":"W1W","state":"England","countryCode":"GB","zipArea":"Westminster","country":"United Kingdom"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Kiss FM UK","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"344892384","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"32"},"name":"Kiss FM UK","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.kissfmuk.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194884295","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:18:58Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

INDONESIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"88"},{"name":"JOKO WIDODO","domains":["PEO"],"score":"58"}],"wordCount":"415","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395793039&p=2kx&v=1&x=7sa2C2F0o1FbSUYrf52y3Q","id":"29395793039","content":"Private companies will be involved in the project, which will also train convicted felons to raise cattle \n \nJAKARTA \u2014 The Indonesian government is planning to develop Nusakambangan, the notorious prison island that houses some of the country\u2019s most fearsome criminals, into a cattle farm next year. \n \nPrivate companies will be involved in the project, which will also train convicted felons to raise cattle. \n \nThe government said it will be part of a larger national beef-sufficiency program. \n \nThe director general of penitentiaries at the Ministry of Justice and Human Rights, I Wayan K Dusak, launched the programme earlier this week. \n \nOver the next 12 months, the government will start the bidding process for companies interested in the project. \n \n\u201cThe government will provide the workers for the farm,\u201d Mr Dusak said, referring to the prisoners. \n \n\u201cThey will be trained in good farming practices and hopefully they would bring their new skills home when they are released and become farmers themselves,\u201d he added. \n \nNusakambangan is a 24,000-hectare island in the Indian Ocean just south of Cilacap in Central Java. The Justice Ministry owns the island and operates four prisons within its vicinity. Only prisoners, prison officers and their families live on the island. \n \nPrison authorities plan to set aside 20 hectares of land on the island for the cattle farm, Mr Dusak said. He said the project will start by raising 14,000 cattle next year. \n \nLast year, a cattle pen was built on a 2-hectare plot on Nusakambangan. It has received 30 heads of cattle for free from a corporate social responsibility programme run by state-controlled Bank Negara Indonesia this year and another 150 heads of cattle bought with money from the state budget. \n \nThis programme involves 100 prisoners as its caretakers. \n \nThe Justice Ministry said there are 150,000 hectares of prison land across the country that can be developed for various industries, including cattle farming. \n \nIndonesians have been consuming more beef as they become wealthier, but today local beef production can only supply 60 per cent of the total demand. \n \nThis year alone Indonesia will need 3.3 million cattle for slaughter, according to an estimation from the Ministry of Agriculture. \n \nThe government\u2019s ban on beef import under a self-sufficiency programme backfired a few years ago as it created a massive beef shortage in the market and forced farmers to slaughter breeding cows to meet demand. \n \nPresident Joko Widodo has set a new target of beef self-sufficiency by 2026. Meanwhile, the government plans to bring in more breeding cows from abroad to replenish the domestic population. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:07Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395768587","companies":[{"symbol":"3245","primary":true,"name":"Dear Life Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3548720006"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"STADIUMS & ARENAS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"OAKLAND, CA, USA; UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"LOS ANGELES, CA, USA; UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1110","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395792905&p=2kx&v=1&x=JuT4H1X9nvSCokEBpeD9pw","id":"29395792905","content":"OAKLAND \u2014 Stephen Curry, a man of many rituals and low-key analyst, wished had an explanation. He would love to have a secret to keep close to the vest, or a process he could explain. \n \nBut after another third quarter explosion \u2014 25 points as the Warriors wiped the Oracle Arena hardwood with the visiting Chris Paul-less Clippers 144-98 \u2014 Curry had no enlightened answer for his third-quarter turn-ups. \n \nIt was the 17th time in his career he scored at least 20 points in a quarter. Many of those are in the third quarter. Saturday, he made 8 of 11 from the field, including five 3-pointers, to go with six rebounds and three assists. He outscored the Clippers by himself as the Warriors turned a comfortable lead into a national embarrassment for Los Angeles. \n \nThe unique part about this latest big quarter: it was planned. \n \nUsually, Curry\u2019s barrages happen organically. They are about feel and rhythm, not strategy and situation. They tend to come out of nowhere, and only those who have experience playing with Curry can sense them coming, like that neighbor who can always feel the storm coming. \n \nSaturday, the Warriors ran a play for Curry to start the third quarter. They never do that. He prefers it that way, too, as he\u2019d rather get a few trips up and down the court before shooting. \n \nBut Curry had made his last two threes. He punctuated the first half with a 51-footer straight down the middle, drilling it at the buzzer as the crowd erupted. Then after airplaning in a circle, he was drilled by Draymond Green as the two leaped into each other. Curry ended up on the hardwood. \n \nSo Kerr looked to get Curry going in the third, coax an explosion. Kevin Durant brought the ball up, and after a couple passes, got it back in the post. Curry curled off a designed double screen and stuck a free throw line jumper. \n \n\u201cIt was just amazing to watch,\u201d Draymond Green said. \u201cLike you said, I\u2019ve seen him do some pretty incredible things. You can kind of see when he\u2019s going into one of those modes. I think it started with two shots, the half-court shot and then once he came out and he hit that first pull-up in the third quarter, you could kind of see it was about to be one of those type of nights.\u201d \n \nThe nation it knew it when, on a fast break, Curry pulled it from the E on the Oracle decal, about 30 feet from the rim. The next time down, he hoisted one in a blink from 28 feet. The next time down, with Durant looking to feed Curry exclusively, a back-door cut led to a reverse layup that left Durant shaking his head in disbelief. \n \nWhat is it about Curry and third quarters? What we do know: it isn\u2019t new. The trend began under coach Mark Jackson. He remembers that vividly. \n \n\u201cThe playoffs. Game 4,\u201d Curry said. \u201cThat was wild. It was my first playoffs. And I was hurt.\u201d \n \nHe is talking about the first round series against Denver. The Warriors were up 2-1 after stealing Game 2 in Denver and hanging on for dear life in Game 3. Their 12-point lead was down to four midway through the third quarter. Control of the series was slipping away. Then Curry, playing on a sprained left ankle, went off. \n \nHe shot a 3-pointer from the left corner and turned to look at the Nuggets bench while it was still in the air. Two minutes later, another 3 followed by a layup in traffic. The next eight points came at the expense of Andre Miller. A pull-up 3-pointer during a frenetic fast break left Oracle blown away. \n \nCurry had 22 points in that third quarter. The Warriors won by 14. He did it again in the third quarter of Game 6 as the Warriors clinched the first-round upset. He had 22 in the third quarter of Game 1 against the Spurs. A trend was born. \n \nHe had 28 in the third quarter in Charlotte last season, after honoring his father at halftime of Dell Curry Night. He had 26 of his 51 points in the quarter of a win at Dallas in February 2015. He had 28 in the third quarter at New Orleans on Halloween. \n \nUnder Steve Kerr, Curry does most of his damage in the third quarter (the first is not far behind). Since the beginning of last season, Curry is averaging 9.6 points in the third quarter. James Harden is second in the NBA during that span at 8.5. \n \nHe has made 283 3-pointers in the third quarter under Kerr, nearly a third of his total. \n \n\u201cYou know it\u2019s on when he hits one from deep,\u201d Andre Iguodala said. \u201cOnce those start dropping, it\u2019s over.\u201d \n \nThere are some unofficial explanations for Curry\u2019s third quarters. He looks to be more aggressive in the third quarter after looking to get others involved the first half. He wears opponents\u2019 down in the third quarter, a nod to his stamina as he gets stronger while defenses might fall off. His teammates look for him more in the third quarters as the defenses take away other options. \n \nAnother: Curry makes mental adjustments at the half. After getting a feel for how he\u2019s being defended, the counter punches come in the second half. \n \nNone of these make Curry say \u201cthat\u2019s it.\u201d He nodded at a couple, acknowledging that could be the reason some of the time. Others, he shook his head like it\u2019s not even factor. One last explanation got his attention. \n \nIs there something about the having the opportunity to put the opponent away? \n \n\u201cThat definitely has something to do with it,\u201d said Curry, who leads the NBA at plus-276 in the third quarter so far this season. \u201cA lot of times, it\u2019s in that space where we create some separation or if we let them back in it, now it\u2019s a close game.\u201d \n \nCurry feeds off moments. And when it calls for him to carry the load \u2014 whether because the team is struggling or the opponent is on the ropes \u2014 he gets more aggressive looking for his shot. Curry in attack mode is a problem for the defense because it must be on point to stay with him. Few defenses are good enough to maintain and eventually, he gets the good looks he needs. \n \nAnd because the Warriors have been such a dominant regular season game, two or three 3-pointers from Curry is usually a knockout punch late in the third quarter. \n \nLast season, he played 60 fourth quarters in his 80 games. The Warriors have 35 games remaining this season. Saturday was already the 15th time Curry did not play the fourth quarter. After another third quarter explosion, the Warriors were up 43. \n \n ","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Marcus Thompson II"},"topics":[{"name":"Stockwatch","group":"Finance"}],"title":"Warriors embarrass Clippers with Stephen Curry latest third quarter gem","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Contra Costa","zipCode":"94598","state":"California","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Walnut Creek","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"East Bay Times","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"597831994","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"East Bay Times","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.eastbaytimes.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194891472","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:07Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:19:00Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.eastbaytimes.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/sjm-warriors-0129-111.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:19:04Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395675703","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"TENNIS TOURNAMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SPORTS; TENNIS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"500","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395793215&p=2kx&v=1&x=lKrtK0n2FNw6e93MHwUWiQ","id":"29395793215","content":"IANS \n \nMelbourne, Jan 29 (IANS) Sania Mirza's aim for her seventh major tennis title ended in despair as she and Croatian partner Ivan Dodig were beaten 2-6, 4-6 by unseeded American Abigail Spears and Colombian Juan Sebastian Cabal in the Australian Open mixed doubles final here on Sunday. \n \nThe Indo-Croatian pair accepted defeat in one hour and three minutes. \n \nSania was bidding for her seventh major tennis title, and first with Croatian partner Ivan Dodig, in the Australian Open mixed doubles final where the second seeds took on the unseeded American-Colombian pair. \n \nSania and Dodig were pushed on the backfoot at the onset of the match, getting broken twice to trail 0-4. Dodig lost his serve in the opening game of the match after a forehand unforced error. \n \nSania too lost her first service game, third of the first set, unable to return a backhand shot. \n \nThe Indo-Croatian pair took a while to get going and began to combine well in the later stages of the first set, winning their next two service games. But it wasn't enough to save the set, surrendering it 2-6. \n \nBut they stepped up their energy in the second set. Beginning to play more as a team, they attacked Spears' serve in the second game after Dodig won the first service game. \n \nThe pressure they applied paid dividends as Abigail-Cabal was hit a backhand volley wide to trail 0-2. Sania then held on to her serve to go 3-0 up. \n \nBut Sania-Dodig couldn't maintain the momentum. Sania was broken in the seventh game with a backhand volley winner. \n \nAbigail and Cabal held onto their serves to square the second set 4-4. \n \nDodig, yet to win a major title in mixed doubles, seemed nervous at the begging of the match owing to his relative inexperience in summit clashes. \n \nAnd he failed to control his nerves at crucial stages of the match, losing his serve in the ninth game with a double fault to trail 4-5. \n \nSpears served for the match in the 10th game and weren't subjected to much pressure, winning the championship with a forehand smash, which underlined their supremacy. \n \nIt was Sania's second Australian Open mixed doubles final after winning in 2009 with compatriot Mahesh Bhupathi.  \n \nPrior to Sunday's final, she won three mixed doubles titles, the last being the 2014 US Open with Brazilian Bruno Soares. \n \nThe 30-year-old Hyderabadi has six major titles in her kitty, three in mixed doubles and three in women's doubles. \n \nThe Indo-Croatian pair played their second Grand Slam final, having lost the French Open final to the experienced pair of Leander Paes and Martina Hingis last year. \n \nSania-Dodig overcame a tough one-hour-18-minute battle in the semi-final against Aussies Samantha Stosur and Sam Groth 6-4, 2-6, (10-5) on Friday. \n \nAbigail and Cabal defeated Elina Svitolina of Ukraine and Aussie Chris Guiccione 7-6 (1), 6-2 in the last four stage. \n \n© 2017 IANS India Private Limited. He alleged that the Liberals wanted to wrest police from Mr Grant, a senior Nationals MP.\n\n\"The Nationals wanted police, the right wing faction of the Liberals wanted police,\" he said. \"So she split it in two.\"\n\n\"It's the police who keep us safe from terrorism,\" Mr Foley said.\n\n\"The police commissioner now has to report to two people. It's scandalous and another deal that is counter to the public interest.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the troubled relationship between the NSW attorney-general and minister for police has been addressed, with Ms Berejiklian confirming a reshaping of the much maligned \"justice cluster\".\n\nThe arrangement, whereby as justice and police minister Mr Grant held a more senior position than then attorney-general Gabrielle Upton, was heavily criticised by the legal profession.\n\nThe NSW Bar Association said it provided Mr Grant \"with unprecedented power in determining legal policy without the historical checks and balances\".\n\nThe NSW Law Society warned the arrangement meant police were \"ostensibly responsible for criminal law policy, while at the same time, the traditional roles of the attorney-general as first law officer of the state, which includes preserving civil liberties, are being eroded\".\n\nMs Berejiklian has confirmed the cluster has been reworked so that new attorney-general Mark Speakman, SC, is the lead minister. November's total of $718 million was up by $123 million compared with a year earlier.\n\nThe results reversed a mid-year slump in the state's stamp duty receipts.\n\nTurnover was very strong in the final quarter of the year. Stamp duty was paid on 21,239 residential transfers across NSW in December, which was 31 per cent higher than in July.\n\nThe average stamp duty received per transaction in December was $34,385 \u2013 around $2100 more than the corresponding month a year earlier.\n\nThe strong stamp duty figures suggest Sydney's property market defied predictions of a slow-down and picked up pace in late 2016.\n\nFigures released by the Domain Group last Tuesday showed Sydney's median house price jumped 4.7 per cent in last three months of the year to reach $1.124 million. The city's median unit prices rose nearly 3 per cent in the quarter to $711,256.\n\nDomain's measure of Sydney's median house price has risen by 69 per cent \u2013 or $450,000 \u2013 in the past four years.\n\nWhile the end-of-year surge in stamp duty will bolster the state's already healthy bottom line, the figures also underscore how difficult it will be for the new Premier, Gladys Berejiklian, to improve housing affordability.\n\nAt her first press conference as Premier last week Ms Berejiklian vowed to address the housing affordability crisis, declaring it \"the biggest issue people have across the state\".\n\nShe said specific policies to deal with this challenge would be outlined \"in the near future\".\n\nStamp duty revenue will get a further boost in coming months as a new surcharge on the stamp duty paid by foreign investors comes into effect. The surcharge was introduced in the June 2016 state budget but revenue from the new measure is not expected until early this year.\n\nSydney's four-year housing boom has helped deliver the state government a massive increase in the transfer duty levies on the transfer of property and other assets.\n\nIn 2011-12, just before the boom began, the government received $3.8 billion in transfer duty but that had swelled to nearly $9 billion by 2015-16.\n\nResidential stamp duty alone accounted for about 9 per cent of the state government's revenue last financial year.\n\nThe half-yearly review of the NSW budget, released last month, lifted the forecast for the state's budget surplus for this financial year by about $300 million to $4 billion.\n\nThe story Boom bolsters Berejiklian's bottom NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"}],"wordCount":"824","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395793351&p=2kx&v=1&x=WQzMxQ1MvA87PAlCSU9QvA","id":"29395793351","content":"The new premier has pledged to govern for all of NSW but Labor says the new ministry rewards factional operatives. \n\nGladys Berejiklian has unveiled a cabinet to fight the 2019 election in the face of a revitalised Labor opposition and a rising minor party vote in the regions, including a resurgent One Nation.\n\nMs Berejiklian and Deputy Premier and Nationals leader John Barilaro announced the new line-up at Queanbeyan, in the regional seat of Monaro held by Mr Barilaro on a margin of just 2.5 per cent.\n\nThe unusual decision follows the Nationals' disastrous loss in last year's Orange byelection to the Shooters, Fishers and Farmers party, which has pledged to target other regional seats.\n\nIn a reshuffle designed to \"reset\" the government for 2019, four ministers have been dumped from cabinet: Nationals Adrian Piccoli who had education; Duncan Gay who held roads; and Leslie Williams who had early childhood education and Aboriginal affairs. Also out of cabinet is Liberal MLC John Ajaka, who was minister for ageing, disability services and multiculturalism. However, Mr Ajaka is set to become President of the Legislative Council.\n\nIn strategic appointments with an eye on the crucial electoral battleground of western Sydney, two new MPs from the area, Mulgoa's Tanya Davies and Castle Hill MP Ray Williams, have been elevated to cabinet.\n\nMs Berejiklian has also created the new portfolio of minister for WestConnex, to be held by Penrith MP Stuart Ayres, who is also minister for western Sydney.\n\nThe move is being seen as an attempt to reset the discussion about the $16.8 billion road project from complaints about the disruption of inner-Sydney communities to the benefits it will bring commuting western Sydney families.\n\nAnother surprise announcement is the new position of minister for counter terrorism which Ms Berejiklian said was necessary \"unfortunately due to the circumstances our world is in\".\n\nLiberal MP David Elliott \u2013 a leader of the centre-right faction that supported Ms Berejiklian's election as Liberal leader and premier after the retirement from politics of former premier Mike Baird \u2013 adds the role to his existing portfolio area of corrections.\n\nIt will involve liaising with state, Commonwealth and international counter terrorism bodies.\n\nUnveiling the new cabinet, Ms Berejiklian repeated the pledge that her government would listen, consult and act and \"wants to make sure every single community across NSW gets its fair share\".\n\nMr Piccoli will be replaced in education by Rob Stokes, whose planning portfolio will be taken over by former industry and energy minister Anthony Roberts.\n\nMr Roberts, a leader of the right faction whose numbers also supported Ms Berejiklian's election, also becomes special minister of state.\n\nNationals MP for Oxley Melinda Pavey enters cabinet to take over the roads portfolio from Mr Gay, while her party colleague Sarah Mitchell has been promoted to the ministry to take on early childhood education and Aboriginal affairs.\n\nAmong the biggest winners are two of Ms Berejiklian's strongest supporters in her own left faction: former Legislative Council president Don Harwin and Hornsby MP and former parliamentary secretary Matt Kean.\n\nMr Harwin comes into cabinet as energy and resources minister and minister for the arts.\n\nHe has also been appointed leader of the government in the Legislative Council. Mr Kean enters cabinet as minister for innovation and better regulation.\n\nMr Harwin and Mr Kean were key to engineering the numbers to have Ms Berejiklian elected leader.\n\nIn other Nationals promotions Adam Marshall will head tourism and major events, which has been taken from Mr Ayres.\n\nDeputy Nationals leader and primary industries and water minister Niall Blair picks up the trade portfolio from Mr Ayres and the key jobs portfolio of industry from Mr Roberts.\n\nFormer deputy premier and Nationals leader Troy Grant has held onto police and adds emergency services to his responsibilities.\n\nFormer local government minister Paul Toole becomes minister for lands and forestry as well as racing.\n\nPru Goward moves from mental health and women to her former portfolio of family and community services. She remains minister for the prevention of domestic violence.\n\nVeteran Liberal MP Brad Hazzard will move from family and community services to health following Jillian Skinner's decision to quit politics after being told she could not remain in the portfolio.\n\nCronulla MP Mark Speakman, a senior barrister, moves from environment to attorney-general, replacing Vaucluse MP Gabrielle Upton who takes over environment.\n\nMs Upton has also been handed the challenging local government portfolio amid unrest over forced mergers including from Woollahra Council in her electorate. Victor Dominello moves from innovation and better regulation to finance.\n\nAndrew Constance remains Transport and Infrastructure Minister and Deputy Liberal leader Dominic Perrottet will move from finance to become treasurer as expected.\n\nOpposition leader Luke Foley said the reshuffle \"is not about serving the interests of the people of NSW\".\n\n\"It's about serving the interests of the backroom operators and lurk merchants of the Liberal Party to whom Ms Berejiklian is beholden to.\" The story first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Sean Nicholls"},"topics":[{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Cabinet shakeup as Gladys Berejiklian resets for 2019","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","state":"New South Wales","countryCode":"AU","zipArea":"Kogarah","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"St George & Sutherland Shire Leader","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169697910","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"6"},"name":"St George & Sutherland Shire Leader","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.theleader.com.au","publisher":"Fairfax Media"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194898097","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:59:48Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:19:05Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://nnimgt-a.akamaihd.net/transform/v1/crop/frm/silverstone-feed-data/fb29f073-02ed-46ee-9fcb-a76504dad85e.jpg/r2_0_728_410_w1200_h678_fmax.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"95"}],"wordCount":"481","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395793389&p=2kx&v=1&x=x1KqJmR7Gx2VcjbtokrYKg","id":"29395793389","content":"Labor warns that the NSW police commissioner must report to two ministers under the change \n\nThe appointment of a new minister for counter-terrorism in NSW has been slammed by the Labor opposition as irresponsible and against the public interest.\n\nUnveiling a cabinet reshuffle on Sunday, Premier Gladys Berejiklian announced corrections minister David Elliott \u2013 not police minister Troy Grant \u2013 would take on the new role.\n\nShe said it was required \"unfortunately due to the circumstances our world is in\".\n\n\"The sad reality is that this is an area of focus for governments around the world \u2013 NSW is already working closely with the Commonwealth and I want the Minister to take this work forward,\" Ms Berejiklian said.\n\n\"Mr Elliott will work closely with the Attorney General, Minister for Police, the Minister for Education, the Minister for Family and Community Services and the Minister for Multiculturalism, as well as our federal counterparts, to ensure a whole-of-government approach to this issue\".\n\nUnder the change, the Terrorism (Commonwealth Powers) Act and the Terrorism (Police Powers) Act will remain the responsibility of the Attorney General.\n\nMr Elliott will provide strategic policy direction for counter-terrorism in NSW, while the police will manage the tactical and operational response to terrorist attacks or threats.\n\nMr Elliott told Fairfax Media: \"Over the coming weeks I will be working to coordinate all stakeholders to ensure that the people of NSW can sleep soundly in the knowledge that we are as best prepared for any contingency as we can be.\"\n\nBut opposition leader Luke Foley said the appointment was the result of an irresponsible deal. He alleged that the Liberals wanted to wrest police from Mr Grant, a senior Nationals MP.\n\n\"The Nationals wanted police, the right wing faction of the Liberals wanted police,\" he said. \"So she split it in two.\"\n\n\"It's the police who keep us safe from terrorism,\" Mr Foley said.\n\n\"The police commissioner now has to report to two people. It's scandalous and another deal that is counter to the public interest.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the troubled relationship between the NSW attorney-general and minister for police has been addressed, with Ms Berejiklian confirming a reshaping of the much maligned \"justice cluster\".\n\nThe arrangement, whereby as justice and police minister Mr Grant held a more senior position than then attorney-general Gabrielle Upton, was heavily criticised by the legal profession.\n\nThe NSW Bar Association said it provided Mr Grant \"with unprecedented power in determining legal policy without the historical checks and balances\".\n\nThe NSW Law Society warned the arrangement meant police were \"ostensibly responsible for criminal law policy, while at the same time, the traditional roles of the attorney-general as first law officer of the state, which includes preserving civil liberties, are being eroded\".\n\nMs Berejiklian has confirmed the cluster has been reworked so that new attorney-general Mark Speakman, SC, is the lead minister. The story first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Sean Nicholls"},"topics":[{"name":"Terrorism news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"New counter terrorism role slammed as 'against the public interest'","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","zipCode":"2582","state":"New South Wales","countryCode":"AU","zipArea":"Yass","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Yass Tribune","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169699270","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Yass Tribune","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.yasstribune.com.au","publisher":"Fairfax Media"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194899870","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:29:42Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:19:06Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://nnimgt-a.akamaihd.net/transform/v1/crop/frm/silverstone-feed-data/ee974bdb-c7e3-4991-93f1-8b638bee948c.jpg/r2_0_728_410_w1200_h678_fmax.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

The Rams also had a massive effort from Deontae Plouffe, who chipped in 16 points and nine rebounds. Lastly, Dyrell Rucker had 13 of his own. \n \nLynn Classical\u2019s high scoring and athletic offense kept them in front by a large margin for most of the game. \n \nBeverly, having played from behind, made things interesting late. Hugh Calice provided some muscle down low as he quietly had eight points and five rebounds. \n \nThe Panthers put up a great fight as the home crowd helped bring them back into the game, erasing a 16-point deficit in the fourth quarter. With 10 seconds left, Beverly had a shot to tie the game as Derrane\u2019s 3-point effort fell short and the Rams came out on top to remain undefeated. \n \nLynn Classical\u2019s athleticism and quick ball movement was the key to success for an undersized but versatile team that only features three seniors. With the win, Lynn Classical moved to 9-0 in the conference and Beverly fell to 7-3. \n \nThe Panthers could take away quite a few positives from this effort as Gavin had a career day and Beverly would not go down without a fight. \n \nBoth of these teams are poised for postseason runs as the offense behind the arc will keep them in any game. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:19:08Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395793575","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"PHYSICAL FITNESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"EXERCISE & FITNESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"YOGA","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SPORTS INSTRUCTION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"SINGAPORE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"87"}],"wordCount":"923","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395793575&p=2kx&v=1&x=VBn1VISAEiN-dvb6Vq5mrw","id":"29395793575","content":"Cards and flowers are lovely, but the best gift to give mum is your time! Create some new memories with her over one of these fun Mother\u2019s Day activities  \nMothers are meant to be pampered all year round, but the upcoming Mother\u2019s Day gives extra reason to show just how much you appreciate her unconditional love! Ditch any plans to purchase a pricey gift, and instead splurge on an activity you can both do together. After all, no pearls or diamonds could compare to the many hours she\u2019ll be spending with her daughter! \n \n\n Yoga In The Dark  \nAll of us have tried yoga before, but switching it up a little sounds like fun, doesn\u2019t it? Sign mum and yourself up for a session of yoga in the dark, where you\u2019ll both be blindfolded throughout! Yes, girls \u2013 blindfolded! This is a chance to connect deeply with your body, all while becoming more attuned to your senses. Although there might not be much talking to one another during class, you can both have some tea or brunch after to chat about the unique experience! \n \nYoga In The Dark , Farrer Road, Singapore 268836, for bookings, visit here . \n \n\n Bounce Fitness Class  \nKulture Studios , Singapore\u2019s first official jumping fitness studio, vows to push you to your limits with exercises containing high energy but low impact moves. The energetic workout lets you lose major calories while bouncing around on a trampoline; something we suppose will turn out to be tons of fun! But, go easy on mummy, okay? We wouldn\u2019t want her to break anything! \n \nKulture Studios , 1 Stadium Place, #02-05 Kallang Wave Mall, Singapore 397628, (+65) 6384 6680, www.kulture.com.sg \n \n\n Breakfast Ceramics Workshop  \nFor all the meals mama has lovingly made for you, why don\u2019t you thank her with a ceramic workshop at Studio Asobi , where you\u2019ll be able to take matching sets of breakfast ceramics home? Recommended for beginners, the class will have you both pinching and sculpting clay from scratch, a chance to discover the hidden artist within yourselves. The end products need to stay at the studio for a month before you can take them home, but once you do, you can both enjoy hearty meals together with your handmade plates! \n \nBlock 705 Hougang Ave 2, Singapore 530705, visit here for more information and to reserve a slot. \n \n\n Modern Calligraphy Session  \nIf your mum is a calligraphy enthusiast ( or actually, even if she\u2019s not! ), take her to a modern calligraphy class with The Letter J Supply , where you\u2019ll both learn to use a traditional dip nib pen in a modern context. They aim to equip you with the fundamental skills, which will eventually lead you towards developing a style of your own. Since you\u2019ll be paying for and taking home the necessary tools, both you and mum can practise together in the future and pen notes to one another! \n \nThe Modern Calligraphy Workshop is held at Bynd Artisan Atelier , 44 Jalan Merah Saga #01-54, Singapore 278116, visit here for more information and to reserve a slot. \n \n\n Watercolour Workshop  \nNatalie Studio runs a series of watercolour workshops from time to time, and it\u2019ll be an ultra fun experience for both you and your mum! We recommend their basic workshop if you aren\u2019t familiar with the craft, but the floral-inspired watercolour classes seem exciting for those who feel like they might have the chops for it. Besides, who doesn\u2019t love painting floras? You know what the best thing is? If you attend both the modern calligraphy workshop by The Letter J Supply and this watercolour class, combining the two skill sets helps create a beautiful masterpiece that you can display in your home! \n \nNatalie Studio , Clementi, for more information visit www.nataliestudio.tictail.com or email hello@ilovenataliestudio.com . \n \n\n Make Your Own Clay Necklaces  \nRemember the good ol\u2019 days when you and your mama had some great laughs playing dress up? Those fun moments may be few and far between now that you\u2019re all grown up, but a clay necklace workshop by  Average Jo can help bring back some fond memories. The course isn\u2019t merely about making the necklace itself, but includes tips on colour theory too, for when you go crazy painting your newly made accessory. Aww, imagine how cute it\u2019ll be wearing matching necklaces out this coming Mother\u2019s Day! \n \nAverage Jo , 1 Stars Avenue, #03-10A, Mediacorp Campus, Singapore 138507, visit here for more information and to reserve a slot. \n \n\n Floral Arrangement  \nAll girls love flowers, so we bet your mum does too! She\u2019ll appreciate attending a floral arrangement class with you, one where florist Bisoufleur teaches students how to create their very own handheld bouquet. It\u2019ll be quite an interesting experience too, since you\u2019ll be dealing with blooms that are considerably more exotic in nature. And you know what to do with your completed bouquet? Give it to mummy for Mother\u2019s Day! \n \n195 Pearl\u2019s Hill Terrace, Level 3, Singapore 168976, visit here for more information and to reserve a slot. \n \n\n Tulipmania At Gardens By The Bay  \nLike we said, all girls love florals. And that\u2019s reason enough to take your mum to Tulipmania at Gardens By The Bay \u2018s Flower Dome, where you\u2019ll be able to witness the beauty a sea of tulips bring.
